column3: John is a 4-year-old boy with Down syndrome who was diagnosed shortly after birth. His parents are concerned about his development, particularly his delayed speech and motor skills. John has a characteristic facial appearance with a small head, upward-slanting eyes, and a flattened nose bridge. He also has a single crease across his palms and a wide space between his first and second toes. John has a congenital heart defect, which is common in children with Down syndrome. He is receiving early intervention services to help with his speech and motor development.
column10: Mary is a 30-year-old woman with Down syndrome who lives with her parents. She has a job at a local grocery store and enjoys spending time with her family and friends. Mary has a mild intellectual disability and relies on her parents for support with daily tasks. She has a history of thyroid problems and is taking medication to manage her thyroid levels. Mary also has a tendency to develop ear infections and requires regular check-ups with her primary care physician.

column3: Samantha is a 10-year-old girl with Romano-Ward syndrome, a rare genetic disorder that affects the electrical system of the heart. She was diagnosed after her parents noticed that she had been experiencing episodes of fainting and had an irregular heartbeat. Samantha has a family history of sudden cardiac arrest, which prompted her doctors to perform genetic testing. She has been prescribed medication to help regulate her heart rhythm and is advised to avoid strenuous exercise and certain medications that can trigger arrhythmias.
column10: Mark is a 28-year-old man with Romano-Ward syndrome, a rare genetic disorder that affects the electrical system of the heart. He was diagnosed with the condition after experiencing several episodes of fainting and irregular heartbeat. Mark has a family history of sudden cardiac arrest, which prompted his doctors to perform genetic testing. He has been prescribed medication to help regulate his heart rhythm and is advised to avoid strenuous exercise and certain medications that can trigger arrhythmias.

column3: Emma is a 7-year-old girl who has been diagnosed with Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD), a genetic disorder that causes cysts to develop in the kidneys. Emma has a family history of the condition, and her parents noticed that she had high blood pressure and protein in her urine during a routine check-up. Further tests confirmed the diagnosis of ADPKD, and Emma is being closely monitored by a pediatric nephrologist.
column10: David is a 45-year-old man who has been diagnosed with Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD), a genetic disorder that causes cysts to develop in the kidneys. David has a family history of the condition, and he has been experiencing back pain and frequent urinary tract infections. Further tests confirmed the diagnosis of ADPKD, and David is being closely monitored by a nephrologist.

column3: Mary is a 5-year-old girl with 22q11.2 deletion syndrome. She was diagnosed at birth due to her characteristic facial features, including a small mouth and low-set ears. She also has a heart defect that was repaired at 3 months of age. Mary has delayed speech and language development and has difficulty with fine motor skills such as writing and cutting. She also experiences recurrent ear infections and has a history of feeding difficulties due to her small mouth. Mary's parents report that she has a happy and friendly personality but can become easily overwhelmed in busy or noisy environments. They are concerned about her academic and social development as she prepares to start kindergarten in the fall.
column10: Sarah is a 28-year-old woman with a history of 22q11.2 deletion syndrome. She was diagnosed with the condition as a child after experiencing recurrent infections and developmental delays. Sarah has a unique facial appearance with a small head and low-set ears, as well as some cognitive and behavioral challenges. Sarah has a history of cardiac abnormalities and has had several surgeries to correct these issues. She also experiences gastrointestinal problems, including frequent vomiting and diarrhea. Sarah has difficulty with social interactions and is prone to anxiety and depression. Despite these challenges, she has a great sense of humor and enjoys spending time with her family and friends.Sarah's medical team monitors her closely for any new cardiac or gastrointestinal issues and provides ongoing support for her mental health. She receives speech and occupational therapy to help with her communication and daily living skills. Overall, Sarah's care team works together to provide comprehensive care for her unique needs.

column3: Sarah is a 5-year-old girl who has been diagnosed with Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). She was brought to the clinic by her parents, who noticed multiple café-au-lait spots on her skin and a small lump under her right arm. Upon examination, the doctor also found some small bumps on her skin, called neurofibromas. Sarah's parents reported that she has been experiencing frequent headaches, and the doctor ordered an MRI to check for any abnormalities in her brain. The MRI revealed some small tumors in her brain, which are common in children with NF1. The doctor explained to Sarah's parents that NF1 is a genetic disorder that affects the growth and development of nerve cells, and can cause various complications such as learning disabilities, vision problems, and hearing loss. The doctor recommended regular check-ups to monitor Sarah's condition and manage any symptoms that may arise.
column10: Emily is a 32-year-old woman who was diagnosed with Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) during her teenage years. She has multiple café-au-lait spots on her skin and has developed several benign tumors on her skin, including a plexiform neurofibroma on her thigh that causes chronic pain and discomfort. Emily has also experienced hearing loss in her left ear and has developed scoliosis. She is concerned about the potential impact of NF1 on her quality of life and is seeking more information about potential treatments to manage her symptoms. Emily's medical team is closely monitoring the growth of her tumors and has recommended physical therapy to help manage her scoliosis and chronic pain. They have also suggested hearing aids to improve her hearing and provided resources for counseling and support groups to address the emotional and social impact of living with NF1.

column3: A 4-year-old boy was brought to the pediatrician by his parents due to developmental delays and behavioral issues. The child was born at term with no complications during pregnancy or delivery. However, the parents noticed that he was not meeting developmental milestones, including sitting up, crawling, and walking, on time. He also had delayed language development and showed signs of hyperactivity and attention deficit. Upon physical examination, the child had a long, narrow face with a prominent forehead and ears. His joints were hypermobile, and his muscle tone was low. The pediatrician also noted that the child had a prominent jaw and a high-arched palate. The child's behavior during the examination was irritable and anxious. Given the clinical presentation, the pediatrician suspected Fragile X syndrome, a genetic disorder that causes intellectual disability, developmental delays, and behavioral problems. The pediatrician referred the child for genetic testing, which confirmed the diagnosis of Fragile X syndrome.
column10: A 30-year-old male with Fragile X syndrome presented to the clinic with symptoms of anxiety and depression. He had a history of delayed development, language and social skills deficits, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) in childhood. On examination, he had a long face with a prominent jaw and large ears, and his joints were hypermobile. He had a mild intellectual disability with an IQ of 75, and he exhibited social anxiety and avoidance behaviors. Genetic testing confirmed a diagnosis of Fragile X syndrome, which is caused by a mutation in the FMR1 gene. The patient was started on a low dose of an antidepressant medication and referred to a specialized clinic for further management of his condition. It was emphasized that early intervention and management can improve the overall quality of life for individuals with Fragile X syndrome.

column3: Tommy is a 7-year-old boy who was referred to a pediatric ophthalmologist due to concerns about his vision. His parents noticed that he was having difficulty seeing in dimly lit environments and frequently tripping over objects that he couldn't see. Upon examination, the ophthalmologist noted that Tommy had a progressive loss of peripheral vision, which is a hallmark symptom of Retinitis pigmentosa. Additionally, the ophthalmologist observed that Tommy's retina had characteristic pigment changes, which further confirmed the diagnosis. Tommy's parents were counseled about the progressive nature of the disease and the need for regular follow-up visits to monitor his vision. The ophthalmologist also discussed the potential benefits of low vision aids and provided a referral to a low vision specialist
column10: John is a 45-year-old man who has been experiencing difficulty seeing in dimly lit areas and has noticed a gradual loss of his peripheral vision over the past few years. He has a family history of vision problems and after a comprehensive eye exam, he was diagnosed with Retinitis Pigmentosa (RP). RP is a genetic disorder that causes the degeneration of the retina, leading to progressive vision loss. John's clinical features include night blindness, tunnel vision, and difficulty with color perception. He is currently being monitored by his ophthalmologist for any further deterioration of his vision and is receiving low vision aids to help him with his daily activities.

column3: Sarah is a 6-year-old girl who has been diagnosed with Mucolipidosis type III. She was born with no apparent health issues, but her parents noticed that she was not meeting her developmental milestones as expected. They also noticed that she had a stiff gait and was not able to run and jump like other children her age. Upon examination, Sarah's doctors noted that she had joint stiffness and limited range of motion in her hips, knees, and ankles. She also had a short stature and a mild facial coarsening. Her hearing and vision were normal, and there were no signs of organ enlargement or dysfunction.Further testing revealed that Sarah had elevated levels of certain enzymes in her blood, which confirmed the diagnosis of Mucolipidosis type III. This rare genetic disorder affects the body's ability to break down certain sugars and fats, leading to the accumulation of substances in the cells and tissues. Sarah's doctors recommended a multidisciplinary approach to manage her condition, including physical therapy to improve her mobility and joint function, growth hormone therapy to address her short stature, and regular monitoring of her organ function. They also advised her parents to seek genetic counseling to understand the risks of passing on the condition to future children.
column10: Mrs. Johnson is a 32-year-old woman with Mucolipidosis type III. She was diagnosed with the condition at the age of 6, after experiencing delayed milestones and difficulty walking. She has a history of recurrent respiratory infections, hearing loss, and joint stiffness. Mrs. Johnson also has short stature and a barrel-shaped chest. Despite her physical limitations, she is a determined and independent individual who enjoys spending time with her family and friends. She currently receives regular physical therapy and respiratory treatments to manage her symptoms.

column3: Samantha is a 7-year-old girl who has been experiencing frequent respiratory infections and difficulty breathing for the past few months. Her parents noticed that she has been coughing more frequently, especially at night, and has been feeling tired and fatigued. Samantha's pediatrician ran some tests and found that she has Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency, a genetic disorder that affects the liver and lungs. This condition causes a deficiency in the protein alpha-1-antitrypsin, which helps protect the lungs from damage caused by enzymes released during inflammation. Without enough of this protein, the lungs are more susceptible to damage and infections. Samantha's pediatrician has recommended that she receive regular monitoring of her lung function and treatment to manage her symptoms, which may include bronchodilators, corticosteroids, and antibiotics as needed. She may also need to avoid exposure to smoke and other irritants that can further damage her lungs.
column10: John is a 45-year-old man who has been experiencing shortness of breath and wheezing for several months. He is a non-smoker and has no history of asthma or allergies. He recently underwent pulmonary function tests that revealed obstructive lung disease, and subsequent genetic testing confirmed a diagnosis of Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency. Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency is a genetic disorder that affects the liver and lungs. It is caused by a deficiency of the alpha-1-antitrypsin protein, which normally protects the lungs from damage caused by enzymes released during inflammation. Without this protein, the lungs are more susceptible to damage from inflammation, leading to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and emphysema. John's diagnosis highlights the importance of genetic testing for patients with unexplained obstructive lung disease, especially if they are non-smokers. Treatment for Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency may include medications to manage symptoms, pulmonary rehabilitation, and in severe cases, lung transplantation.

column3: Sarah is a 10-year-old girl with Marfan syndrome who presents to the clinic for a routine check-up. She was diagnosed with the condition at age 5 after her parents noticed that she was taller than her peers and had unusually long fingers and limbs. Sarah has a tall stature with a slender build, and her arm span is greater than her height. She also has a high-arched palate, a narrow face, and crowded teeth. During the physical exam, the doctor notes that Sarah has a heart murmur and aortic regurgitation, which are common cardiovascular complications of Marfan syndrome. The doctor orders an echocardiogram to monitor her heart function and recommends regular follow-up appointments with a cardiologist. Sarah's parents express concern about her risk for developing scoliosis and ask about strategies to prevent or manage this complication. The doctor explains that regular monitoring with X-rays and bracing or surgery may be necessary if scoliosis develops. Overall, Sarah is doing well and is able to participate in regular physical activity, but her care team will continue to monitor her closely for any signs of cardiovascular or skeletal complications.
column10: John is a 35-year-old male who was recently diagnosed with Marfan syndrome. He presents with a tall and thin body habitus, with disproportionately long limbs and fingers. He reports a history of joint pain, particularly in his knees and hips, and has a history of dislocations. On physical exam, John has a high arched palate, crowded teeth, and a chest deformity called pectus excavatum. Additionally, he has a murmur on cardiac exam and his ophthalmologic exam reveals ectopia lentis, or dislocated lenses. John's family history is significant for a brother who also has Marfan syndrome and a father who died suddenly at a young age, possibly due to an aortic aneurysm. John is concerned about his own risk for aortic complications and is seeking further evaluation and management.

column3: A 6-year-old boy named Jack was brought to the pediatrician by his parents due to persistent diarrhea and abdominal pain. He had been experiencing these symptoms for several months, and his parents had noticed that he had lost weight and appeared pale and fatigued. Upon further investigation, the pediatrician discovered that Jack had Congenital sucrase-isomaltase deficiency, a rare genetic disorder that affects the ability to digest certain sugars. This condition causes chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and malabsorption of nutrients, which can lead to malnutrition and stunted growth. Jack's parents were advised to modify his diet by avoiding foods that contain sucrose and isomaltose, and to supplement his diet with lactose-free milk and other nutrient-rich foods. With these changes, Jack's symptoms improved and he was able to gain weight and resume normal activities.
column10: Mrs. Smith is a 35-year-old female with a history of chronic diarrhea and abdominal pain since childhood. She reports that her symptoms worsen after consuming foods high in carbohydrates, such as bread, pasta, and sweets. Mrs. Smith has been diagnosed with Congenital sucrase-isomaltase deficiency, a rare genetic disorder that impairs the body's ability to digest sucrose and maltose. She has been advised to follow a strict low-carbohydrate diet and take supplements to manage her symptoms. Despite these measures, she still experiences occasional episodes of diarrhea and abdominal discomfort, which significantly affect her quality of life. Mrs. Smith is seeking further guidance on how to manage her condition and improve her symptoms.

column3: Sarah is a 7-year-old girl who has been diagnosed with cystic fibrosis (CF) since birth. She presents with chronic cough, wheezing, and recurrent respiratory infections. Her parents report that she has difficulty gaining weight and has frequent episodes of abdominal pain and diarrhea. Sarah's sweat chloride test was positive, confirming the diagnosis of CF. She is currently receiving treatment with pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy and inhaled bronchodilators to help manage her symptoms. Her care team is closely monitoring her lung function and nutritional status to prevent complications and improve her quality of life.
column10: John is a 32-year-old male who has been diagnosed with cystic fibrosis since childhood. He presents to the clinic today with complaints of worsening shortness of breath, cough, and increased sputum production over the past few weeks. He reports a history of recurrent respiratory infections and has been hospitalized multiple times for exacerbations of his cystic fibrosis. On physical examination, he has decreased breath sounds and crackles on auscultation of his lungs. His oxygen saturation is 91% on room air. His pulmonary function tests show a significant decline in his forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1) compared to his baseline. John is currently being treated with inhaled bronchodilators, chest physiotherapy, and antibiotics for his exacerbation.

column3: Samantha is a 2-year-old girl with Trisomy 18, also known as Edwards syndrome. She was born with a low birth weight and has had several medical issues since birth. Samantha has a small head circumference, a small jaw, and clenched fists. She also has a heart defect and difficulty feeding. Samantha has developmental delays and has not yet achieved many milestones, such as sitting up or crawling. She requires frequent medical attention and has a team of healthcare providers working with her family to manage her care. Despite her challenges, Samantha is a happy and sweet child who loves to be held and cuddled.
column10: Mrs. Johnson is a 35-year-old woman who was diagnosed with Trisomy 18 during her pregnancy. She was advised to terminate the pregnancy, but she decided to carry the baby to term. Her daughter was born with a low birth weight and small size. The baby had a small head circumference, a cleft lip, and a heart defect. The baby had difficulty breathing and was admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit. The baby also had feeding difficulties and required a feeding tube. Mrs. Johnson was informed that her daughter's life expectancy was limited due to the severity of her condition.

column3: Tommy is a 5-year-old boy who was brought to the pediatrician's office by his parents due to persistent dry, scaly skin. His parents have noticed that his skin has been getting progressively worse over the past few months, and they have tried various moisturizers and creams without much improvement. On physical examination, Tommy has thick, scaly plaques covering most of his body, especially on his arms and legs. He also has small, red bumps on his cheeks and forehead. His hair is dry and brittle, and his nails are thickened and discolored. Based on these clinical features, Tommy is diagnosed with Recessive X-linked ichthyosis, a rare genetic disorder that affects the skin and other organs.
column10: John is a 35-year-old male who presents to the dermatology clinic with complaints of dry, scaly skin that has been present since birth. He reports that his skin becomes particularly dry and itchy during the winter months. On examination, John has large, dark, polygonal scales that are present over his entire body, with sparing of the face and scalp. He also has areas of erythema and hyperpigmentation. The scales are most pronounced on his extremities and trunk. John reports that his skin feels tight and uncomfortable, and he has tried various moisturizers and topical treatments with little relief. Based on these clinical features, John is diagnosed with Recessive X-linked ichthyosis, a rare genetic disorder that affects the skin's ability to shed dead cells, leading to the formation of thick, scaly skin.

column3: A 6-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a history of recurrent epistaxis and skin discolorations since infancy. His parents report that he has been experiencing frequent nosebleeds, often lasting for more than 10 minutes, and that they have noticed small red spots on his lips and tongue. The boy has also complained of abdominal pain and fatigue. On physical examination, the boy has multiple telangiectasias on his lips, tongue, and fingers, and a few on his face and ears. His mucous membranes are dry and his liver is enlarged. Based on these clinical features, the boy is diagnosed with Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT), a rare genetic disorder characterized by abnormal blood vessel formation. The recurrent nosebleeds and telangiectasias on his lips and tongue are classic features of HHT, while the abdominal pain and fatigue could be signs of anemia due to chronic blood loss. The enlarged liver is also a common finding in HHT, as abnormal blood vessels can form within the liver, leading to congestion and enlargement.
column10: A 35-year-old woman presented to the clinic with a history of recurrent nosebleeds since childhood, as well as a family history of similar episodes. She reported having several episodes of heavy bleeding in the past year, requiring multiple visits to the emergency department for nasal packing and cauterization. On examination, she had multiple telangiectasias on her lips, tongue, and fingers, as well as a systolic murmur on cardiac auscultation. Imaging studies revealed multiple pulmonary arteriovenous malformations (AVMs), consistent with a diagnosis of Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT). Genetic testing confirmed a mutation in the ENG gene. The patient was referred to a multidisciplinary team, including a hematologist, pulmonologist, and interventional radiologist for further management and treatment of her HHT-related complications.

column3: A 4-year-old boy was referred to a pediatric geneticist for evaluation of developmental delay and joint stiffness. His parents reported that he had missed several developmental milestones, including walking and talking, and had a history of recurrent ear infections. On examination, the child had short stature, coarse facial features, and limited range of motion in his joints. He also had hearing loss and a prominent forehead. X-ray studies revealed dysplasia of the hip and spine. Urine analysis showed elevated levels of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate, consistent with a diagnosis of Mucopolysaccharidosis type 4A (MPS 4A), also known as Morquio syndrome. Genetic testing confirmed a mutation in the GALNS gene. The child was referred to a multidisciplinary team, including a pediatric orthopedic surgeon and a physical therapist, for management of his MPS 4A-related complications.
column10: Mucopolysaccharidosis type 4A (MPS 4A), also known as Morquio syndrome, is a rare genetic disorder that affects both children and adults. A 30-year-old man presented to the clinic with complaints of joint pain, shortness of breath, and difficulty walking. He had a history of recurrent ear infections and had undergone multiple surgeries for hernias and spinal stenosis. On examination, he had short stature, a prominent forehead, and a barrel-shaped chest. He also had limited range of motion in his joints, particularly in his hips and knees. Pulmonary function tests revealed restrictive lung disease. X-ray studies showed dysplasia of the spine and hips. Urine analysis confirmed elevated levels of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate, consistent with a diagnosis of MPS 4A. Genetic testing confirmed a mutation in the GALNS gene. The patient was referred to a multidisciplinary team, including a pulmonologist, physical therapist, and orthopedic surgeon, for management of his MPS 4A-related complications.

column3: A 5-year-old girl named Emily was brought to the dentist by her parents for routine dental check-up. Emily has a history of weak and brittle teeth, which often break or chip while eating. Her parents also mentioned that her teeth appeared discolored and had a translucent appearance. Upon examination, the dentist observed that Emily had multiple teeth with enamel defects and a greyish-blue discoloration. The teeth were also smaller than normal and had a bulbous appearance. X-rays revealed that the enamel and dentin of her teeth were irregularly formed and had a thin layer of dentin, consistent with the diagnosis of Dentinogenesis Imperfecta.
column10: A 35-year-old woman presents to the dentist with a chief complaint of tooth sensitivity and discoloration. On examination, the patient has thin and translucent enamel, and the dentin appears yellow-brown in color with a mottled appearance. The patient also reports a history of multiple dental fractures and previous restorations. Based on these findings, the patient is diagnosed with Dentinogenesis imperfecta, a rare genetic disorder that affects the development of teeth.

column3: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his mother who reports that he has been experiencing recurrent episodes of kidney stones. The child has a history of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. The pediatrician suspects cystinuria, a genetic disorder that causes the buildup of cystine, an amino acid, in the kidneys and urine. Upon further examination, the pediatrician finds that the child has a family history of cystinuria and notes that the child's urine has a high concentration of cystine. The pediatrician orders a urine analysis and blood tests to confirm the diagnosis. The child is prescribed medication to dissolve the cystine buildup and prevent the formation of kidney stones.
column10: A 34-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain and urinary urgency. He reports a history of recurrent kidney stones, which he has been passing for the past few years. The patient has a family history of kidney stones and reports that his father and grandfather have also had recurrent kidney stones. On physical examination, the patient is in significant distress and appears to be in pain. His vital signs are stable, and his abdomen is tender to palpation in the right lower quadrant. A urinalysis reveals a high concentration of cystine crystals, and a CT scan confirms the presence of multiple kidney stones. Based on these findings, the patient is diagnosed with Cystinuria, a genetic disorder that results in the formation of kidney stones composed of cystine.

column3: A 10-year-old boy was brought to the ophthalmologist by his parents after they noticed that he had difficulty seeing in dim light and had trouble reading small print. The ophthalmologist performed a thorough eye examination and found that the boy had macular degeneration, which is a progressive deterioration of the central part of the retina. The ophthalmologist explained to the family that the boy had Stargardt disease, an inherited form of macular degeneration that affects children and young adults. The ophthalmologist noted that the most important clinical features of Stargardt disease include central vision loss, difficulty seeing in dim light, and the presence of yellowish flecks in the retina. The flecks, known as fundus flavimaculatus, are a hallmark of the disease and can be seen on a dilated eye exam. The ophthalmologist also explained that Stargardt disease is caused by mutations in the ABCA4 gene, which is responsible for producing a protein that helps remove toxic waste products from the retina.
column10: Patient X is a 45-year-old man who presents to the clinic with complaints of blurry vision and difficulty reading. He reports that he has had these symptoms for several years, but they have progressively worsened over time. Upon further examination, it is discovered that he has Stargardt disease. Stargardt disease is a genetic disorder that affects the retina, the part of the eye that senses light. The most common symptom of Stargardt disease is central vision loss, which can make it difficult to read or recognize faces. In Patient X's case, this is the primary complaint. Upon further examination, it is discovered that Patient X has yellowish deposits called lipofuscin in the retina. These deposits are a hallmark of Stargardt disease and are caused by the accumulation of toxic waste products in the retina.

column3: A 2-year-old boy was brought to the hospital by his parents due to concerns of developmental delay and abnormal physical features. Upon physical examination, the child was found to have a small head circumference, a wide and flat nasal bridge, low-set ears, and a small jaw. Additionally, his hands and feet were small and he had a single crease across his palms.Further investigations revealed that the child had a rare genetic disorder called Triploidy. This condition occurs when a fetus inherits three sets of chromosomes instead of the usual two, resulting in a total of 69 chromosomes instead of 46.
column10: A 32-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of irregular periods and difficulty conceiving for the past two years. She reports a history of two miscarriages in the first trimester. On physical examination, she has characteristic facial features such as a small head circumference, low-set ears, and a small jaw. Her blood pressure is elevated, and she has mild edema in her lower extremities. Further investigation reveals that the patient has triploidy, a rare chromosomal abnormality in which there are three sets of chromosomes (69 in total) instead of the usual two sets (46 in total). The patient is referred to a genetic counselor for further evaluation and management. It is important to note that individuals with triploidy often have severe developmental abnormalities and may not survive beyond the first few months of life. Therefore, early diagnosis and management are crucial for improving the prognosis and quality of life for affected individuals.

column3: A 6-year-old boy was brought to the hospital by his parents with complaints of muscle weakness, difficulty in walking, and delayed speech development. The child had a history of delayed motor milestones and had trouble running and jumping like other children his age. The parents also reported that the child had a history of frequent falls, especially while climbing stairs. Upon examination, the child was found to have muscle weakness and atrophy, particularly in the facial and neck muscles. The child's gait was also abnormal, with a waddling gait and a tendency to trip and fall. The child's speech was slurred and slow, and he had difficulty in pronouncing words. Further investigations, including electromyography (EMG), revealed the presence of myotonia, a condition where muscles are slow to relax after contraction. Genetic testing confirmed the diagnosis of Steinert myotonic dystrophy, an inherited neuromuscular disorder.
column10: A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with muscle stiffness and weakness that has been progressively worsening over the past few years. He has a family history of muscle disorders. On examination, the patient has prominent facial and neck muscle weakness, and his grip strength is reduced. The patient also has difficulty releasing his hand after making a fist. Muscle percussion myotonia is noted in the upper and lower extremities. The patient also exhibits gait difficulties and falls frequently. Further evaluation reveals a diagnosis of Steinert myotonic dystrophy, a genetic disorder characterized by muscle stiffness, weakness, and myotonia. Other clinical features of this condition can include cataracts, heart conduction abnormalities, and intellectual impairment. The patient is referred to a specialist for further management and genetic counseling.

column3: A 7-year-old boy named Jack was brought to the pediatrician by his parents for evaluation of his recurrent ear infections. The child had a history of frequent respiratory tract infections and difficulty breathing during sleep. Upon examination, the pediatrician noted that Jack had a small chin and a flat midface, which made his eyes appear to be positioned abnormally high. The boy also had a high-arched palate, a small jaw, and a cleft palate. Based on these findings, the pediatrician suspected that Jack might have Stickler syndrome, a genetic disorder that affects the connective tissue in the body. Stickler syndrome is known to cause abnormalities in the shape of the face and skull, as well as hearing loss, vision problems, and joint problems.
column10: A 36-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with complaints of recurrent joint pain and stiffness, particularly in his knees and hips. He also reports difficulty seeing at night and a family history of hearing loss. On physical examination, the patient has hypermobile joints with mild crepitus on movement. His visual acuity is reduced, and he has a high myopic refractive error. Audiometry reveals bilateral high-frequency hearing loss. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of Stickler syndrome.

column3: A 5-year-old boy presents to the clinic with complaints of recurrent vomiting and lethargy. He had a history of poor feeding and failure to thrive since infancy. On examination, the child appeared pale and dehydrated. Blood tests revealed hypoglycemia, metabolic acidosis, and elevated levels of liver enzymes. Further investigations showed high levels of medium chain fatty acids in the blood and urine, confirming a diagnosis of medium chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency (MCADD)
column10: A 32-year-old male patient presents to the emergency room complaining of severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. He reports having had multiple episodes of similar symptoms in the past, but this time it was much worse. On physical examination, the patient appears to be in distress, with tenderness in the epigastric region. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of liver enzymes and hypoglycemia. Further evaluation reveals that the patient has Medium chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency (MCADD), an inherited metabolic disorder that affects the breakdown of fatty acids for energy. MCADD is characterized by episodes of hypoglycemia, vomiting, lethargy, and seizures, especially during periods of fasting or stress. The patient's symptoms were likely triggered by a recent illness that caused him to skip meals and experience prolonged fasting.

column3: A 10-year-old child was brought to the clinic by her parents due to behavioral and motor changes that had been noticed over the past few months. The child had become increasingly irritable, aggressive, and had difficulty concentrating in school. Her parents also noticed that she had started to have involuntary movements in her arms and legs. On examination, the child had choreiform movements, which were more prominent in her upper limbs. She also had gait abnormalities and difficulty with balance. A detailed family history revealed that her father had been diagnosed with Huntington's disease a few years ago. Based on the clinical presentation and family history, the child was diagnosed with juvenile-onset Huntington's disease. Further investigations including genetic testing confirmed the diagnosis. The family was referred to a specialist for management and genetic counseling. The child was started on medications to manage her symptoms, and her parents were advised on the importance of regular follow-up visits to monitor disease progression and provide support for the child's care.
column10: A 50-year-old man was recently diagnosed with Huntington disease, a genetic disorder that causes progressive degeneration of brain cells. He has a family history of the disease, with his father and grandfather also affected. The patient initially presented with mild motor symptoms, such as involuntary movements of the arms and legs, which gradually worsened over time. He also experienced cognitive decline, including difficulty with memory, concentration, and decision-making. On physical examination, the patient exhibited chorea, a type of involuntary movement characterized by jerky, dance-like movements of the limbs and face. He also had bradykinesia, or slow movement, and rigidity in his limbs. The patient's psychiatric symptoms included depression, anxiety, and irritability, which are common in Huntington disease. He also had difficulty sleeping and had a history of suicidal thoughts.

column3: A 6-month-old infant was brought to the pediatrician for poor weight gain, irritability, and developmental delays. The infant was found to have elevated levels of phenylalanine in the blood and was diagnosed with Phenylketonuria (PKU). PKU is an inherited disorder in which the body cannot break down phenylalanine, an amino acid found in many foods. If left untreated, high levels of phenylalanine can cause brain damage and intellectual disability.
column10: A 30-year-old male presented to his primary care physician with complaints of fatigue, headaches, and difficulty concentrating. Upon further investigation, the patient revealed a history of Phenylketonuria (PKU), a rare genetic disorder characterized by the inability to break down the amino acid phenylalanine. The patient reported that he had been non-compliant with his low-phenylalanine diet for several months, which had led to his current symptoms.On physical examination, the patient appeared fatigued and had mild tremors in his hands. His neurological exam was normal, but laboratory tests revealed elevated levels of phenylalanine in his blood. The diagnosis of PKU was confirmed, and the patient was advised to strictly adhere to a low-phenylalanine diet and to take supplements to ensure adequate intake of other essential amino acids.

column3: A 7-year-old boy was brought to the emergency department by his parents after he fell off his bike and injured his knee. The boy had a history of hemophilia A, an inherited bleeding disorder in which the blood does not clot normally. Upon examination, there was swelling and tenderness in the affected knee joint. The boy also reported pain and difficulty moving the knee. These are common clinical features of hemophilia A. The medical team conducted laboratory tests which showed a prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), indicating a clotting factor deficiency. The boy was diagnosed with a joint bleed and was treated with factor VIII replacement therapy to stop the bleeding and prevent further complications. The parents were advised to monitor the child closely for any signs of bleeding or injury and to seek immediate medical attention if any symptoms occur.
column10: John is a 35-year-old man with Hemophilia A, an inherited bleeding disorder that affects the clotting factors in his blood. He has a history of frequent bleeding episodes, particularly in his joints and muscles. Recently, he has been experiencing pain and swelling in his right knee, which is a common site for bleeding in patients with Hemophilia A. On examination, John's right knee is warm, swollen and tender to the touch. He has limited range of motion and finds it difficult to walk. Laboratory tests confirm that John's clotting factor VIII levels are low, indicating that he is at risk of bleeding complications. Based on his symptoms and clinical presentation, John is diagnosed with a bleeding episode in his right knee joint.

column3: A 7-year-old boy was brought to the emergency department by his parents due to persistent nosebleeds that had been occurring for several days. The parents reported that the nosebleeds were not severe, but they were concerned because they had never lasted this long before. The child had a history of easy bruising and bleeding from minor cuts. On examination, the child appeared pale and had multiple petechiae on his arms and legs. His nose was actively bleeding at the time of the examination. The child's blood work revealed a prolonged bleeding time and decreased von Willebrand factor activity. Based on these findings, the child was diagnosed with Von Willebrand disease, a bleeding disorder that affects the blood's ability to clot. This condition is often inherited and can cause prolonged bleeding after injury or surgery, as well as spontaneous bleeding episodes.
column10: A 32-year-old female presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of heavy menstrual bleeding. She reports that her periods have been excessively heavy for as long as she can remember, and that she frequently experiences nosebleeds that are difficult to control. Upon further questioning, she reports a history of easy bruising and prolonged bleeding after minor cuts or injuries. She denies any history of significant trauma or major surgeries. On physical exam, the patient appears pale and fatigued. She has multiple bruises on her arms and legs, and there is evidence of recent bleeding from her nose. Laboratory testing reveals a low platelet count and prolonged bleeding time. Further testing confirms a diagnosis of Von Willebrand disease, a genetic bleeding disorder characterized by deficiency or dysfunction of the von Willebrand factor, a protein that plays a critical role in platelet function and clotting.

column3: A 4-year-old girl presents to her pediatrician with delayed developmental milestones and poor head growth. On examination, the child has microcephaly, a lack of social reciprocity, and loss of previously acquired skills. She also has a characteristic hand-wringing movement and intermittent episodes of hyperventilation. The pediatrician suspects Rett syndrome, a rare genetic disorder that primarily affects females. The child is referred to a specialist for further evaluation and management. Rett syndrome is caused by a mutation in the MECP2 gene, which affects brain development and leads to severe cognitive and physical disabilities. Early diagnosis and management of Rett syndrome are essential for optimal outcomes.
column10: Rett syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that affects brain development, leading to cognitive, motor, and behavioral problems. Here's a brief medical vignette of an adult with Rett syndrome: Sarah is a 25-year-old woman with Rett syndrome. She was diagnosed at the age of 2 after her parents noticed that she was not developing normally. Sarah has severe cognitive impairment and cannot speak or communicate effectively. She also has motor problems, including difficulty walking and using her hands. Sarah experiences frequent seizures, which are a common feature of Rett syndrome. She also has breathing problems, including episodes of apnea, which can be life-threatening. Sarah's behavior is characterized by anxiety, agitation, and self-injurious behaviors such as hand biting. Despite her challenges, Sarah's family provides her with a supportive environment and appropriate medical care. Her healthcare team includes a neurologist, a pulmonologist, and a psychiatrist. They work together to manage her symptoms and improve her quality of life.

column3: A 2-year-old female child was brought to the pediatric clinic with a history of developmental regression and seizures. Her parents noticed that she had stopped babbling and making eye contact around 12 months of age. Additionally, she had developed a characteristic rash on her face and limbs. On examination, the child had microcephaly and spasticity. The rash was found to be chilblain-like lesions on the fingers, toes, and ears. Brain imaging showed calcifications in the basal ganglia and white matter. Based on these findings, a diagnosis of Aicardi-Goutières syndrome was suspected.
column10: A 35-year-old male presented to the neurology clinic with a 2-year history of progressive weakness and spasticity in his lower extremities. He also reported a history of seizures, which had started 5 years ago. On examination, the patient had bilateral hyperreflexia and spasticity in his lower limbs. He had a characteristic chilblain-like rash on his fingers, toes, and ears. Brain imaging showed calcifications in the basal ganglia and white matter. Genetic testing revealed a mutation in the TREX1 gene, confirming a diagnosis of Aicardi-Goutières syndrome. The patient was started on antiepileptic medication for seizure control and referred to physical therapy for management of spasticity.

column3: A 7-year-old African American boy presents to the emergency room with severe pain in his arms and legs. He has a history of sickle cell anemia and has been experiencing these episodes of pain for the past few years. The pain is described as a sharp, throbbing sensation that is worse with movement. His parents report that he has been fatigued and pale over the past few days. On physical examination, the child appears pale and tired. His temperature is normal, but his heart rate is elevated. His arms and legs are tender to touch, and he winces when they are moved. His spleen is enlarged, and his liver is palpable below the costal margin. Laboratory tests reveal a low hemoglobin level and an elevated white blood cell count, suggesting an acute sickle cell crisis. The child is admitted to the hospital and started on intravenous fluids and pain medication. He receives a blood transfusion to increase his hemoglobin levels and reduce the sickling of his red blood cells. He is closely monitored for signs of complications, such as acute chest syndrome or stroke. The medical team works with the child and his family to develop a plan for managing his sickle cell disease and preventing future crises.
column10: A 32-year-old African American male with a history of sickle cell anemia presents to the emergency room with severe pain in his arms and legs. He reports that the pain started suddenly and has been getting worse over the past few hours. He rates the pain as a 9/10 in intensity and describes it as a sharp, stabbing pain that radiates down his limbs. He also reports feeling short of breath and dizzy. On examination, the patient appears pale and slightly jaundiced. His heart rate is elevated, and his blood pressure is slightly low. His oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. He has diffuse tenderness to palpation of his extremities, particularly in the long bones. There is no evidence of focal neurologic deficit. Given his history of sickle cell anemia, the patient is diagnosed with a vaso-occlusive crisis and is started on intravenous fluids and pain control. He is also given oxygen therapy to help improve his oxygen saturation. Additional workup is performed to rule out infection or other complicating factors.

column3: A 6-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician with a history of frequent falls and difficulty running and climbing stairs. He has been experiencing progressive muscle weakness for the past year, and his parents have noticed that he has trouble keeping up with his peers during physical activities. On examination, the child has a waddling gait and has difficulty standing up from a squatting position. He also has calf muscle pseudohypertrophy and decreased muscle tone in his upper extremities. The pediatrician suspects Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) and orders a creatine kinase (CK) level, which is found to be elevated. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of DMD. The pediatrician counsels the parents about the progressive nature of the disease and the need for ongoing management, including physical therapy and orthopedic interventions to prevent contractures and scoliosis. The child is referred to a specialist center for further evaluation and management.
column10: A 32-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of muscle weakness and difficulty walking. He reports a history of delayed motor milestones during childhood and was diagnosed with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) at age 5. On physical examination, he has significant proximal muscle weakness in both upper and lower extremities, with marked wasting of the calves and thighs. He also has a positive Gower's sign, where he uses his arms to help push himself up from a seated position. His creatine kinase levels are markedly elevated, indicating ongoing muscle breakdown. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of DMD, which is characterized by progressive muscle weakness and wasting due to a mutation in the dystrophin gene. The patient is referred to a neuromuscular specialist for further management, including physical therapy, respiratory support, and genetic counseling.

column3: A 10-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician's office with complaints of multiple skin lesions on his face, trunk, and extremities. He also reports having frequent bloody stools and abdominal pain. On physical examination, the child has multiple pigmented lesions on his face, including multiple café-au-lait spots and freckles. He also has multiple polyps in his colon, which were identified on colonoscopy. The pediatrician suspects the child has Gardner syndrome, a hereditary condition characterized by the development of multiple polyps in the colon and tumors in various other organs.
column10: A 35-year-old male presents with multiple colon polyps and a family history of colorectal cancer. Upon further evaluation, he is diagnosed with Gardner syndrome, a rare autosomal dominant disorder characterized by the presence of numerous adenomatous colon polyps, osteomas, and soft tissue tumors. He reports having multiple jaw cysts and experiencing dental problems. Physical examination reveals multiple skin lesions, including epidermoid cysts and desmoid tumors. The patient is referred for genetic counseling and screening for other associated malignancies, including thyroid cancer and hepatoblastoma. Treatment options include surgical removal of polyps and tumors, as well as regular surveillance to monitor for the development of additional tumors.

column3: A 6-month-old male infant is brought to the pediatrician's office by his parents due to concerns about poor feeding and delayed development. The child was born at full term without any complications but has not met any of his developmental milestones. He has also been experiencing frequent respiratory infections and has difficulty breathing at night. On physical examination, the infant is noted to have several clinical features consistent with CHARGE syndrome, including coloboma (a hole in the iris of the eye), choanal atresia (blockage of the nasal passage), and facial asymmetry. The infant also has a heart murmur, a small jaw, and a cleft palate. Further evaluation, including genetic testing, confirms the diagnosis of CHARGE syndrome, which is a genetic disorder that affects multiple organ systems. Treatment for this condition is often focused on addressing the specific symptoms and complications that arise, such as feeding difficulties, respiratory infections, and hearing loss. Early intervention services are critical to support the child's development and improve outcomes.
column10: A 34-year-old female presents to the clinic with a history of CHARGE syndrome. She reports a lifelong history of multiple congenital anomalies, including coloboma, heart defects, atresia choanae, growth retardation, genital abnormalities, and ear abnormalities. She has a history of recurrent respiratory infections and has undergone multiple surgeries, including a tracheostomy and gastrostomy tube placement. On physical examination, the patient has facial asymmetry and a small jaw (micrognathia). She has a high-arched palate, a nasal voice, and a left-sided hearing loss. Her heart sounds are normal, but she has a history of a ventricular septal defect that was surgically repaired in childhood. She has hypotonia and difficulty with fine motor skills. Due to her complex medical history and ongoing respiratory issues, the patient requires frequent monitoring and management by a multidisciplinary team, including otolaryngology, pulmonology, cardiology, and genetics. She also benefits from ongoing physical and occupational therapy to improve her motor skills and overall quality of life.

column3: A 5-year-old boy with Osteogenesis imperfecta, also known as brittle bone disease, presents to the emergency department with a right thigh fracture after a minor fall while playing. The child has a history of multiple fractures, including a left arm fracture at age 3 and a right leg fracture at age 4, both of which occurred after minimal trauma. His parents report that he has been experiencing frequent bone fractures since infancy. On physical examination, the child has blue sclerae, a triangular face, and a short stature. He is noted to have joint hypermobility, and his skin is thin and fragile. Radiographic imaging confirms the right thigh fracture and shows multiple old fractures in various stages of healing. These findings are consistent with the diagnosis of Osteogenesis imperfecta, a genetic disorder characterized by decreased bone density and increased susceptibility to fractures. The child is admitted for pain management and orthopedic intervention, and a referral is made to a genetic counselor for further evaluation and family counseling.
column10: A 32-year-old male presents to his primary care physician with complaints of recurrent fractures and bone pain. The patient reports a history of multiple fractures since childhood, including a fracture of his left femur at the age of 6 and a fracture of his right tibia at the age of 14. He also reports experiencing frequent bone pain, especially in his back and legs. On physical examination, the patient has a short stature, blue sclera, and a triangular face. His teeth appear translucent and he has a mild scoliosis. There is tenderness on palpation of his spine and long bones.Based on these clinical features, the patient is diagnosed with osteogenesis imperfecta (OI), a genetic disorder that affects the production of collagen, which is a key component of bone and other connective tissues. OI is characterized by fragile bones that are prone to fracture, as well as other features such as short stature, blue sclera, and dental abnormalities. The patient is referred to a specialist for further evaluation and management, including regular monitoring of bone density and the use of bisphosphonates to strengthen his bones. He is also advised to avoid high-impact activities and to take precautions to prevent falls and other injuries.

column3: A 6-month-old male infant is brought in by his parents with complaints of lethargy, poor feeding, and dehydration. The child was born full-term with no complications during delivery. The parents report that the infant has been experiencing these symptoms for the past two weeks, and despite increased feeding, he has not been gaining weight. On physical examination, the infant appears weak, with a weight of 4.5 kg (below the 5th percentile for his age), and a height of 58 cm (below the 10th percentile for his age). The infant has hyperpigmentation of the skin, particularly in the genital area and axillae. Laboratory investigations reveal hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and elevated ACTH levels. A diagnosis of X-linked adrenal hypoplasia congenita is suspected, and genetic testing confirms the diagnosis. The infant is started on hormone replacement therapy with glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids, which results in a significant improvement in his symptoms and growth.
column10: A 32-year-old male presents to his primary care physician complaining of fatigue, weakness, and weight loss. Upon further questioning, the patient reports experiencing frequent episodes of nausea and vomiting, and has noticed increased pigmentation on his skin, especially on his knuckles, elbows, and knees. Further investigation reveals that the patient has a history of recurrent infections, including sinusitis, bronchitis, and pneumonia. His medical history is significant for delayed puberty and short stature. Physical exam shows a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg, with no postural drop. The patient has hyperpigmentation on his knuckles, elbows, and knees, with scattered hyperpigmented macules on his trunk and extremities. He has a lean body habitus, with muscle wasting in his limbs. Laboratory work-up reveals low serum cortisol and aldosterone levels, with elevated levels of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH). A subsequent genetic test confirms the diagnosis of X-linked adrenal hypoplasia congenita (AHC). The most important clinical features of X-linked AHC include adrenal insufficiency, which presents as fatigue, weakness, weight loss, and hyperpigmentation. Patients with X-linked AHC may also have delayed puberty, short stature, and recurrent infections due to impaired immune function. Diagnosis is confirmed with genetic testing. Treatment involves lifelong hormone replacement therapy with glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids.

column3: A 5-year-old boy was brought to the emergency department by his parents with a 2-day history of vomiting and lethargy. On examination, the child appeared pale and dehydrated. Blood tests showed a metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap, elevated liver enzymes, and hypoglycemia. Further investigations revealed a deficiency of long chain 3-hydroxyacyl-CoA dehydrogenase (LCHAD), a rare autosomal recessive disorder that impairs the beta-oxidation of long-chain fatty acids. This leads to the accumulation of toxic metabolites, causing multi-organ dysfunction, particularly affecting the liver, heart, and skeletal muscles. The child was started on intravenous fluids, glucose, and carnitine supplementation. He was also given a low-fat, high-carbohydrate diet to prevent the accumulation of long-chain fatty acids. After a few days of treatment, the child's metabolic acidosis and liver enzymes normalized, and he was discharged home with close follow-up. Long-term management of LCHAD deficiency involves strict adherence to a low-fat, high-carbohydrate diet, regular monitoring of blood glucose and fatty acid levels, and close surveillance for potential complications such as cardiomyopathy and liver failure. Early diagnosis and prompt treatment are crucial in preventing life-threatening metabolic crises and improving the long-term outcome of affected individuals.
column10: A 32-year-old male presented to the emergency room with complaints of severe muscle pain, weakness, and dark urine. The patient reported a history of exercise intolerance and fatigue that worsened over the past few months. He also reported a recent upper respiratory infection that seemed to trigger his symptoms. On examination, the patient was found to have muscle tenderness and weakness, with an elevated creatine kinase level. Further laboratory tests revealed an elevated ammonia level and metabolic acidosis. Based on the clinical features, the patient was diagnosed with Long chain 3-hydroxyacyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency, a rare autosomal recessive disorder that affects the metabolism of fatty acids. This disorder results in the accumulation of toxic metabolites that lead to muscle breakdown and damage, causing rhabdomyolysis. The symptoms of this disorder are often triggered by exercise or illness and can include muscle pain, weakness, myoglobinuria, and elevated creatine kinase levels. If left untreated, Long chain 3-hydroxyacyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency can lead to liver failure, cardiomyopathy, and even sudden death. The patient was started on aggressive intravenous fluid therapy to prevent kidney damage from myoglobinuria and was given intravenous glucose to prevent further muscle breakdown. He was also referred to a metabolic specialist for further management of his rare disorder.

column3: A 3-year-old boy was brought to the pediatrician by his parents for evaluation of developmental delay and behavioral problems. The child was noted to have significant delays in his motor and language development, and also exhibited hyperactivity, poor attention span, and frequent laughing and smiling. On physical exam, he had a small head circumference and prominent forehead, as well as a wide mouth with protruding tongue and a tendency to drool. Genetic testing revealed a deletion in the maternally inherited chromosome 15q11.2-13 region, confirming a diagnosis of Angelman syndrome.
column10: An adult with Angelman syndrome presented to the clinic with a history of developmental delay since childhood. The patient had a characteristic happy demeanor, with frequent bouts of laughter and smiling. On examination, the patient had microcephaly, a wide mouth with a protruding tongue, and a prominent chin. The patient had ataxic gait and hand flapping movements. The patient also had a history of sleep disturbances, with frequent awakenings during the night and difficulty falling asleep.

column2: Change in presentation related to age
column3: A 4-year-old male child was brought in by his parents to the pediatrician's office for evaluation of developmental delay. The child's parents reported that he had been slow to meet developmental milestones, including walking and talking. On examination, the child was noted to have a large head circumference, prominent forehead, and a long narrow face. He also had widely spaced teeth, and his hands and feet were larger than average. Based on these findings, the child was diagnosed with Sotos syndrome. Sotos syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by excessive growth during the first few years of life. Other clinical features can include a distinctive facial appearance, developmental delay, and behavioral problems such as anxiety and hyperactivity. The pediatrician referred the child to a geneticist for further evaluation and management. Genetic testing confirmed the diagnosis of Sotos syndrome, and the child was referred to a multidisciplinary team including a developmental pediatrician, physical therapist, and speech therapist. The team worked together to develop an individualized treatment plan to address the child's developmental delays and behavioral issues.
column10: Mrs. Smith is a 35-year-old woman who was recently diagnosed with Sotos syndrome. She presented to her primary care physician with complaints of frequent headaches, difficulty sleeping, and joint pain. Upon further evaluation, she was found to have a significantly increased head circumference and an elongated face with a prominent forehead. She also had large hands and feet, and a history of delayed motor development as a child. Additionally, Mrs. Smith was found to have mild intellectual disability and speech delay. Her bone age was advanced compared to her chronological age, and she had scoliosis and joint hypermobility. Further testing revealed a deletion of the NSD1 gene, confirming the diagnosis of Sotos syndrome. Mrs. Smith's care team recommended regular follow-up with a neurologist, as well as a genetic counselor to discuss the risk of passing on the syndrome to future children. They also recommended physical therapy to address her joint pain and scoliosis, and speech therapy to address her delayed speech. Overall, Mrs. Smith's diagnosis of Sotos syndrome highlights the importance of recognizing the characteristic clinical features and providing appropriate multidisciplinary care.

column3: A 10-year-old boy presents with hearing loss and goiter. His parents report that he has had difficulty hearing since he was a toddler, and he has been wearing hearing aids since age 4. The goiter was noticed by his pediatrician during a routine check-up and was found to be non-tender and firm upon examination. The boy's thyroid hormone levels are within normal limits, but a hearing test shows a moderate to severe bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. Based on these findings, the boy is diagnosed with Pendred syndrome, a genetic disorder characterized by the combination of congenital hearing loss and goiter. Pendred syndrome is caused by mutations in the SLC26A4 gene, which encodes for a protein involved in the transport of iodide in the thyroid gland.
column10: Mrs. Smith, a 35-year-old female, presented to her primary care physician with complaints of hearing loss and goiter. She reported a gradual onset of hearing loss that began in her teenage years and had progressed to the point where she was now having difficulty hearing conversations. She also noted that her neck had become visibly enlarged over the past few years. On physical examination, Mrs. Smith had a goiter that was smooth, firm, and diffusely enlarged. She had bilateral sensorineural hearing loss, which was confirmed by audiometry. A thyroid function test revealed mild hypothyroidism, but her TSH levels were elevated. Further evaluation revealed that Mrs. Smith had Pendred syndrome, an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by the presence of a goiter and sensorineural hearing loss. Pendred syndrome is caused by mutations in the SLC26A4 gene, which encodes for a protein that is involved in the transport of iodide in the thyroid gland and inner ear.

column3: A 4-year-old girl was brought into the emergency room by her parents due to difficulty breathing and a persistent cough. Upon examination, the child was found to have dysmorphic features such as a small head circumference, wide-spaced eyes, and a flat nasal bridge. She also had a cleft palate and an extra digit on both hands and feet. Imaging studies revealed a diaphragmatic hernia and lung hypoplasia, which explained her respiratory distress. The child was diagnosed with Fryns syndrome, a rare genetic disorder that affects multiple systems in the body. Treatment was initiated to manage her respiratory symptoms, and the child was referred to a geneticist for further evaluation and management.
column10: A 35-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with shortness of breath and recurrent respiratory infections. On examination, the patient is found to have dysmorphic facial features, including a small head circumference, low-set ears, and a small jaw. He also has a cleft palate, a short neck, and webbed fingers and toes. The patient has a history of congenital diaphragmatic hernia repair in infancy and has undergone multiple surgeries for his airway obstruction. Lung function tests reveal decreased lung capacity, and a chest x-ray shows bilateral lung hypoplasia.

column3: A 6-year-old boy was brought to the pediatrician's office for evaluation of recurrent fevers and dry, scaly skin. On examination, the child was noted to have sparse, brittle hair, absent eyebrows and eyelashes, and a thin, dry skin with reduced sweating. He had a prominent forehead and a flattened nasal bridge. The teeth were also affected, with missing teeth and misshapen enamel. The child was diagnosed with hypohidrotic ectodermal dysplasia, a rare genetic disorder that affects the development of ectodermal tissues such as the skin, hair, nails, teeth, and sweat glands. The reduced sweating predisposed him to recurrent fevers and overheating. The child was referred to a geneticist for further evaluation and management.
column10: A 35-year-old male patient presented to the clinic with complaints of excessive heat intolerance and dry skin. He reported a history of recurrent fevers and difficulty sweating since childhood. On physical examination, the patient had sparse, fine hair over his scalp and eyebrows, and his skin appeared rough, dry, and scaly. He had few sweat glands, and his teeth were misshapen and prone to decay. The patient was diagnosed with Hypohidrotic ectodermal dysplasia, a rare genetic disorder that affects the development of the skin, hair, teeth, and sweat glands. The condition is characterized by a triad of symptoms - hypohidrosis, hypotrichosis, and hypodontia. Patients with this condition are unable to sweat properly, leading to heat intolerance, and are at increased risk of developing overheating and heat exhaustion. Additionally, they may have thin, sparse hair, and abnormal tooth development. Treatment is supportive and may include measures to prevent overheating, regular dental check-ups, and cosmetic interventions to improve hair growth.

column2: Change in presentation related to age
column3: A 7-year-old boy presents to his pediatrician with complaints of recurrent episodes of burning pain in his hands and feet. The pain is often accompanied by a rash and swelling. The boy's mother also reports that he has experienced gastrointestinal issues, including diarrhea and abdominal pain, for several months. Upon examination, the pediatrician notes that the boy has angiokeratomas on his skin, particularly in the groin area. The boy is referred to a geneticist, who diagnoses him with Fabry disease.
column10: A 38-year-old male presented with a history of recurrent episodes of severe abdominal pain, diarrhea, and peripheral neuropathy. He also reported experiencing frequent episodes of sweating, fatigue, and dizziness. The patient had a family history of renal disease and cardiac issues. On examination, the patient had a rash on his trunk and extremities, and his corneas showed characteristic corneal whorls. Further investigations revealed a low level of alpha-galactosidase A enzyme activity, and genetic testing confirmed a diagnosis of Fabry disease. The patient was started on enzyme replacement therapy to manage his symptoms and prevent disease progression.

column3: A 12-year-old boy was brought to the hospital by his parents due to unexplained behavioral changes, including irritability and mood swings. Upon further examination, the child was found to have tremors and difficulty with coordination. The medical team also observed the presence of Kayser-Fleischer rings in his eyes. After conducting a series of tests, the doctors diagnosed the child with Wilson disease, a rare genetic disorder that affects the body's ability to metabolize copper. The accumulation of copper in the liver, brain, and other organs can lead to a wide range of symptoms, including tremors, difficulty with movement, and cognitive impairment. The medical team immediately started the child on a treatment plan that included medications to chelate and remove excess copper from the body. They also recommended a low-copper diet and regular monitoring of liver function and neurological symptoms. With appropriate treatment and management, the child's symptoms improved, and he was able to resume normal activities.
column10: Patient X, a 35-year-old male, presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue, abdominal pain, and jaundice for the past several weeks. On physical examination, he has hepatomegaly and is noted to have a tremor of his hands. His speech is slurred, and he has difficulty with coordination. His liver function tests are elevated, and his serum ceruloplasmin level is low.Based on these findings, a diagnosis of Wilson disease is suspected. Wilson disease is an autosomal recessive disorder that causes copper to accumulate in the liver, brain, and other organs. The most common clinical features of Wilson disease include hepatic dysfunction, neurologic symptoms, and psychiatric disturbances. Hepatic symptoms include fatigue, abdominal pain, and jaundice. Neurologic symptoms include tremors, difficulty with coordination, and slurred speech. Psychiatric disturbances can include depression, anxiety, and personality changes.

column3: A 4-year-old boy was brought to the pediatrician's office by his parents due to a noticeable white reflex in his right eye. On examination, the pediatrician observed a white pupillary reflex in the right eye and referred the child to an ophthalmologist. The ophthalmologist performed a dilated fundus examination and found a large white mass in the right eye, occupying approximately 80% of the globe. The diagnosis of retinoblastoma was made, and further imaging studies were obtained.
column10: Retinoblastoma is a rare type of cancer that affects the retina of the eye. It most commonly affects children but can also occur in adults. One clinical feature of retinoblastoma is the presence of a white or yellowish spot in the pupil of the eye, which can be seen in flash photography. In adults, the tumor may be larger and more advanced at the time of diagnosis, leading to symptoms such as vision loss, eye pain, and redness.One example of an adult with retinoblastoma is a 40-year-old female who presented with a several-month history of blurry vision and occasional eye pain in her left eye. On examination, her visual acuity was decreased in the left eye, and there was a visible mass in the retina. Further testing, including MRI and biopsy, confirmed the diagnosis of retinoblastoma. Treatment options included surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy, depending on the extent of the tumor and the patient's overall health. Close follow-up was necessary to monitor for recurrence and potential spread to other parts of the body.

column3: A 7-year-old boy was brought into the clinic by his parents due to difficulty walking and frequent falls. Upon examination, the child displayed significant muscle weakness in his lower limbs, particularly in the muscles surrounding the tibia bone. He had a waddling gait and could not stand on his toes. The child also had a positive Gower's sign, where he had to use his arms to push himself up from the floor when attempting to stand. Further tests revealed elevated levels of creatine kinase, a marker for muscle damage. These clinical features indicated that the child likely had Tibial muscular dystrophy, a rare form of muscular dystrophy that primarily affects the muscles in the lower legs. The child was referred to a specialist for further evaluation and management of his condition.
column10: A 45-year-old male patient presents with a history of progressive muscle weakness and difficulty in walking since childhood. He reports that he has trouble climbing stairs and getting up from a seated position. On examination, he is found to have muscle wasting in the lower limbs, particularly in the calf muscles. He has difficulty in dorsiflexing his feet and has a waddling gait. The patient also has scoliosis and a high-arched foot. His reflexes are reduced, and there is evidence of sensory loss. The patient reports a family history of similar symptoms, and genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Tibial Muscular Dystrophy. The most important clinical features of this condition are progressive muscle weakness and wasting in the lower limbs, particularly in the calf muscles, which can lead to difficulty in walking and standing. Other common features include foot deformities, scoliosis, and reduced reflexes. Genetic testing is necessary for confirmation of the diagnosis.

column3: A 7-year-old girl named Emily presents to her pediatrician for a routine check-up. Upon physical examination, the pediatrician notes that Emily has a short stature, a webbed neck, and a low hairline. The pediatrician also observes that Emily has a slight swelling of her hands and feet. Emily's parents report that she has difficulties with spatial reasoning and math, and that she seems to struggle with social interactions. Given these clinical features, the pediatrician suspects that Emily may have Turner syndrome, a genetic disorder that affects females. Turner syndrome is caused by the absence of all or part of one X chromosome. The most common clinical features of Turner syndrome include short stature, webbed neck, low hairline, and swelling of the hands and feet.
column10: A 28-year-old female presents to the clinic with a history of delayed puberty, short stature, and difficulty conceiving. Physical examination reveals a webbed neck, low hairline, widely spaced nipples, and small breasts. She has a high-pitched voice and a broad chest with widely spaced nipples. Her arms are slightly bowed, and she has a short stature with a height of 4 feet and 10 inches. The patient is diagnosed with Turner Syndrome, a genetic disorder affecting females where one of the X chromosomes is missing or partially missing. This condition is associated with a variety of clinical features, including short stature, delayed puberty, infertility, and certain physical features like a webbed neck, low hairline, and widely spaced nipples. The patient is referred to an endocrinologist for further evaluation and management of her condition.

column3: A 5-year-old boy with Smith-Magenis syndrome (SMS) was brought to the pediatrician's office by his parents due to behavioral issues and developmental delays. The child was noted to have a short stature, low muscle tone, and distinctive facial features including a broad forehead, deep-set eyes, and a prominent midface. The parents reported that their son had difficulties sleeping at night, often waking up multiple times and exhibiting self-injurious behaviors such as head banging and biting. The child also had a history of recurrent ear infections and gastrointestinal issues such as chronic constipation. On further evaluation, the child was found to have mild intellectual disability and speech delays, with limited vocabulary and difficulty expressing himself. He also had a tendency towards repetitive behaviors such as hand flapping and rocking.
column10: A 35-year-old male with Smith-Magenis syndrome presents to the clinic with complaints of chronic sleep disturbances and behavioral problems. He reports difficulty falling and staying asleep, and often wakes up feeling tired and irritable. Additionally, he has a history of self-injurious behavior, aggression, and impulsivity. On physical exam, the patient has a distinctive facial appearance, including a broad forehead, deep-set eyes, and a flat midface. He also has a short stature and mild to moderate intellectual disability. Further evaluation reveals a deletion in chromosome 17p11.2, which is characteristic of Smith-Magenis syndrome. The patient is referred to a sleep specialist and behavioral therapist for management of his symptoms, including the use of melatonin for sleep disturbances and behavioral therapies to address self-injurious behavior and aggression.
