ALS is a progressive neurodegenerative disease that typically affects adults, and its onset is rare in individuals younger than 20 years of age. If you have any other medical topic you would like me to assist you with, please let me know. 2. Juvenile ALS: A 10-year-old male child presents with progressive muscle weakness and difficulty with movements. The child's parents report that he has been experiencing muscle cramps and difficulty with daily activities like standing up from a chair or climbing stairs. The child's medical history is unremarkable, and there is no family history of neurological disorders. Upon physical examination, muscle wasting and fasciculations are noted. The child also exhibits spasticity in the lower limbs, with brisk reflexes and a positive Babinski sign. An electromyography (EMG) confirms the diagnosis of juvenile amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). The child is referred to a neurologist for further management and support.
column10: Mr. Smith is a 56-year-old male who presented with a six-month history of progressive weakness in his arms and legs. He has difficulty with fine motor tasks such as buttoning his shirt and frequently drops items. He has also experienced difficulty with speaking and swallowing. On examination, Mr. Smith has significant atrophy in his upper and lower extremities with fasciculations noted throughout his muscles. His reflexes are hyperactive and he has a positive Babinski sign. He has difficulty with tongue movements and his speech is slurred.Based on his clinical presentation, Mr. Smith was diagnosed with Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), a progressive neurodegenerative disease that affects the motor neurons in the brain and spinal cord. This diagnosis was confirmed with electromyography (EMG) and nerve conduction studies which revealed widespread denervation and axonal loss. ALS is a devastating disease with no known cure. Treatment is primarily supportive and focused on maintaining quality of life. Mr. Smith will require a multidisciplinary approach to care involving physical therapy, occupational therapy, speech therapy, and palliative care.

column3: A six-year-old child named Emily was brought to the pediatrician due to developmental delays and behavioral problems. Her parents noticed that she had difficulty communicating and interacting with others, and she often exhibited hyperactivity and aggressiveness. On physical examination, Emily had coarse facial features, a prominent forehead, and thick lips. She also had an enlarged liver and spleen. Further evaluation revealed that Emily had Sanfilippo syndrome type C, a rare genetic disorder caused by a deficiency in an enzyme called heparan N-sulfatase. This deficiency leads to the accumulation of heparan sulfate in the brain and other organs, causing progressive neurological deterioration.
column10: A 35-year-old male patient presented to his primary care physician with complaints of developmental delay, behavioral problems, and difficulty with coordination. The patient had a history of intellectual disability and had never achieved developmental milestones. He had also experienced frequent ear infections and recurrent upper respiratory tract infections since childhood. On physical examination, the patient had coarse facial features, a large head, and thickened lips. The patient also had joint stiffness and limited range of motion, especially in his shoulders and hips. Neurological examination revealed ataxia, tremors, and mild spasticity in his lower extremities. Further testing revealed elevated levels of heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate in the patient's urine, confirming the diagnosis of Sanfilippo syndrome type C. Genetic testing was also performed, which revealed a mutation in the gene responsible for heparan N-sulfatase deficiency. The patient was referred to a specialist for management of his symptoms, including physical and occupational therapy, as well as medications to control his tremors and spasticity. The patient's family was also provided with genetic counseling and advised to undergo carrier testing to determine their risk of passing on the condition to future generations.

column3: A 7-year-old male child was brought to the ophthalmology clinic by his parents with complaints of decreased vision and difficulty reading. On examination, the child was found to have bilateral foveal schisis, which is characteristic of X-linked retinoschisis. The schisis was more prominent in the macula and was associated with a decrease in visual acuity. The child had a family history of X-linked retinoschisis, which further confirmed the diagnosis. The child was started on regular follow-up visits and was advised to avoid activities that could cause eye trauma. The ophthalmologist also discussed the possibility of genetic testing and counseling with the parents.
column10: A 35-year-old male patient presents with complaints of progressive loss of vision in both eyes. On examination, his visual acuity was found to be reduced to 20/200 in the right eye and 20/400 in the left eye. Fundus examination revealed macular schisis in both eyes, along with peripheral retinoschisis. The clinical features were suggestive of X-linked retinoschisis, which was confirmed by genetic testing. The patient reported a family history of similar symptoms in his brother, maternal uncle, and grandfather. The management plan included regular follow-up visits, genetic counseling, and low vision aids. The patient was also advised to avoid high-impact sports and activities to prevent further damage to the retina.

column1: Hemolytic anemia due to red cell pyruvate kinase deficiency
column3: A 7-year-old boy presents to the emergency room with fatigue, shortness of breath, and yellowing of his skin and eyes. He has a past medical history of recurrent infections and anemia. On physical examination, his spleen is enlarged and his liver is palpable. Laboratory tests reveal a low hemoglobin level, elevated bilirubin, and decreased haptoglobin. A peripheral blood smear shows evidence of hemolysis, including schistocytes and spherocytes. Further testing reveals that the patient has red cell pyruvate kinase deficiency, a rare genetic disorder that causes hemolytic anemia. The patient is started on supportive therapy, including blood transfusions and folic acid supplementation, and referred to a hematologist for further management. The most important clinical features in this case include anemia, jaundice, splenomegaly, and evidence of hemolysis on peripheral blood smear. Early recognition and treatment are essential for managing this life-threatening condition.
column10: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department complaining of shortness of breath, fatigue and dark urine for the past two days. He reports a history of recurrent episodes of anemia since childhood but had never been diagnosed with a specific condition. On examination, he is pale with jaundice and tachycardia. Laboratory tests reveal a hemoglobin level of 6.8 g/dL, a reticulocyte count of 12.5%, and elevated bilirubin and lactate dehydrogenase levels. A peripheral blood smear shows numerous fragmented red cells and spherocytes. Further testing reveals a diagnosis of hemolytic anemia due to red cell pyruvate kinase deficiency. The patient is started on blood transfusions and referred to a hematologist for further management.

column3: A 6-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a history of recurrent fractures and frequent infections. The child's parents report that he has a history of multiple fractures that occurred with minimal trauma, and they have also noticed that he has difficulty seeing at night. On physical examination, the child's height and weight are within the normal range, but his skull appears to be abnormally large. Additionally, he has a prominent forehead, a flattened nasal bridge, and a wide mandible. The child's laboratory test results reveal anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated levels of serum alkaline phosphatase. Based on these findings, the child is diagnosed with Albers-Schönberg osteopetrosis, a rare genetic disorder that affects bone density and bone growth. This disorder is characterized by abnormal bone growth and thickening, which can lead to recurrent fractures, vision problems, and infections. The child is referred to a specialist for further evaluation and management of his condition.
column10: Mr. X is a 36-year-old male who presented to the hospital with a history of chronic pain in his lower back and legs. He reported experiencing frequent fractures of his upper and lower limbs, even after minimal trauma. Mr. X also complained of vision problems, including decreased visual acuity and double vision. On physical examination, Mr. X had short stature, a broad forehead, and a prominent jaw. His teeth appeared crowded, and his gums were swollen and tender. He had a limited range of motion in his hips, knees, and ankles, and his gait was unsteady. Blood tests showed elevated levels of alkaline phosphatase and calcium. X-rays revealed diffuse bone sclerosis, with thickening and narrowing of bone trabeculae. A bone biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of Albers-Schönberg osteopetrosis.

column3: A 3-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with vomiting and lethargy. His parents report that he has had a history of recurrent episodes of vomiting and abdominal pain after consuming fruits, juices, and sweets. On examination, the child is dehydrated and has a distended abdomen. Laboratory investigations reveal hypoglycemia, elevated liver enzymes, and metabolic acidosis. The child is diagnosed with Hereditary fructose intolerance, a rare autosomal recessive disorder that results in the inability to metabolize fructose. The child is started on intravenous fluids and glucose, and a fructose-free diet is recommended. The parents are counseled on the importance of avoiding fructose-containing foods, and the child is referred to a metabolic specialist for further management.
column10: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain and vomiting. He reports a history of recurrent abdominal pain and diarrhea after consuming foods containing high-fructose corn syrup. Physical examination reveals a distended abdomen with tenderness to palpation in the right upper quadrant. Laboratory results show elevated liver enzymes and hypoglycemia. The patient is diagnosed with Hereditary fructose intolerance (HFI) and is advised to avoid foods containing fructose and sucrose. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of HFI. The patient is started on a fructose-free diet and his symptoms improve within a few days. A follow-up appointment with a genetic counselor is recommended to discuss the risk of passing on the genetic mutation to his children.

column3: Sarah is a 6-year-old girl who is brought to the clinic by her parents for evaluation of joint pain and hypermobility. On examination, she has soft, velvety skin with easy bruising and scars on her knees. Her joints are hypermobile, and she demonstrates the ability to touch her thumb to her wrist and bend her fingers backward. She also has mitral valve prolapse and a history of gastrointestinal issues. Based on these clinical features, Sarah is diagnosed with Classical Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, a genetic disorder that affects collagen synthesis. Her management will include physical therapy to improve joint stability and monitoring for potential cardiovascular and gastrointestinal complications.
column10: A 32-year-old woman presented to her primary care physician with a history of joint hypermobility, skin hyperextensibility, and chronic joint pain. She reported a long-standing history of easy bruising and poor wound healing. Her medical history was significant for recurrent joint dislocations and subluxations, as well as frequent gastrointestinal complaints. Physical examination revealed skin that was thin, velvety, and easily stretched, with multiple atrophic scars and bruises. Her joints demonstrated hypermobility with a Beighton score of 8/9. Further evaluation revealed a family history of similar symptoms, and genetic testing confirmed a diagnosis of Classical Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. She was referred to a specialist for ongoing management of her joint and connective tissue symptoms.

column3: A 6-year-old child presents with a chronic cough and recurrent respiratory infections since infancy. The child also has a history of chronic ear infections and has required multiple sets of ear tubes. Physical examination reveals digital clubbing and nasal polyps. Chest X-ray shows bronchiectasis. A sweat chloride test is normal ruling out cystic fibrosis. A nasal biopsy confirms the diagnosis of primary ciliary dyskinesia.
column10: A 30-year-old man presents to the clinic with a history of chronic cough and recurrent respiratory tract infections since childhood. He reports daily production of yellow-green sputum and occasional hemoptysis. He also complains of chronic sinusitis, nasal congestion, and difficulty breathing. He has a history of infertility and situs inversus totalis. On examination, he has digital clubbing and bilateral crepitations on chest auscultation. A high-resolution CT scan of the chest shows bronchiectasis and mucous plugging. A diagnosis of primary ciliary dyskinesia is suspected, which is confirmed by a nasal nitric oxide test and ciliary biopsy.

column3: Meet 5-year-old Max, who presents to the pediatric clinic with his parents. He has a history of achondroplasia, a genetic condition that affects bone growth and leads to short stature. Max's parents report that he is experiencing some difficulty with his mobility, including frequent falls, difficulty climbing stairs, and a waddling gait. On examination, Max's height is below the 3rd percentile for his age, and his limbs are disproportionately short compared to his trunk. He has a large head with a prominent forehead and flattened nasal bridge, which are characteristic of achondroplasia. Max's joints are hypermobile, and he has mild kyphosis and lordosis. The pediatrician notes that Max's neurological exam is normal, and there are no signs of spinal cord compression or hydrocephalus. Based on these findings, the pediatrician recommends close monitoring of Max's growth and development, regular check-ins with a pediatric orthopedist, and physical therapy to help with his mobility challenges.
column10: Mary is a 35-year-old female with a history of Achondroplasia, a genetic disorder that affects the growth of bones, resulting in short stature. She presents with complaints of chronic back pain, which has been worsening over the past few months. On physical examination, Mary has a disproportionately short stature, with short limbs and a large head. She also exhibits kyphosis, a condition characterized by an exaggerated curvature of the spine. X-rays reveal spinal stenosis, a narrowing of the spinal canal that compresses the spinal cord and nerves, leading to back pain and muscle weakness. Mary is referred to a neurosurgeon for further evaluation and management.

column3: A 7-year-old boy presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of decreased vision in both eyes for the past 6 months. On examination, his visual acuity is found to be 20/50 in the right eye and 20/60 in the left eye. He also has central scotomas and color vision defects. Further evaluation reveals a family history of optic atrophy, and genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Leber hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON). The patient is started on high-dose idebenone therapy, and genetic counseling is provided to the family. Follow-up visits are scheduled to monitor the patient's vision and overall visual function
column10: A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with a complaint of sudden painless vision loss in both eyes over the last several weeks. He has a history of hearing loss and his mother and maternal uncle also had similar vision problems. On examination, his visual acuity is severely reduced and he has a central scotoma in both eyes. Fundus examination shows optic disc pallor and telangiectatic vessels. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Leber hereditary optic neuropathy, a rare genetic disorder that causes progressive vision loss due to optic nerve damage. The patient is started on supportive therapy and genetic counseling is recommended for him and his family members.

column3: A 5-year-old child was brought to the clinic by his parents with complaints of a rash on his face and intermittent episodes of confusion. On examination, the child appeared malnourished and had a photosensitive rash on his face. The child's neurological examination was remarkable for intermittent confusion and ataxia. Further investigations revealed that the child had low levels of tryptophan and other neutral amino acids in his blood and urine. The diagnosis of Hartnup disease was suspected, and genetic testing confirmed it. The child was started on a high-protein diet and given nicotinamide supplements, leading to significant improvement in his symptoms.
column10: A 32-year-old male presents to the clinic complaining of skin rash and fatigue. The patient reports experiencing intermittent episodes of diarrhea and vomiting for several months. Upon examination, the patient is noted to have a photosensitive rash on his face and arms. His laboratory findings reveal low levels of tryptophan and niacin. Further investigation reveals that the patient has Hartnup disease, an autosomal recessive disorder that impairs the absorption and metabolism of tryptophan. The patient is started on niacin supplementation and advised to avoid sunlight exposure.

column3: A 1-month-old male infant was brought to the emergency department by his parents due to severe respiratory distress. The baby was born with multiple congenital anomalies, including a large cystic mass on the back of his head, polydactyly, and a small jaw. On physical examination, he was noted to have a high-pitched cry, microcephaly, and a small, poorly developed chest. Further investigations revealed renal anomalies and a dilated loop of bowel suggestive of Meckel syndrome. The child was admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit for respiratory support and management of his congenital anomalies. Despite aggressive treatment, the infant's prognosis was poor due to the severity of his condition.
column10: A 32-year-old female presented with a history of multiple fetal losses and a stillbirth at 24 weeks. On examination, she was found to have a small head circumference, micrognathia, and a cleft palate. An ultrasound revealed bilateral renal cysts and a hypoplastic lungs. Further evaluation showed a polydactyly of both hands and feet. Genetic testing confirmed the diagnosis of Meckel syndrome. The patient was counseled on the poor prognosis and advised against future pregnancies.

column3: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician's office by his parents due to delayed puberty and a lack of sense of smell. The boy's parents report that he has not begun to develop any secondary sexual characteristics, and they have noticed that he does not react to strong odors. Upon examination, the pediatrician notes that the boy's testes are small and there is no sign of pubic hair. The pediatrician also confirms that the boy has no sense of smell. Based on these findings, the pediatrician suspects Kallmann syndrome, a rare genetic disorder that affects the development of the hypothalamus and pituitary gland. Further testing, including hormone levels and genetic testing, is recommended to confirm the diagnosis and develop a treatment plan.
column10: A 30-year-old male presents to the endocrinology clinic with a history of delayed puberty and infertility. On further evaluation, he reports a lack of sense of smell since childhood and difficulty recognizing taste. His physical exam is notable for underdeveloped secondary sexual characteristics, including sparse pubic hair and small testicular size. Hormonal analysis reveals low levels of testosterone, LH, and FSH. MRI of the brain shows a small olfactory bulb and absence of the olfactory sulci, consistent with Kallmann syndrome. Genetic testing confirms a mutation in the KAL1 gene. The patient is started on testosterone replacement therapy and referred for fertility evaluation. He is also advised to undergo genetic counseling due to the inheritable nature of the condition.

column3: A 6-year-old male presents to the clinic with developmental delays, poor growth, and dysmorphic facial features. The child's parents report that he has difficulty feeding and has had recurrent ear infections. On physical examination, the child has microcephaly, a small chin, and a flattened nasal bridge. He also has syndactyly of the second and third toes. The child's laboratory workup shows low cholesterol levels and elevated 7-dehydrocholesterol levels, consistent with Smith-Lemli-Opitz syndrome. The child is referred to a geneticist for further evaluation and management of the disorder.
column10: Ms. Johnson, a 35-year-old woman with a history of developmental delay and intellectual disability, presents with complaints of chronic constipation, difficulty sleeping, and behavioral problems. On examination, she has dysmorphic facial features, including a small head circumference, widely spaced eyes, and a small chin. She also has syndactyly of her second and third toes and a short fourth finger. Laboratory testing reveals low levels of cholesterol and an increased ratio of 7-dehydrocholesterol to cholesterol, consistent with a diagnosis of Smith-Lemli-Opitz syndrome. Further evaluation is recommended to assess for potential complications, such as cataracts, cardiac anomalies, and liver dysfunction.

column3: A 2-month-old male infant is brought to the pediatrician's office by his parents for evaluation of multiple birth defects. The child was diagnosed with Trisomy 13 during prenatal testing. On physical examination, the infant is found to have cleft lip and palate, polydactyly, microcephaly, and coloboma of the iris. Additionally, the child has a heart murmur and hypotonia. The pediatrician suspects the child may also have hearing and vision impairments. The parents express concern about the child's prognosis and quality of life. Further genetic counseling and management are recommended.
column10: A 35-year-old woman with a history of Trisomy 13 presents to the clinic with complaints of difficulty breathing and feeding intolerance. She was born with a cleft lip and palate, and has had multiple surgeries in the past to correct them. On examination, she has a high-arched palate, microphthalmia, and polydactyly. She also has a heart murmur and is mildly hypotonic. Chest x-ray reveals a small heart with pulmonary hypoplasia. An echocardiogram shows a ventricular septal defect and patent ductus arteriosus. The patient is referred to a multidisciplinary team for further evaluation and management.

column3: A newborn baby boy was born at 38 weeks gestation via cesarean section due to poor fetal growth. The baby was noted to have short limbs, a disproportionately large head, and a small chest. He also had a narrow chest and difficulty breathing. Imaging studies revealed severe narrowing of the rib cage and shortening of the long bones. Genetic testing confirmed a diagnosis of Thanatophoric dysplasia, a rare and severe form of skeletal dysplasia. The baby was monitored closely for respiratory distress and received supportive care, but unfortunately, he passed away shortly after birth due to complications related to his condition.
column10: A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a history of multiple skeletal abnormalities and short stature. She reports a family history of similar symptoms, and her parents are first cousins. On physical examination, she is found to have short limbs, a narrow chest, and a prominent forehead. Imaging studies reveal severe skeletal dysplasia and a small chest cavity, which puts her at risk of respiratory distress. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Thanatophoric dysplasia, a rare and lethal genetic disorder that affects bone development. The patient is referred to a genetic counselor and a palliative care specialist for further management.

column3: A 2-month-old male infant was referred to a pediatric geneticist for evaluation of macrosomia, macroglossia, and omphalocele. The patient's birth weight was 4.5 kg and his length was 57 cm. Physical examination revealed an enlarged tongue, a large omphalocele, and earlobe creases. The patient had no other significant medical history. A diagnosis of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome was made based on the patient's clinical presentation and genetic testing confirmed a paternal uniparental disomy of chromosome 11. The patient was closely monitored for the development of Wilms tumor, a common complication of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.
column10: A 32-year-old male presents to the clinic with a history of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome. He reports being diagnosed with this genetic disorder shortly after birth and has since undergone multiple surgeries to treat the associated complications. On physical examination, he is noted to have a large head circumference, macroglossia, and abdominal distension. Further evaluation reveals an enlarged liver and kidneys, as well as a history of hypoglycemia in infancy. The patient is currently being monitored for the development of Wilms tumor, a common complication of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.

column3: A5-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a history of rough, itchy, and scaly patches on her skin. Her parents report that the patches started appearing on her scalp and face, and have now spread to her trunk and extremities. On examination, the patient has multiple hyperkeratotic papules and plaques on her forehead, scalp, and cheeks. The skin lesions are greasy and have a distinct odor. The nails are also affected, with longitudinal ridges and V-shaped notches. A diagnosis of Darier disease is suspected based on the characteristic clinical features, and a skin biopsy is performed to confirm the diagnosis. The patient is started on topical and systemic therapies to manage her symptoms and prevent complications.
column10: A 42-year-old male presents to the dermatologist with a long-standing history of persistent, itchy, and painful skin lesions. The patient reports that the lesions first appeared in his teenage years and have been progressively worsening over time. Upon physical examination, there were numerous hyperkeratotic, crusted papules and plaques on his scalp, face, chest, and back. The nails were also affected, with V-shaped notches and longitudinal ridges. The patient reported a family history of similar skin lesions. A skin biopsy was performed, which revealed characteristic suprabasal clefting and acantholysis, confirming the diagnosis of Darier disease. The patient was advised to avoid sun exposure and given topical and systemic treatments to control his symptoms.

column3: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents due to concerns about his head shape. The child was born with a slightly misshapen head, but over time it has become more pronounced. On physical examination, the pediatrician notes that the child has a prominent forehead, a flattened back of the head, and a ridge along the top of the skull. The child also has mild hearing loss and has been diagnosed with a heart murmur. After conducting genetic testing, the child is diagnosed with Muenke syndrome, a genetic disorder that affects the growth and development of the skull. The pediatrician explains to the parents that the child may need surgery to correct the shape of his head, and that he will need to be closely monitored for any other health issues related to the syndrome. The pediatrician also recommends that the child undergo regular hearing tests and cardiac evaluations to ensure that any potential complications are caught early and treated appropriately.
column10: John is a 32-year-old male who presents to his primary care physician with complaints of headaches and sleep disturbances. John reports that he has always had an unusually shaped head and has difficulty finding hats that fit properly. On physical examination, the physician notes that John's head is brachycephalic with a prominent forehead and flattened occiput. Additionally, John has a midline ridge along the top of his skull. Further evaluation reveals that John has Muenke syndrome, a genetic disorder characterized by the premature fusion of the cranial sutures. This results in the unique head shape seen in John as well as potential complications such as increased intracranial pressure, developmental delays, and hearing loss. John is referred to a specialist for further management and monitoring of his condition.

column3: A 6-year-old male child is brought to the clinic by his parents, who are concerned about their son's short stature and difficulty walking. The child was born at term with no complications, but his growth has been significantly delayed since early childhood. On physical examination, the child's height is below the 3rd percentile, and his arm span is greater than his height. The child has a characteristic waddling gait and bowed legs. Joint hypermobility is also noted, particularly in the knees and elbows. X-rays of the child's long bones reveal irregularities in the growth plates, consistent with pseudoachondroplasia. Further genetic testing confirms the diagnosis. The child is referred to a pediatric orthopedist for management of his joint problems and monitoring of his growth.
column10: A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of joint pain and stiffness. He reports a history of short stature and disproportionate limb length. He has difficulty with physical activities and experiences frequent joint dislocations. On physical examination, his height is 4 feet 2 inches and he has a shortened upper and lower extremity. He has joint laxity and tenderness on palpation. X-rays show joint space narrowing and irregularities in the epiphyses. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Pseudoachondroplasia.

column3: A 10-year-old boy presents to the pediatric endocrine clinic with a family history of multiple endocrine tumors. The child's father and grandmother both have a history of pituitary tumors, parathyroid adenomas, and pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors. On physical examination, the child is found to have a small subcutaneous lipoma on his arm and an elevated calcium level on bloodwork. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1). The child is referred to an endocrine surgeon for management of his parathyroid and pancreatic tumors and will require lifelong monitoring for the development of additional tumors
column10: A 45-year-old male patient presents to the endocrinologist with a history of recurrent kidney stones, hypercalcemia, and peptic ulcer disease. He also reports a family history of pituitary tumors and pancreatic cancer. Physical examination reveals multiple facial angiofibromas, lipomas, and café-au-lait spots. Lab workup shows elevated levels of parathyroid hormone, gastrin, and insulin-like growth factor 1. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1). The patient is referred for further evaluation and management of his endocrine tumors, including regular monitoring for the development of additional neoplasms.

column3: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room with a history of recurrent seizures and fever. His parents report that he has a history of developmental delay, episodes of prolonged febrile seizures, and atypical absences. On examination, the child is febrile, with a temperature of 38.5°C, and has generalized hypotonia. His electroencephalogram (EEG) shows generalized spike-and-wave discharges, and an MRI scan of his brain is unremarkable. Based on the clinical presentation and EEG findings, the child is diagnosed with Dravet syndrome, a rare and severe form of epilepsy that typically starts in infancy or early childhood. Dravet syndrome is characterized by prolonged seizures, developmental delay, and cognitive impairment, and is often refractory to treatment with antiepileptic drugs. The child is started on a combination of antiepileptic medications, and his parents are counseled on the need for close monitoring and management of his seizures.
column10: A 26-year-old male presents with a history of seizures since childhood. The seizures are typically triggered by fever, stress, or excitement, and are characterized by sudden loss of consciousness, convulsions, and post-ictal confusion. The patient has been diagnosed with Dravet syndrome, a rare genetic disorder that causes severe epilepsy and developmental delay. On examination, the patient has poor coordination, ataxia, and cognitive impairment. He is also at increased risk for sudden unexpected death in epilepsy (SUDEP) and requires close monitoring and antiepileptic medication management.

column3: A 5-year-old male child presents to the emergency department with lethargy, weakness, and vomiting. On examination, the child is found to be hypotonic with muscle weakness and has an enlarged liver. The child's blood work shows hypoglycemia and elevated creatine kinase levels. The child's medical history is significant for recurrent episodes of hypoglycemia, lethargy, and weakness. The child is diagnosed with Systemic primary carnitine deficiency, a rare genetic disorder that affects the transport of fatty acids into the mitochondria, leading to impaired energy production. Treatment with L-carnitine is initiated, and the child's symptoms improve significantly. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis, and the child is referred to a metabolic specialist for long-term management.
column10: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe muscle weakness and fatigue for the past several weeks. He reports difficulty walking and has experienced several falls. He also describes episodes of hypoglycemia and nausea. On physical examination, he appears malnourished and has muscle wasting. Laboratory testing reveals a low serum carnitine level and an elevated creatine kinase level. He is diagnosed with systemic primary carnitine deficiency, a rare genetic disorder that impairs the body's ability to transport fatty acids into the mitochondria for energy production. Treatment with high doses of oral carnitine supplementation is initiated, resulting in significant improvement in his symptoms and quality of life.

column3: A 5-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician with excessive weight gain and insatiable hunger. On examination, he is found to have almond-shaped eyes, a thin upper lip, and a small head circumference. He also has hypotonia and delayed motor development. Further evaluation reveals a deletion on chromosome 15, confirming the diagnosis of Prader-Willi syndrome. The parents report that the child has a history of feeding difficulties, including poor suckling and failure to thrive in infancy. They also note behavioral issues such as temper tantrums and obsessive-compulsive behaviors. The pediatrician recommends a multidisciplinary approach to manage the child's obesity, including a low-calorie diet and increased physical activity. They also refer the child to a geneticist and a developmental pediatrician for ongoing evaluation and management of the child's complex medical needs.
column10: Mr. Smith is a 35-year-old male with a history of Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) who presents to the clinic with complaints of excessive eating and weight gain. He reports feeling constantly hungry and has gained 10 pounds in the last month despite being on a strict diet. On physical examination, he has mild hypotonia and central obesity with a BMI of 38. His blood work reveals hyperphagia, hyperinsulinemia, and elevated fasting glucose levels consistent with PWS. He is referred to a nutritionist and endocrinologist for management of his weight and metabolic abnormalities.

column3: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician with developmental delay and distinct facial features. On examination, the child has arched eyebrows with long eyelashes, a flat nasal bridge, and a wide mouth with a prominent upper lip. The child also has short stature and joint hypermobility. The pediatrician suspects Kabuki syndrome and orders genetic testing to confirm the diagnosis. Further evaluation reveals hearing loss and a heart murmur. The child is referred to a multidisciplinary team for management of the various medical and developmental issues associated with Kabuki syndrome.
column10: Mr. X is a 28-year-old man with Kabuki syndrome who presents to the clinic with complaints of recurrent infections. He was diagnosed with Kabuki syndrome in childhood due to his distinctive facial features, including long eyelashes, arched eyebrows, and a flattened nasal tip. Mr. X has a history of hearing loss, heart defects, and developmental delay. On physical examination, he has joint hypermobility and short stature. Laboratory tests reveal low immunoglobulin levels, consistent with an increased susceptibility to infections. Mr. X is referred to an immunologist for further evaluation and management of his recurrent infections.

column3: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents with concerns about his short stature. The child was born at term with a birth weight of 7 lbs 4 oz, and has been growing at a slower rate than his peers. He is currently at the 10th percentile for height and weight. On physical exam, the child has a disproportionate short stature, with short arms and legs and a normal-sized trunk. His head circumference is average for his age. There is mild bowing of his legs and his fingers appear short and stubby. The child has no other significant medical history, and his developmental milestones are within normal limits. Based on these findings, a diagnosis of hypochondroplasia is suspected.
column10: Mrs. Smith is a 35-year-old woman with a history of hypochondroplasia. She presents to the clinic with complaints of lower back pain and difficulty walking. On physical examination, her height is 4 feet 5 inches, and her arm span is greater than her height. She has a short neck with limited range of motion, a protuberant abdomen, and mild lumbar lordosis. Her lower extremities are short and bowed, and she has a waddling gait. X-rays reveal a narrowed interpedicular distance and a small spinal canal. MRI shows mild spinal stenosis at the L4-L5 level. Mrs. Smith is diagnosed with lumbar spinal stenosis and referred to a neurosurgeon for further evaluation and management.

column3: A 7-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a swollen and painful right knee. He reports that he fell while playing basketball earlier in the day. The child has a past medical history of Hemophilia B, and his family reports that he has been experiencing frequent bleeding episodes. Physical examination reveals a large hemarthrosis in the right knee with limited range of motion. Laboratory tests confirm a low factor IX level. The child is diagnosed with a bleeding episode related to Hemophilia B and is started on factor IX replacement therapy. He is advised to avoid contact sports and activities that may increase the risk of bleeding. The child is referred to a Hemophilia treatment center for ongoing management and monitoring of his condition.
column10: John is a 35-year-old man with a history of Hemophilia B. He presents to the emergency department with severe pain and swelling in his right knee. On examination, there is tenderness, warmth, and a large effusion in the knee joint. His factor IX level is found to be significantly low. Imaging shows evidence of joint damage and bleeding. John is started on factor IX replacement therapy and pain control. He is referred to a hematology specialist for long-term management of his Hemophilia B.

column3: A 6-year-old girl presents to the pediatrician with concerns about her facial and head shape. On physical exam, she has a high forehead, small and wide-set eyes, a beaked nose, and mild facial asymmetry. Her head circumference is at the 99th percentile, and she has fusion of some of the bones in her skull. She also has shortened fingers and toes, with a small pinky finger that curves inward. Based on these findings, the pediatrician suspects Saethre-Chotzen syndrome and refers the patient to a geneticist for further evaluation and genetic testing.
column10: A 28-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of headaches and visual disturbances. On examination, she has a prominent forehead, low-set ears, and a small jaw. Her fingers are short and stubby, and her toes are abnormally fused. She also has a broad, flat nose and widely spaced eyes. These clinical features suggest a diagnosis of Saethre-Chotzen syndrome, a rare genetic disorder that affects craniofacial development. The patient is referred to a geneticist for further evaluation and management.

column1: Glycogen storage disease due to acid maltase deficiency
column3: A 4-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician with progressive muscle weakness, fatigue, and difficulty walking. His parents report that he has been experiencing these symptoms for the past year, and they have noticed that he has become more clumsy and has difficulty climbing stairs. The child has a history of recurrent episodes of hypoglycemia and has had several hospital admissions for unexplained episodes of vomiting and lethargy. Physical examination reveals muscle wasting and weakness, particularly in the proximal muscles. Blood tests show elevated creatine kinase levels and evidence of liver dysfunction. Based on these findings, the child is diagnosed with Glycogen storage disease due to acid maltase deficiency.
column10: A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with a history of weakness, fatigue, and muscle pain. He reports difficulty climbing stairs and feels easily fatigued after moderate activity. On physical examination, he appears thin with muscle wasting. His creatine kinase levels are elevated, and a muscle biopsy reveals the presence of vacuoles filled with glycogen. Further genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Glycogen storage disease due to acid maltase deficiency. The patient is started on enzyme replacement therapy, and his symptoms improve gradually over time.

column3: A 6-year-old boy was brought to the hospital by his parents with complaints of frequent headaches and difficulty in walking. On examination, the child had mild to moderate motor weakness in both legs, with a spastic gait. Neurological examination revealed evidence of cognitive impairment, including difficulty with memory and attention. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain showed multiple areas of leukoencephalopathy, with subcortical infarcts. Genetic testing revealed a mutation in the NOTCH3 gene, confirming a diagnosis of Cerebral autosomal dominant arteriopathy-subcortical infarcts-leukoencephalopathy (CADASIL). The child was started on symptomatic treatment and referred for genetic counseling for the family.
column10: A 56-year-old male presents with a history of recurrent episodes of stroke-like symptoms including weakness on his right side, difficulty with speech and coordination, and cognitive decline. Neurological examination revealed bilateral pyramidal signs and dysarthria. MRI showed multiple subcortical infarcts and extensive white matter changes consistent with Cerebral autosomal dominant arteriopathy-subcortical infarcts-leukoencephalopathy (CADASIL). Genetic testing confirmed the diagnosis. The patient had a family history of similar symptoms and was advised to undergo regular monitoring and management of stroke risk factors.

column3: A 7-year-old boy presents to the pediatric clinic with a family history of thyroid cancer and pheochromocytoma. He has a palpable thyroid nodule and episodes of hypertension and sweating. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2). Further evaluation reveals multiple endocrine tumors, including medullary thyroid carcinoma and bilateral pheochromocytomas. The patient undergoes surgical resection of the tumors and is started on lifelong thyroid hormone replacement therapy. Close monitoring for recurrence and development of additional tumors is necessary due to the high risk of malignancy associated with MEN2.
column10: A 35-year-old woman presented to the endocrine clinic with a history of pheochromocytoma and medullary thyroid carcinoma. She also reported a family history of similar tumors. Physical examination revealed palpable thyroid nodules and elevated serum calcitonin levels. Genetic testing confirmed the diagnosis of Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2). The patient was referred for thyroidectomy and adrenalectomy to prevent the development of further tumors. Regular surveillance for the recurrence of medullary thyroid carcinoma and pheochromocytoma was also recommended.

column3: A 4-year-old male child presented with progressive weakness, regression of developmental milestones, and seizures. His parents had noticed a decline in his motor abilities, and he had lost his ability to walk independently. On physical examination, he had a weak cry, hypotonia, and nystagmus. His brain MRI revealed symmetrical hyperintensities in the basal ganglia and brainstem, consistent with Leigh syndrome. Blood tests showed elevated lactate levels. Genetic testing confirmed a mutation in the mitochondrial DNA. The child was started on a regimen of thiamine, riboflavin, and coenzyme Q10, and was referred to a neurologist for further management.
column10: A 32-year-old male presents to the clinic with a long-standing history of progressive neurological symptoms, including muscle weakness, poor coordination, and difficulty speaking. He also reports experiencing frequent headaches and episodes of nausea and vomiting. On examination, the patient has bilateral optic atrophy, generalized hypotonia, and spasticity in his lower limbs. MRI imaging shows bilateral symmetrical lesions in the basal ganglia and brainstem. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Leigh syndrome, a rare inherited disorder that affects mitochondrial function and energy production in the body. The patient is started on supportive therapy, including thiamine, riboflavin, and other vitamins, but unfortunately, the prognosis is poor, and the patient's condition continues to decline over time.

column3: A 6-month-old male infant is brought to the pediatrician's office by his parents because of vomiting, poor feeding, and lethargy. The infant is the product of an uneventful pregnancy and delivery and has no significant past medical history. On physical examination, the infant appears irritable and is dehydrated. Blood tests reveal elevated levels of 3-hydroxyisovaleric acid, 3-methylcrotonylglycine, and 3-methylglutaconic acid. Based on these findings, the infant is diagnosed with 3-methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase deficiency. The parents are counseled about the need for a special diet and the importance of preventing fasting to avoid metabolic crises. The infant is started on a low-protein diet supplemented with a special formula and is referred to a metabolic specialist for further management.
column10: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting for the past 24 hours. He reports a history of recurrent episodes of abdominal pain and vomiting, especially after consuming high-protein meals. On physical examination, he appears lethargic and has mild dehydration. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of plasma ammonia and 3-hydroxyisovaleric acid. Further workup confirms a diagnosis of 3-methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase deficiency, an autosomal recessive metabolic disorder characterized by defective leucine metabolism. The patient is started on a low-protein diet, carnitine supplementation, and intravenous fluids to manage his symptoms and prevent further metabolic decompensation.

column3: A 5-year-old child presents to the pediatrician with a complaint of poor vision and light sensitivity. On physical examination, the child is noted to have very pale skin and hair, with blue irises and nystagmus. The child is diagnosed with Oculocutaneous albinism type 2, which is confirmed by genetic testing. The pediatrician educates the parents on the importance of sun protection and regular ophthalmologic follow-up to monitor for potential vision loss. The child is referred to a pediatric ophthalmologist for further evaluation and management.
column10: A 35-year-old male presents to the dermatology clinic with a lifelong history of fair skin, white hair, and light-colored eyes. He reports experiencing severe sunburns with minimal sun exposure and has a family history of similar symptoms. On examination, the patient has hypopigmented skin with numerous freckles and light-colored hair. He also has nystagmus and decreased visual acuity. The clinical features suggest a diagnosis of Oculocutaneous albinism type 2, a genetic disorder that affects melanin production and causes hypopigmentation of the skin, hair, and eyes. The patient is advised to use sun protection measures and undergo regular ophthalmologic examinations to monitor for potential vision impairment.

column3: A 5-year-old child presents to the dermatology clinic with yellowish papules on the neck, axilla, and groin. The papules are discrete and have a cobblestone appearance. The child has a history of hypermobility of joints and recurrent joint dislocations. The ophthalmological examination reveals angioid streaks in the retina. The clinical presentation is consistent with Pseudoxanthoma elasticum, a rare genetic disorder that affects the elastic fibers in the skin, eyes, and blood vessels. The diagnosis is confirmed by genetic testing. The child is referred to a multidisciplinary team for management and monitoring of potential complications such as arterial stiffening, gastrointestinal bleeding, and retinal detachment.
column10: A 35-year-old female presents with yellowish papules on her neck, axilla, and groin for the past 5 years. She reports decreased vision in her left eye and a history of gastrointestinal bleeding. On examination, she has multiple small yellowish papules on her skin and a cobblestone appearance on the back of her neck. Fundoscopy reveals angioid streaks in both eyes. Skin biopsy confirms the diagnosis of pseudoxanthoma elasticum. The patient is referred for genetic counseling and advised to undergo routine ophthalmologic and gastrointestinal evaluations.

column3: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the ophthalmologist with complaints of poor vision since birth. The parents also report that the child has difficulty seeing in low light conditions. The child has no other significant medical history or family history of eye diseases. On examination, the child's visual acuity is severely impaired, and the fundus shows evidence of retinal degeneration, including pale optic discs and attenuated retinal vessels. Electroretinography (ERG) confirms the diagnosis of Leber congenital amaurosis. The ophthalmologist discusses the prognosis and recommends genetic testing for the child and his family members.
column10: Ms. X is a 30-year-old female who presents with a history of progressive visual impairment since childhood. She reports difficulty seeing in dimly lit environments and has noticed a loss of peripheral vision. Her medical history is significant for a diagnosis of Leber congenital amaurosis (LCA) at the age of 5. On examination, her visual acuity is severely impaired, with hand motion vision in both eyes. Fundus examination reveals a pale optic disc and attenuated retinal vessels. Electroretinogram (ERG) shows severely reduced or absent responses. Genetic testing confirms a homozygous mutation in the RPE65 gene. Ms. X is counseled regarding the progressive nature of the disease and the lack of effective treatments. She is advised to maintain regular follow-up with her ophthalmologist and to use low-vision aids to optimize her visual function.

column3: A 10-year-old boy presents with chronic muscle weakness, fatigue, and intermittent muscle cramps. He has a history of frequent urination and excessive thirst. On physical examination, he is found to have low blood pressure and a low heart rate. Laboratory tests reveal hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and low magnesium levels. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Gitelman syndrome. The child is started on potassium and magnesium supplements, and his symptoms gradually improve. Follow-up visits show normalization of his electrolyte levels and resolution of his symptoms.
column10: A 28-year-old male presents with recurrent episodes of muscle weakness, cramping, and fatigue. He also reports intermittent episodes of abdominal pain and nausea. On examination, his blood pressure is low, and he has mild hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia. His serum electrolytes show a metabolic alkalosis. The patient has a history of frequent episodes of tetany and carpopedal spasm. He reports no family history of renal disorders. Based on his clinical findings, the patient is diagnosed with Gitelman syndrome, a rare autosomal recessive renal tubular disorder that is characterized by a defect in the thiazide-sensitive sodium-chloride co-transporter in the distal convoluted tubule. The patient is started on potassium and magnesium supplements, along with a low-sodium diet. Regular monitoring of his serum electrolytes and renal function is planned to prevent complications such as renal impairment and arrhythmias.

column3: A 5-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a history of pale skin, white hair, and light blue eyes. His parents report that he has always had poor vision and struggles to see in bright sunlight. The child has a history of frequent sunburns despite using sunscreen regularly. Examination reveals nystagmus and reduced visual acuity. His skin lacks pigmentation and has multiple freckles. The child is diagnosed with Oculocutaneous albinism type 1, a rare genetic disorder that affects the production of melanin, leading to hypopigmentation of the skin, hair, and eyes. The child is advised to avoid excessive sun exposure and to wear protective clothing and sunglasses to minimize the risk of skin cancer and vision problems.
column10: A 28-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology clinic with a history of photophobia and reduced visual acuity since childhood. He reports a family history of albinism and fair skin with frequent sunburns. On examination, he has white hair, pale skin, and iris transillumination defects. His best-corrected visual acuity is 20/100 in both eyes, with nystagmus and strabismus noted. Fundus examination reveals hypopigmentation of the retina and foveal hypoplasia. A diagnosis of oculocutaneous albinism type 1 is made based on the clinical features. The patient is counseled on sun protection measures, the importance of regular ophthalmic follow-up, and low vision aids.

column3: A 6-year-old boy presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of poor vision and difficulty seeing in low light. His parents report that he has had these symptoms for the past year. On examination, the child has reduced visual acuity and color vision. Fundus examination reveals a pale optic disc, attenuated blood vessels, and macular atrophy. Electroretinography (ERG) shows reduced cone and rod function. Based on these findings, the child is diagnosed with cone rod dystrophy. Further genetic testing is recommended to identify the underlying cause of the condition.
column10: A 35-year-old male presents with complaints of progressive vision loss in both eyes for the past 5 years. He has difficulty seeing in dim light and his peripheral vision is gradually decreasing. The patient reports a family history of similar vision problems. On examination, visual acuity is reduced to 20/200 in both eyes. Fundoscopy shows macular atrophy with thinning of the retinal vessels. Electroretinography (ERG) reveals reduced cone and rod responses, consistent with cone-rod dystrophy. The patient is referred to a genetic counselor for further evaluation and management.

column3: A 6-month-old male infant presents with poor feeding, vomiting, lethargy, and seizures. The infant was born at term without any complications. Upon physical examination, the infant appears jaundiced and has hepatomegaly. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated serum ammonia levels and hyperammonemia. The infant is diagnosed with Citrullinemia type I, an autosomal recessive disorder of the urea cycle. Treatment with a low-protein diet and medications to reduce ammonia levels is initiated. The child is referred to a metabolic specialist for long-term management.
column10: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department with confusion and lethargy. He has a history of recurrent episodes of vomiting, abdominal pain, and seizures. On physical examination, he appears jaundiced with hepatosplenomegaly. His blood tests reveal hyperammonemia, elevated liver enzymes, and low serum citrulline levels. A diagnosis of Citrullinemia type I is made. The patient is started on intravenous fluids, medications to reduce ammonia levels, and a low-protein diet. He is referred to a metabolic specialist for long-term management.

column3: A 10-year-old male presented to the pediatric clinic with a history of recurrent abdominal pain, intermittent diarrhea, and multiple dark pigmented spots on his lips, oral mucosa, and hands. On physical examination, there were several polyps detected on colonoscopy, and a diagnosis of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome was made. The family history was significant for similar pigmented spots in his father and sister. Genetic testing confirmed a germline mutation in the STK11 gene. The child was referred to a gastroenterologist for further management and surveillance for the development of gastrointestinal malignancies.
column10: A 38-year-old male presented with a history of multiple episodes of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting for the past few months. He reported a history of multiple surgeries for small bowel obstruction in the past. He also had a family history of gastrointestinal cancers. On examination, he had multiple hyperpigmented macules on his lips, buccal mucosa, and fingertips. There was no palpable abdominal mass or lymphadenopathy. An abdominal CT scan revealed multiple polyps in the small bowel. Endoscopy confirmed the presence of numerous polyps in the stomach and small bowel. Genetic testing confirmed the diagnosis of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. The patient was advised to undergo regular surveillance for gastrointestinal malignancies and to follow up with a gastroenterologist.

column3: A 5-year-old boy presents to the clinic with multiple café-au-lait macules on his skin and a family history of similar skin findings. On examination, there are over 6 café-au-lait macules, axillary freckling, and cutaneous neurofibromas. The child has developmental delay and speech difficulties. Genetic testing confirms Legius syndrome. Further evaluation reveals no evidence of neurofibromatosis type 1.
column10: A 36-year-old woman presents with multiple café-au-lait spots and freckling on her skin. She reports a history of learning difficulties and developmental delays during childhood. On examination, she has axillary freckling and multiple café-au-lait spots on her trunk and limbs. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of Legius syndrome. Further evaluation reveals no evidence of neurofibromas or other complications associated with neurofibromatosis type 1. The patient is counseled on the benign nature of Legius syndrome and advised to continue regular surveillance for any signs of complications.

column3: A 5-year-old male child presented with a history of recurrent bone pain, bowing of legs and short stature since early childhood. Physical examination revealed mild genu varum deformity and dental abnormalities. Laboratory investigations showed hypophosphatemia, increased alkaline phosphatase and decreased renal tubular maximum reabsorption rate of phosphate. Based on the clinical and laboratory findings, the child was diagnosed with X-linked hypophosphatemia, a rare genetic disorder that affects the metabolism of phosphate and leads to rickets-like symptoms. The child was started on phosphate and vitamin D supplementation to prevent further bone deformities and improve growth.
column10: John is a 32-year-old male who has been experiencing bone pain, weakness, and deformities since childhood. He has a history of multiple fractures and dental problems. On examination, he has a short stature, bowed legs, and a protuberant forehead. Laboratory investigations reveal low serum phosphate levels and elevated alkaline phosphatase levels. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of X-linked hypophosphatemia. He is started on phosphate supplements and calcitriol, which improve his symptoms and serum phosphate levels.

column1: Autosomal dominant optic atrophy, classic form
column3: A 7-year-old boy presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of gradual loss of vision in both eyes over the past few years. His parents report that he has difficulty seeing objects at a distance and frequently bumps into things. On examination, his visual acuity is reduced to 20/100 in both eyes. Fundus examination reveals optic disc pallor and attenuation of retinal vessels, consistent with the diagnosis of autosomal dominant optic atrophy, classic form. The boy has no other significant medical history or family history of similar symptoms. Further genetic testing confirms the diagnosis. The ophthalmologist recommends regular follow-up and low-vision aids to improve his quality of life.
column10: A 35-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology clinic with a complaint of decreased vision in both eyes for the past year. His family history is significant for multiple members with similar visual symptoms. On examination, his visual acuity is reduced to 20/200 in both eyes with bilateral optic disc pallor and central scotomas on visual field testing. The patient is diagnosed with Autosomal dominant optic atrophy, classic form, and genetic testing confirms the OPA1 mutation. The patient is referred to a genetic counselor for further counseling and management.

column3: Sarah is a 10-year-old girl who presents to the neurology clinic with a history of difficulty walking and frequent falls. Her parents report that she has had these symptoms for the past few years, but they have become progressively worse. On examination, Sarah has a wide-based gait and difficulty with coordination, particularly in her lower extremities. She also has decreased reflexes in her legs and an abnormal Babinski sign. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Friedreich ataxia. Further evaluation reveals a hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and scoliosis. Sarah's parents are counseled on the progressive nature of the disease and the need for close monitoring of cardiac function. Physical therapy is recommended to help with coordination and balance, and a referral is made to a cardiologist for further management of her cardiac disease.
column10: John is a 32-year-old male who presents with progressive difficulty walking and coordination problems for the past few years. He reports falling frequently and experiencing uncontrolled shaking of his limbs. Upon examination, he has a staggering gait, difficulty with fine motor movements, and diminished reflexes in his lower limbs. His speech is slightly slurred, and he has nystagmus. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of Friedreich ataxia. Additional findings include scoliosis and cardiomyopathy on echocardiogram. John's family history is significant for his brother also having Friedreich ataxia.

column3: A 6-year-old child presents with facial deformities and difficulty hearing. On physical examination, the child has a small jaw, narrow airway, and drooping lower eyelids. The child also has bilateral conductive hearing loss. These features are consistent with Treacher-Collins syndrome, a rare genetic disorder that affects facial development. The child may require surgery to correct the jaw and airway abnormalities, as well as hearing aids or cochlear implants to improve hearing.
column10: Ms. S is a 35-year-old female with a known history of Treacher-Collins syndrome. She presents to the clinic with complaints of difficulty breathing and swallowing. On examination, her facial features are consistent with the syndrome, including underdeveloped cheekbones, a small jaw, and downward slanting eyes. She has a high-arched palate and a narrow airway, contributing to her respiratory and swallowing difficulties. A flexible nasopharyngolaryngoscopy was performed, which revealed a narrow pharynx and larynx, with no evidence of obstructing lesions. Further management is focused on addressing her airway and feeding difficulties through a multidisciplinary approach involving speech and language therapy, nutrition, and possible surgical interventions.

column3: A 4-year-old male child presents to the clinic with multiple basal cell carcinomas on his face and trunk. He also has several odontogenic keratocysts in his jaw and palmar pits on his hands. His mother reports a family history of similar skin lesions and jaw cysts. Upon further examination, the child has macrocephaly, frontal bossing, and hypertelorism. These findings, along with his clinical history, are consistent with Gorlin syndrome. The child is referred to a geneticist for further evaluation and management of this autosomal dominant disorder.
column10: Mr. X, a 35-year-old man with a past medical history of multiple basal cell carcinomas and a family history of Gorlin syndrome, presents to the dermatology clinic with a new lesion on his forehead. Physical examination reveals multiple skin lesions, including a large basal cell carcinoma on his back and several smaller lesions on his face, scalp, and trunk. He also has several palmar pits and a mild hypertelorism. Genetic testing confirms a pathogenic variant in the PTCH1 gene, consistent with Gorlin syndrome.

column3: A 5-year-old boy presents with developmental delay and characteristic facial features. His parents report that he has never been able to speak and has significant difficulty with motor coordination. Physical examination reveals a high forehead, wide-set eyes, a small chin, and a prominent nose. The child also has seizures and hearing loss. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome, a rare genetic disorder caused by a deletion on chromosome 4p. Treatment is mainly supportive and may include speech and occupational therapy, as well as medication to control seizures.
column10: A 28-year-old female presents to the clinic with a history of developmental delay and facial dysmorphism. On examination, she has a high forehead, wide nasal bridge, and a small chin. She also has prominent epicanthal folds and widely spaced eyes. She has a short stature and a high-pitched voice. The patient reports a history of seizures and recurrent upper respiratory infections. Her medical history is significant for Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome, a rare genetic disorder caused by a deletion of genetic material on chromosome 4p. The patient is referred to a geneticist for further evaluation and management.

column3: A 5-year-old male presents to the pediatrician's office with a history of vomiting, diarrhea, and failure to thrive. The child has been experiencing recurrent episodes of abdominal pain and has lost significant weight over the past few months. A physical exam reveals hepatosplenomegaly and hyperlipidemia. Further evaluation reveals low levels of lysosomal acid lipase activity, leading to a diagnosis of Lysosomal acid lipase deficiency. The child is referred to a specialist for further management and treatment.
column10: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of abdominal pain, diarrhea, and unintentional weight loss. The patient reports having a history of hyperlipidemia and was previously diagnosed with fatty liver disease. Physical examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly and mild jaundice. Laboratory tests show elevated liver enzymes and low levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol. Further testing reveals a deficiency in lysosomal acid lipase (LAL) activity, confirming a diagnosis of Lysosomal Acid Lipase Deficiency (LAL-D). The patient is started on enzyme replacement therapy and referred to a specialist for ongoing management.

column3: A 2-day-old female neonate is brought to the pediatrician's office by her parents with concerns of unusual physical features. The child is noted to have a small chest, short limbs, and a flattened face. She also has a cleft palate and a small chin. The neonate has respiratory distress and is tachypneic. The pediatrician notes these clinical features and orders imaging studies. The imaging studies reveal that the child has Campomelic dysplasia, a rare genetic disorder characterized by skeletal abnormalities, including bowing of the long bones, and abnormal curvature of the spine. The pediatrician discusses the diagnosis with the parents and refers them to a geneticist for further evaluation and management.
column10: A 25-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of short stature and difficulty breathing. On examination, he is noted to have a short neck, flattened face, and a small jaw. His chest is narrow and bell-shaped with prominent ribs and a short, bowed sternum. There is also a curvature of the spine, with mild scoliosis and kyphosis. The patient reports a history of recurrent respiratory infections and difficulty with physical activity. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Campomelic dysplasia, a rare genetic disorder characterized by skeletal abnormalities, respiratory distress, and genital anomalies. The patient is referred for further evaluation and management by a multidisciplinary team, including orthopedics, pulmonology, and endocrinology.

column2: Change in presentation related to age
column3: A 3-day-old male infant presented with poor feeding, vomiting, lethargy, and seizures. The baby was born at term with no complications during delivery. The mother reported a family history of urea cycle disorders. Physical examination revealed hepatomegaly and neurological abnormalities including hyperreflexia and hypertonia. Laboratory investigations showed elevated ammonia levels, metabolic acidosis, and elevated liver function tests. A diagnosis of Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency was made based on clinical presentation, family history, and laboratory findings. The infant was started on emergent treatment with intravenous glucose, lipids, and arginine.
column10: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency room with confusion and vomiting. He has a history of recurrent episodes of unexplained lethargy and confusion. On examination, he is drowsy, disoriented, and has signs of hyperammonemia such as asterixis and elevated ammonia levels. Further investigations revealed elevated levels of citrulline, arginine, and ornithine, and a genetic test confirmed a diagnosis of Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency. He was started on intravenous sodium benzoate and arginine to lower ammonia levels and was referred to a metabolic specialist for further management.

column3: A 7-year-old boy presents with a history of multiple schwannomas involving various cranial nerves, spinal nerves, and peripheral nerves. The patient has a family history of neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2), and genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of full NF2-related schwannomatosis. He complains of persistent headaches, difficulty with balance, and hearing loss in his left ear. Physical examination reveals multiple subcutaneous nodules and café-au-lait spots on his skin. MRI shows multiple enhancing masses throughout the brain and spinal cord, including bilateral acoustic neuromas, multiple spinal nerve sheath tumors, and peripheral nerve tumors. Treatment options are discussed with the family, and the patient undergoes surgical resection of the largest tumors with follow-up monitoring for any new tumor growth or symptoms.
column10: A 34-year-old male presents with a six-month history of progressive hearing loss in his left ear. On examination, he is found to have multiple painless subcutaneous nodules on his scalp and neck. MRI of the brain and spine reveals multiple intracranial and spinal tumors consistent with schwannomas. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Full NF2-related schwannomatosis. The patient is referred to a multidisciplinary team for management, including surgical resection of symptomatic tumors and ongoing surveillance for potential tumor growth and associated neurological deficits.

column3: A 6-year-old male presents to the clinic with delayed speech development and intellectual disability. The child has a small head circumference and a distinctive facial appearance with deep-set eyes, a broad nasal bridge, and a pointed chin. He also has seizures and constipation. Further genetic testing reveals a deletion or mutation in the ZEB2 gene, confirming a diagnosis of Mowat-Wilson syndrome. The child is referred for further evaluation and management of his developmental and neurological needs.
column10: A 32-year-old male presents to the clinic with a history of developmental delay, intellectual disability, and facial dysmorphism. On physical examination, he has a prominent forehead, deep-set eyes, a short nose with a prominent nasal bridge, and a wide mouth with a prominent upper lip. He also has hypotonia and gait ataxia. He has a history of Hirschsprung disease and seizures. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the ZEB2 gene, confirming a diagnosis of Mowat-Wilson syndrome.

column3: A 4-year-old boy was brought to the pediatrician due to developmental delays and abnormal eye movements. Upon examination, the child was found to have hypotonia, ataxia, and a characteristic "molar tooth sign" on brain imaging. Further genetic testing confirmed a diagnosis of Joubert syndrome. The child also had episodes of apnea, which required continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) during sleep. The pediatrician referred the child to a neurologist and a genetic counselor for further management and counseling.
column10: A 27-year-old woman presents to the neurology clinic with a history of difficulty with coordination and balance since childhood. She reports that she has difficulty with fine motor skills, such as writing and buttoning clothes. She also experiences frequent episodes of dizziness and vertigo. Upon examination, the physician notes that the patient has a distinctive facial appearance, including a prominent forehead and a small chin. She also has abnormal eye movements and a jerky, unsteady gait. MRI imaging reveals a characteristic "molar tooth sign," indicating Joubert syndrome. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis. The patient is referred to a multidisciplinary team for management of her symptoms, which may include physical therapy, speech therapy, and neurologic medications.

column3: A 2-year-old male child is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of poor muscle tone, developmental delay, and visual impairment. On physical examination, the child is found to have microcephaly, hypotonia, and difficulty with eye movements. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain reveals brain malformations, including lissencephaly and cerebellar hypoplasia. The child is diagnosed with Walker-Warburg syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by congenital muscular dystrophy, brain malformations, and eye abnormalities. The prognosis is poor, with most affected children not surviving beyond infancy.
column10: A 32-year-old male presents with severe muscle weakness, difficulty walking, and multiple congenital anomalies. On examination, he has a large head circumference, microcephaly, and bilateral cataracts. He also has severe hypotonia and muscle wasting, with limited range of motion in his joints. Neurological exam reveals global developmental delay, nystagmus, and seizures. MRI shows a small brain with cerebellar hypoplasia and hydrocephalus. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Walker-Warburg syndrome.

column1: Homocystinuria due to cystathionine beta-synthase deficiency
column3: A 6-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician with developmental delay and poor growth. On examination, the child has a tall stature with long limbs and thin body habitus. He has a high arched palate, myopia, and dislocated lenses in both eyes. The child also has a marfanoid habitus, with hypermobility of the joints and a pectus excavatum. The pediatrician suspects a metabolic disorder and orders a blood test, which shows elevated levels of homocysteine and methionine. Further testing confirms a diagnosis of Homocystinuria due to cystathionine beta-synthase deficiency. The child is started on a low protein diet, vitamin B6 supplementation, and betaine therapy to reduce homocysteine levels and prevent further complications such as thromboembolism, osteoporosis, and intellectual disability.
column10: A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue, joint pain, and visual disturbances. On physical examination, he has a tall stature, thin build, and long, slender fingers. He also has a high arched palate and a history of lens dislocation. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of homocysteine and methionine in the blood, confirming a diagnosis of Homocystinuria due to cystathionine beta-synthase deficiency. Further investigations reveal a genetic mutation in the CBS gene. The patient is started on a low-methionine diet and vitamin B6 supplements, with regular follow-up to monitor his symptoms and homocysteine levels.

column2: Change in presentation related to age
column3: A 6-month-old infant presents with poor feeding, lethargy, and hypotonia. On examination, the child has a weak cry, poor muscle tone, and is unresponsive to stimuli. Laboratory studies reveal an elevated lactate level and metabolic acidosis. The child is diagnosed with biotinidase deficiency, a rare inherited disorder that prevents the body from processing biotin, a B-vitamin essential for normal growth and development. Treatment with biotin supplementation is initiated, and the child's symptoms gradually improve. Follow-up testing confirms the diagnosis of biotinidase deficiency through genetic testing, and the child is placed on lifelong biotin supplementation.
column10: A 28-year-old male presents with a history of seizures, developmental delays, and vision loss. He also reports experiencing muscle weakness and difficulty walking. On examination, he has sparse hair and eyebrows, and his skin is dry and scaly. Lab results reveal low levels of biotin and elevated levels of lactate and pyruvate. These findings, along with a positive biotinidase enzyme assay, lead to a diagnosis of biotinidase deficiency. The patient is started on biotin supplementation, which results in a significant improvement in his symptoms.

column3: A 7-year-old boy was brought to the clinic by his parents due to difficulty with coordination and balance. The parents reported that their son frequently falls and has difficulty walking straight. The child also has slurred speech and difficulty swallowing.
