On examination, the child had a wide-based gait, with frequent stumbling and loss of balance. His speech was slow and slurred, and he had difficulty with fine motor movements. Genetic testing confirmed a diagnosis of Spinocerebellar ataxia type 3.
column10: A 45-year-old male presents with a 5-year history of progressive gait ataxia, dysarthria, and dysphagia. He also complains of tremors in his hands and difficulty with fine motor skills. The patient has a family history of similar symptoms, and genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Spinocerebellar ataxia type 3 (SCA3). On examination, the patient has a wide-based gait with uncoordinated movements, slurred speech, and difficulty swallowing. There is also evidence of mild tremors in his hands and difficulty with finger-to-nose testing. MRI of the brain reveals cerebellar atrophy. The patient is started on symptomatic treatment with physical therapy, speech therapy, and medications to manage tremors and spasticity.

column3: A 7-year-old boy presents to the neurology clinic with a history of difficulty with balance and coordination. On examination, he has a wide-based gait and poor coordination of his limbs. He also has difficulty with fine motor tasks, such as buttoning his shirt. His reflexes are brisk, and he has dysarthria with slurring of his speech. Genetic testing reveals a diagnosis of Spinocerebellar ataxia type 2.
column10: Mr. Smith, a 45-year-old male, presented to the neurology clinic with a chief complaint of difficulty with balance and coordination for the past few years. He reported frequent falls and difficulty with activities that require fine motor skills. On examination, he had a wide-based gait, dysmetria, and dysarthria. He also had nystagmus and impaired smooth pursuit eye movements. His family history was significant for similar symptoms in his father and two siblings. Genetic testing confirmed a diagnosis of Spinocerebellar ataxia type 2. Further evaluation revealed evidence of cerebellar atrophy on brain imaging. The patient was started on physical therapy and referred for genetic counseling.

column3: A 7-year-old boy presents with unsteady gait and frequent falls. On examination, he has dysarthria, nystagmus, and intention tremors. His reflexes are brisk and he has difficulty with fine motor tasks. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the ATXN1 gene, confirming the diagnosis of Spinocerebellar ataxia type 1. The child's family history reveals that his father also has the same condition. The child is referred to a specialist for management and genetic counseling.
column10: Mr. Johnson is a 45-year-old man who presents with gait difficulties and unsteadiness for the past year. He reports frequent falls and difficulty with fine motor tasks such as buttoning his shirt. His family history is significant for his father and grandfather having similar symptoms. On physical examination, he demonstrates a wide-based, unsteady gait and difficulty with tandem walking. He also has dysarthria and dysphagia. Neurological examination reveals limb and truncal ataxia, hyperreflexia, and extensor plantar responses. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Spinocerebellar ataxia type 1.

column3: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician's office with complaints of difficulty walking and frequent falls. His parents report that he has always been a clumsy child, but his symptoms have worsened over the past year. On examination, the boy has spasticity and weakness in his legs, with brisk reflexes and a positive Babinski sign. His upper extremities are unaffected, and he does not have any cognitive or behavioral abnormalities. After further evaluation, the child is diagnosed with primary lateral sclerosis, a rare form of motor neuron disease that primarily affects the upper motor neurons. The prognosis for this condition is generally good, but the child will require ongoing physical therapy to manage his symptoms.
column10: A 54-year-old man presents with a 2-year history of progressive weakness in his legs and difficulty with coordination. He has no significant medical history and takes no medications. On examination, he is found to have spasticity in his lower extremities, hyperreflexia, and increased muscle tone. There is no evidence of muscle wasting or fasciculations. He has a positive Babinski sign and difficulty with heel-to-toe walking. MRI of the brain and spine are normal. Electromyography and nerve conduction studies reveal normal motor and sensory function, ruling out peripheral neuropathy. After further evaluation, the patient is diagnosed with Primary Lateral Sclerosis, a rare form of motor neuron disease characterized by progressive spasticity and weakness in the limbs without muscle wasting or fasciculations.

column3: A 5-year-old girl presents to the pediatrician with complaints of frequent urination, excessive thirst, and difficulty seeing in the dark. On examination, she appears pale and dehydrated. Her blood pressure is elevated, and her urine analysis reveals the presence of cystine crystals. The physician suspects cystinosis and orders further tests. The child's blood test shows elevated levels of cystine, confirming the diagnosis. The physician initiates treatment with cysteamine, and the child's symptoms start to improve gradually. The physician discusses the importance of strict adherence to treatment and regular follow-up visits to monitor the disease's progression.
column10: A 30-year-old male presents to the clinic with a history of recurrent episodes of dehydration, vomiting, and lethargy. On examination, he appears pale, has dry mucous membranes, and decreased urine output. Further investigations reveal that he has anemia, hypokalemia, and metabolic acidosis. A renal biopsy confirms the diagnosis of Cystinosis. The patient is started on cysteamine therapy to prevent the accumulation of cystine crystals in the kidneys and other organs. The patient is advised to maintain adequate hydration and follow-up regularly with his nephrologist for renal function monitoring.

column3: A 6-year-old male child presents to the pediatrician with developmental delay and intellectual disability. His parents report that he has difficulty with fine and gross motor skills and has delayed speech and language development. Physical examination reveals a distinctive facial appearance, including a prominent forehead, large ears, and a wide mouth with prominent lips. The child also has short stature and broad, tapered fingers with hyperextensible joints. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Coffin-Lowry syndrome, a rare X-linked genetic disorder characterized by intellectual disability, developmental delay, and distinctive facial features. The pediatrician provides the family with genetic counseling and refers the child to early intervention services to optimize his development and quality of life.
column10: Mr. Smith is a 35-year-old male with a history of developmental delay and intellectual disability. He presents to the clinic with complaints of difficulty with speech and fine motor skills. On examination, he has dysmorphic facial features including a prominent forehead, a wide nasal bridge, and downward-slanting eyes. He also has large, fleshy hands with tapering fingers and a short stature. His gait is unsteady, and he has difficulty with balance and coordination. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Coffin-Lowry syndrome.

column3: A 4-year-old boy was brought to the clinic by his parents with complaints of developmental delay and difficulty walking. The parents reported that the child had started walking late and had experienced frequent falls. On examination, the child had decreased muscle tone and strength, and exaggerated reflexes. He was unable to perform coordinated movements and appeared unsteady on his feet. His speech was also delayed, and he was unable to form complete sentences. Further tests revealed an absence of myelin in the brain, indicating Metachromatic leukodystrophy.
column10: A 30-year-old male presents to the neurology clinic with progressive weakness and loss of coordination in his limbs. He reports a history of clumsiness and difficulty with fine motor tasks that started in childhood. On examination, he has spasticity and hyperreflexia in all four limbs, with muscle atrophy and fasciculations. He also has cognitive impairment, including memory deficits and difficulty with abstract reasoning. MRI of the brain shows diffuse white matter signal abnormality. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Metachromatic leukodystrophy.

column3: A 3-year-old male child is brought to the pediatrician by his parents with concerns of developmental delay and behavioral issues. The child has not yet begun to speak in full sentences and is often restless and irritable. On physical examination, the child has coarse facial features, enlarged liver and spleen, and joint stiffness. The pediatrician suspects Sanfilippo syndrome and orders further diagnostic tests. The urine test shows high levels of glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) and genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Sanfilippo syndrome type A. The child is referred to a specialist for further management.
column10: A 30-year-old male presents with progressive developmental delay, behavioral abnormalities, and neurological symptoms. The patient has a history of delayed speech and cognitive impairment since childhood. On examination, he has coarse facial features, a prominent forehead, and a large tongue. Neurological examination reveals impaired coordination, gait abnormalities, and exaggerated reflexes. Further investigations reveal elevated urinary glycosaminoglycans and deficient enzyme activity, consistent with Sanfilippo syndrome type A. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis. The patient is referred to a specialist for genetic counseling and symptomatic management.

column2: Change in presentation related to age
column3: A 4-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician due to shortness of breath and difficulty breathing. The infant is noted to have a small chest with a narrow rib cage and short limbs. The chest X-ray shows a bell-shaped thorax with reduced lung capacity. The infant is diagnosed with Jeune syndrome, also known as asphyxiating thoracic dystrophy. The parents report that the infant has had difficulty feeding and gaining weight. The pediatrician refers the infant to a pediatric orthopedic surgeon for further management of the skeletal abnormalities.
column10: A 28-year-old female presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath and chest pain. She has a history of Jeune syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by short stature, a narrow chest, and respiratory distress. On physical examination, her respiratory rate is elevated, and she appears to be in respiratory distress. Her chest X-ray reveals a narrow thorax and prominent pulmonary vasculature. Arterial blood gas analysis reveals hypoxemia and respiratory acidosis. The patient is immediately started on supplemental oxygen and is admitted to the hospital for further management of her respiratory distress.

column3: A 6-month-old female infant is brought to the clinic by her parents for a genetic evaluation. The parents report that their daughter was born with multiple birth defects, including a cleft palate, heart defects, and an anal atresia. On physical examination, the infant has hypertelorism (widely spaced eyes) and downward slanting of the palpebral fissures, giving the appearance of "cat eyes." The child also has low-set ears, a small head circumference, and a high-arched palate. The geneticist suspects Cat-eye syndrome, a rare genetic disorder caused by a duplication of a specific region on chromosome 22. The child is referred for genetic testing and further evaluation to confirm the diagnosis and determine the appropriate management and treatment plan.
column10: A 28-year-old female presents to the clinic with a history of developmental delay and multiple congenital anomalies. Physical examination reveals hypertelorism, downward slanting of the eyes, and coloboma of the iris. There is also a small growth on the iris that resembles a "cat's eye." The patient reports hearing loss and has a cleft palate. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Cat-eye syndrome, a rare chromosomal disorder characterized by multiple anomalies involving the eyes, ears, heart, and kidneys. The patient is referred to a genetic counselor for further management and surveillance of potential complications.

column1: Autosomal recessive generalized dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa, severe form
column3: A 4-year-old male child is brought to the hospital by his parents with complaints of persistent skin blistering and wounds. The child has a known history of autosomal recessive generalized dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa, severe form. On examination, the child has widespread skin erosions and blisters on the face, neck, trunk, and extremities. There are multiple wounds and areas of tissue loss, exposing the underlying muscle and bone. The oral mucosa is also involved, with blisters and erosions on the tongue and inside of the cheeks. The child is malnourished, anemic, and has a low-grade fever. The parents report that the child is experiencing severe pain, especially during dressing changes and bathing. The child is admitted to the hospital for wound care and pain management. The child's condition is life-threatening, and the prognosis is poor, with a high risk of infection, sepsis, and death.
column10: A 28-year-old male presents with a history of recurrent blistering and erosions on his skin since birth. He reports that even minor friction or trauma results in severe pain and blistering, which often takes weeks to heal. On physical examination, the patient has extensive scarring and blistering over his entire body, including his scalp, face, hands, and feet. The skin appears thin and fragile, with areas of erosions and crusting. The nails are dystrophic, and the patient has lost several of his fingers due to repeated infections. The mucous membranes of the mouth, throat, and esophagus are also affected, leading to difficulty eating and swallowing. The patient reports a history of anemia and malnutrition due to the chronic inflammation and poor absorption of nutrients from the gut. The clinical features are consistent with Autosomal recessive generalized dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa, severe form, a rare inherited disorder that affects the structural proteins of the skin and mucous membranes. The condition is associated with a high risk of complications, including chronic pain, infections, scarring, and squamous cell carcinoma.

column3: A 5-year-old boy presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue, anemia, and recurrent infections. He also has a history of easy bruising and bleeding. On physical examination, he has hepatosplenomegaly and bone pain. Further investigation reveals low platelet count and elevated levels of chitotriosidase. The diagnosis of Gaucher disease is suspected, and genetic testing confirms the diagnosis. The patient is referred to a specialist for further management.
column10: A 35-year-old female presents with a history of easy bruising, fatigue, and anemia. She reports a family history of Gaucher disease. Physical examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly and mild skeletal abnormalities. Laboratory tests show thrombocytopenia, anemia, and elevated levels of acid phosphatase. A bone marrow biopsy confirms the diagnosis of Gaucher disease. The patient is referred to a specialist for further management and enzyme replacement therapy.

column3: A 6-year-old male child presents with thick, scaly, and dry skin all over his body since birth. He has a history of frequent infections and eye problems. On physical examination, his skin appears rough, and there is excessive scaling on the scalp, neck, and extremities. His eyes appear red and irritated, and he has a corneal opacity. The child also has a history of developmental delay and intellectual disability. Genetic testing reveals a diagnosis of syndromic recessive X-linked ichthyosis.
column10: John is a 35-year-old male presenting with thick, scaly, and dry skin all over his body. He has been experiencing these symptoms since childhood. On examination, he has a thick layer of scales on his scalp, face, neck, and extremities. The skin on his palms and soles is thickened and has deep fissures. John also has hair loss and a reduced ability to sweat. Further questioning revealed that John's mother is a carrier of the genetic mutation associated with syndromic recessive X-linked ichthyosis. Genetic testing confirmed the diagnosis.  Syndromic recessive X-linked ichthyosis is a rare genetic disorder characterized by dry, scaly skin that affects males. It is caused by a deficiency in steroid sulfatase, an enzyme that helps to break down cholesterol sulfate in the skin. This results in the buildup of scale on the skin's surface, causing the characteristic symptoms of the condition.

column3: A 2-year-old male is brought to the pediatrician's office by his parents for evaluation of delayed development. The child has a history of feeding difficulties and failure to thrive in infancy, and has not yet started speaking. On examination, the child has a small head circumference, arched eyebrows, long eyelashes, and a small upturned nose. He also has micrognathia, or a small jaw, and a thin upper lip. The child has limb abnormalities, including short arms and fingers with clinodactyly, or a curvature of the fingers towards the thumb. These features are suggestive of Cornelia de Lange syndrome, a genetic disorder characterized by developmental delay, intellectual disability, and distinctive facial features. Further evaluation will include genetic testing to confirm the diagnosis and monitoring for potential medical complications such as gastrointestinal issues, hearing and vision problems, and heart defects.
column10: A 28-year-old female with Cornelia de Lange syndrome presents to the clinic with complaints of abdominal pain and constipation for the past two days. She has a history of global developmental delay, intellectual disability, and dysmorphic facial features, including thin arched eyebrows, long eyelashes, and a small upturned nose. On examination, she has a short stature, microcephaly, and limb abnormalities, including thin and curved fingers. Abdominal examination reveals distension and tenderness in the left lower quadrant. A CT scan confirms the presence of a sigmoid volvulus, which requires immediate surgical intervention. The patient is at increased risk of gastrointestinal complications due to structural abnormalities and dysmotility associated with Cornelia de Lange syndrome.

column3: A 4-year-old girl presents to the pediatrician's office with severe limb deformities. Her parents report that she has always had difficulty walking and that her joints often appear swollen. Physical examination reveals short stature, scoliosis, and clubfoot. The child's fingers are short and stubby, and her knees and hips are severely restricted in motion. The doctor suspects Diastrophic dysplasia, a rare genetic disorder that affects the development of bone and cartilage. Further testing confirms the diagnosis. The child is referred to a specialist for ongoing care and management of her condition.
column10: A 27-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of chronic joint pain and stiffness. She reports having short stature since childhood and difficulty walking long distances. Physical examination reveals a height of 4 feet 3 inches, with a disproportionate shortening of the limbs. The patient also has a spinal curvature, a small chest, and a cleft palate. Radiographic imaging confirms the diagnosis of Diastrophic dysplasia, a rare genetic disorder that affects bone and cartilage development. The patient is referred for genetic counseling and offered pain management options to improve her quality of life.

column2: Change in presentation related to age
column3: A 6-month-old female infant was brought to the pediatrician by her parents due to the presence of rash and blisters on her skin. The rash was initially noted on the scalp and gradually spread to other parts of the body, including the trunk and extremities. The blisters eventually ruptured, leaving behind hyperpigmented macules that appeared as streaks or swirls. The infant had normal developmental milestones, but ophthalmologic examination revealed retinal detachment in the right eye. A diagnosis of Incontinentia pigmenti was made based on the characteristic skin lesions and ocular involvement. Further genetic testing confirmed a mutation in the IKBKG gene. The parents were counseled on the potential complications of the disease, including dental abnormalities, neurological deficits, and increased risk of infections. Follow-up appointments with an ophthalmologist and dermatologist were scheduled to monitor for any progression of the disease.
column10: A 32-year-old female presents with a history of recurrent blistering and hyperpigmented lesions over her body, which started in infancy. She also reports having dental abnormalities, vision loss, and hearing impairment. On examination, linear hyperpigmented streaks are seen on her skin, along with vesicles and scars. Dental examination reveals hypodontia and peg-shaped teeth. Ophthalmological examination shows retinal detachment, and audiometry reveals sensorineural hearing loss. A diagnosis of Incontinentia pigmenti is suspected based on the classic clinical features. A genetic test confirms the diagnosis of a mutation in the IKBKG gene. The patient is referred to a multidisciplinary team for management, including regular ophthalmological and audiological monitoring, dental care, and genetic counseling for future pregnancies.

column3: A 3-year-old boy presents with a history of developmental delay, intellectual disability, and abnormal facial features. On examination, the child has a small head circumference, low-set ears, a wide and flat nose, a small mouth with a protruding tongue, and multiple digital anomalies such as polydactyly, syndactyly, and brachydactyly. The child also has a history of recurrent respiratory tract infections and feeding difficulties due to a cleft palate. Based on these clinical features, the child is diagnosed with Orofaciodigital syndrome type 1, a rare genetic disorder that affects the development of the face, oral cavity, and extremities. Further genetic testing is recommended to confirm the diagnosis and to provide appropriate management and genetic counseling for the family.
column10: A 29-year-old male presents to the clinic with craniofacial abnormalities and digital anomalies. On physical examination, he has a high-arched palate, cleft lip and palate, hypertelorism, and hypoplastic nose. He also has polydactyly of both hands and feet, with syndactyly of the third and fourth fingers. The patient reports hearing loss and speech delay since childhood. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of Orofaciodigital syndrome type 1. The patient is referred to a multidisciplinary team, including an otolaryngologist, audiologist, and speech therapist, for further evaluation and management.

column3: A 5-year-old boy presents to the clinic with bilateral ectrodactyly (missing fingers and toes), sparse hair, and a cleft lip and palate. The child's parents report recurrent infections in the respiratory and urinary tract, as well as hearing loss. On physical exam, the child has dry and scaly skin with areas of hyperkeratosis, and a small pit in the lower eyelid. The child is diagnosed with EEC syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by ectodermal dysplasia, ectrodactyly, and cleft lip and palate. The child is referred to a multidisciplinary team for further evaluation and management of potential complications, including hearing loss and recurrent infections.
column10: A 32-year-old male presents to the clinic with a history of ectrodactyly, ectodermal dysplasia, and cleft lip and palate. He reports having dry skin, sparse hair, and missing teeth. He has a history of recurrent infections and has been diagnosed with hearing loss. On physical examination, he has a cleft lip and palate, missing fingers and toes, and thin, dry skin. His ears appear small and malformed, and he has a high-pitched voice. His teeth are missing or malformed, and his nails are thin and brittle. A diagnosis of EEC syndrome is made based on his clinical features. Further evaluation is done to assess for any associated anomalies and to provide appropriate management and genetic counseling.

column3: A 4-year-old child presents to the pediatrician with short stature, short limbs, and a narrow chest. The child also has a heart murmur and extra fingers on each hand. The child's parents report that the child has had difficulty breathing and eating, and has had frequent respiratory infections. The child is diagnosed with Ellis Van Creveld syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by skeletal abnormalities, congenital heart defects, and polydactyly. The pediatrician refers the child to a geneticist for further evaluation and management.
column10: Mrs. Johnson is a 32-year-old woman who presents to the clinic with short stature, polydactyly, and dental abnormalities. She reports that she has experienced difficulty breathing and shortness of breath with exertion. Upon examination, she is found to have a narrow chest, a heart murmur, and clubbing of the fingers. X-rays reveal a severe deformity of the chest wall and shortening of the long bones. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of Ellis Van Creveld syndrome. She is referred to a specialist for further management of her cardiac and respiratory symptoms.

column3: A 6-year-old boy presents to the dentist with complaints of tooth sensitivity and discoloration. On examination, the dentist finds that the boy's teeth have a grayish-brown color and are translucent at the tips. The boy's teeth also have an abnormal shape and structure, with bulbous crowns and short roots. The dentist suspects that the boy may have Dentin dysplasia type I, which is confirmed by radiographs that show obliteration of the pulp chamber and root canals. The dentist explains to the boy's parents that the condition is genetic and that the boy may require extensive dental treatment, including root canals and crowns, to preserve his teeth. The dentist also recommends that the boy's siblings and other family members undergo dental screening for Dentin dysplasia type I.
column10: Mr. Smith, a 35-year-old male, presents with a chief complaint of severe tooth pain in multiple teeth. On examination, he has generalized thinning of the enamel and bulbous crowns with short roots. Additionally, he has a history of multiple failed root canal treatments, and his teeth are extremely sensitive to hot and cold temperatures. Radiographs reveal obliteration of pulp chambers and root canals with a characteristic "shell" appearance. Further evaluation reveals that Mr. Smith has Dentin dysplasia type I, a rare genetic disorder characterized by abnormal dentin formation. Treatment options are limited, and extraction of affected teeth may be necessary to alleviate pain and prevent infection.

column2: Change in presentation related to age
column3: A 6-year-old boy presented to the clinic with a history of delayed motor milestones and progressive muscle weakness. His parents reported that he had difficulty climbing stairs and getting up from a sitting position. On examination, the child had scapular winging, contractures of the elbows and ankles, and weakness of the proximal muscles. He also had a family history of muscular dystrophy, with his maternal uncle and grandfather both affected. Genetic testing revealed a mutation in the emerin gene, confirming a diagnosis of X-linked Emery-Dreifuss muscular dystrophy. The child was referred to a neuromuscular specialist for ongoing management and support.
column10: John is a 35-year-old male who has a history of muscle weakness and wasting. He reports difficulty with walking, climbing stairs, and lifting objects. He also has experienced cardiac symptoms, including palpitations and shortness of breath. His family history is significant for muscular dystrophy, as his mother's brother was diagnosed with the condition. Upon examination, John has a waddling gait, scapular winging, and weakened grip strength. His EKG shows atrial fibrillation and conduction abnormalities. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of X-linked Emery-Dreifuss muscular dystrophy.

column3: A 5-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician with complaints of frequent falls and difficulty walking. On examination, he is noted to have short stature with disproportionately short limbs, a flattened facial profile, and a prominent forehead. X-rays reveal abnormalities of the spine and hip joints consistent with spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia congenita. The child's parents report a family history of similar features in other family members. The pediatrician refers the child to a geneticist for further evaluation and management.
column10: A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of chronic back pain and difficulty walking. He reports a history of short stature and joint stiffness since childhood. On physical examination, he has a disproportionately short stature with short limbs and a barrel-shaped chest. His spine is rigid and limited in range of motion with decreased lumbar lordosis. X-ray of the spine shows flattened vertebral bodies with irregular end plates and narrowed intervertebral disc spaces. The patient is diagnosed with Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia congenita, a rare genetic disorder characterized by abnormal bone growth, short stature, and spinal deformities. The patient is referred to a specialist for further management and monitoring of the condition.

column3: A 7-year-old child presents with thick, scaly, hyperkeratotic plaques on the palms and soles. The plaques extend to the dorsal surfaces of the hands and feet and are associated with erythema, foul odor, and pain. The child reports difficulty walking due to the severity of the plaques on the soles. The family history is notable for similar skin lesions in the mother and older siblings. The diagnosis of Mal de Meleda is suspected and confirmed by genetic testing, revealing a mutation in the ARS-B gene.
column10: A 32-year-old female presents with thickened, scaly, hyperkeratotic plaques on the palms, soles, and periungual regions of the fingers and toes, which have been present since childhood. She reports a family history of similar skin findings. The lesions are asymptomatic but cosmetically bothersome. Physical exam reveals diffuse, yellowish hyperkeratosis with well-defined borders and accentuation over the creases of the skin. There is no nail deformity or other systemic involvement. Biopsy confirms the diagnosis of Mal de Meleda. The patient is referred for genetic counseling and advised on regular skin care to prevent infections and complications.

column2: Change in presentation related to age
column3: A 6-month-old male infant is brought to the emergency department by his parents with lethargy and poor feeding. The child was born full-term and had normal development until recently. On examination, the infant appears weak and has low muscle tone. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated liver enzymes, low blood sugar, and elevated levels of creatine kinase. A genetic test confirms the diagnosis of Mitochondrial trifunctional protein deficiency. The child is started on a high-fat, low-carbohydrate diet and receives supportive care. However, despite treatment, the infant's condition deteriorates, and he dies within a week.
column10: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe muscle weakness and myalgia. He reports a history of recurrent episodes of muscle pain and fatigue after exertion. He also describes experiencing lightheadedness and syncope during physical activity. On examination, he demonstrates proximal muscle weakness and elevated creatine kinase levels. Further investigations reveal a deficiency in the mitochondrial trifunctional protein. The patient is diagnosed with Mitochondrial trifunctional protein deficiency, a rare genetic disorder that impairs the body's ability to break down certain fats for energy production. Treatment involves a low-fat diet, avoidance of fasting, and supplementation with medium-chain triglycerides.

column3: A 6-month-old male infant is brought to the pediatrician with facial abnormalities and difficulty breathing. On physical examination, the infant has craniosynostosis, a flattened midface, and bulging eyes. The child's fingers and toes are also fused together. The pediatrician suspects Pfeiffer syndrome and refers the infant to a craniofacial specialist for further evaluation and management. Imaging studies reveal premature fusion of the skull bones, which is causing pressure on the brain and hindering normal development. The child requires surgery to correct the craniosynostosis and manage the other associated anomalies.
column10: A 32-year-old male presents with multiple craniofacial abnormalities including a small head circumference, bulging eyes, a flattened mid-face, and a small jaw. He also reports difficulty breathing due to narrow air passages and recurrent ear infections. Physical examination reveals craniosynostosis, or premature fusion of the skull bones, and syndactyly, or fusion of the fingers and toes. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Pfeiffer syndrome, a rare genetic disorder that affects the development of the skull, hands, and feet. The patient is referred to a multidisciplinary team of specialists, including a craniofacial surgeon and a genetic counselor, for further management and counseling on the potential risks of inheritance for future children.

column3: A 10-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of weakness in both legs. His family reports that he has had similar episodes in the past, lasting for several hours before spontaneously resolving. The patient also reports experiencing occasional muscle cramps and palpitations. Physical exam reveals decreased strength in both legs with intact sensation and reflexes. Blood work shows low potassium levels (2.5 mmol/L). Based on these findings, the patient is diagnosed with hypokalemic periodic paralysis. The patient is started on potassium supplementation and advised to avoid triggers such as high carbohydrate meals and strenuous exercise. Follow-up with a neurologist is recommended for further management and monitoring.
column10: A 34-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of muscle weakness in his arms and legs. He reports having similar episodes in the past, but they usually resolve within a few hours. On physical examination, he has profound weakness in his proximal muscles with intact sensation and reflexes. His serum potassium level is found to be low at 2.5 mEq/L. He is diagnosed with Hypokalemic periodic paralysis, a rare genetic disorder characterized by sudden episodes of muscle weakness and low levels of potassium in the blood. Treatment with intravenous potassium is initiated, and the patient's symptoms rapidly improve.

column3: Sara is a 5-year-old girl who was referred to a pediatrician due to recurrent respiratory tract infections, growth retardation, and developmental delay. She has a history of frequent episodes of pneumonia and otitis media since early childhood. Her parents also report that she is smaller in size compared to her peers and has difficulty with fine motor skills such as holding a pencil. Physical examination reveals a small head circumference and a high-pitched voice. Laboratory investigations show a low white blood cell count and lymphocyte count. A genetic test confirms the diagnosis of Nijmegen breakage syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by impaired DNA repair mechanisms. The most important clinical feature of this condition is the increased susceptibility to infections due to defective immune function. Additionally, patients with Nijmegen breakage syndrome have an increased risk of developing cancer, particularly lymphomas, due to the accumulation of DNA damage. Early diagnosis and management of infections are crucial for the management of this condition.
column10: A 32-year-old male presents to the clinic with a history of recurrent respiratory infections and poor growth since childhood. He reports having several episodes of pneumonia and bronchitis in the past year, requiring hospitalization each time. On physical exam, he appears small for his age and has a prominent nasal bridge, microcephaly, and a high-pitched voice. His lymph nodes are enlarged, and he has an erythematous rash on his face. Laboratory studies reveal a low white blood cell count and low immunoglobulin levels. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Nijmegen breakage syndrome. The patient is referred to an immunologist for further management and monitoring of his immune system.

column3: A 4-year-old male child presented with a history of progressive developmental delay, ataxia, and dysarthria. He had difficulty walking and frequently fell down. The parents also reported a decline in his cognitive abilities, with difficulty in learning new concepts and memorizing simple things. On examination, the child had hepatosplenomegaly, vertical supranuclear gaze palsy, and tremors. Further investigations revealed abnormal lipid metabolism with elevated levels of cholesterol and sphingomyelin in the blood. Genetic testing confirmed the diagnosis of Niemann-Pick disease type C. The child was started on supportive therapy, including physical therapy and speech therapy, and was referred to a specialist center for management.
column10: John is a 32-year-old man who presents with progressive neurological symptoms. He has a history of developmental delay and learning difficulties in childhood. On examination, he has vertical supranuclear gaze palsy, ataxia, dysarthria, and dystonia. He also has hepatosplenomegaly and hyperlipidemia. MRI brain shows diffuse white matter abnormalities, and a skin biopsy shows lipid-laden cells. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Niemann-Pick disease type C.

column3: A 7-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a history of progressive muscle weakness and difficulty walking. His parents report that he has been experiencing frequent falls and has trouble getting up from a sitting position. Physical examination reveals bilateral weakness in the quadriceps and hamstrings, and he is unable to walk on his heels or toes. Creatine kinase levels are elevated, and a muscle biopsy shows evidence of muscle fiber atrophy and rimmed vacuoles. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of GNE myopathy, a rare autosomal recessive disorder that affects muscle function and leads to progressive muscle weakness. The child is referred to a neuromuscular specialist for ongoing management and support.
column10: Mrs. X is a 38-year-old female who presents with a gradual onset of muscle weakness and difficulty walking for the past 5 years. She reports difficulty climbing stairs, getting up from a seated position, and has noticed weakness in her arms. She has a positive family history of muscle weakness, with her mother and maternal aunt having similar symptoms. On examination, Mrs. X has significant muscle atrophy in her thighs and forearms, and she struggles to lift her arms above her head or stand up from a chair without assistance. She has a waddling gait and is unable to walk on her heels or toes. Laboratory tests reveal elevated creatine kinase levels and genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of GNE myopathy.

column3: John is a 4-year-old boy who has been experiencing developmental delays and frequent respiratory infections. He also has a small head and short stature. On examination, his face appears coarse with a prominent forehead, a flat nose bridge, and a large tongue. He has a thickened skin and joint stiffness, particularly in his hands and fingers. His parents also report that he has been experiencing hearing loss and frequent urinary tract infections. John is diagnosed with Mucopolysaccharidosis type 1, a rare genetic disorder characterized by the deficiency of an enzyme that breaks down complex sugars. This results in the accumulation of these sugars in the body leading to a variety of symptoms including skeletal abnormalities, developmental delays, and organ dysfunction.
column10: A 32-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of joint pain and stiffness, difficulty walking and frequent respiratory infections. On examination, the patient has coarse facial features, a short neck, and a prominent forehead. His hands are enlarged with thickened, stiff fingers. The patient reports a history of developmental delay and was diagnosed with mucopolysaccharidosis type 1 (MPS 1) in childhood. The diagnosis was confirmed with genetic testing that revealed a deficiency in the enzyme alpha-L-iduronidase. The patient's symptoms have progressively worsened over time, and he reports difficulty with daily activities due to joint pain and stiffness. Further evaluation with imaging studies reveals evidence of spinal cord compression and degenerative joint disease. The patient is started on enzyme replacement therapy and referred to a specialist for further management.

column3: A 2-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician with developmental delays and dysmorphic features. The child has a small head circumference and a smooth, shiny forehead with a prominent forehead ridge. On physical exam, the child has a high-arched palate, widely spaced eyes, and a small jaw. The child has hypotonia and difficulty with motor skills such as sitting and walking. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Miller-Dieker syndrome, a rare genetic disorder caused by a deletion of genetic material on chromosome 17. The pediatrician discusses the importance of early intervention and supportive therapies to help the child reach their full potential. The child is referred to a team of specialists for ongoing care and management.
column10: A 27-year-old male presents with developmental delay, intellectual disability, and frequent seizures since childhood. On physical examination, the patient has a small head circumference, widely spaced eyes, and a prominent forehead. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain shows a smooth brain surface with no gyri or sulci, consistent with lissencephaly, a hallmark feature of Miller-Dieker syndrome. The patient's family history is negative for similar neurological conditions. The patient is managed with antiepileptic medications and receives regular neurodevelopmental assessments.

column2: Change in presentation related to age
column3: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician with delayed developmental milestones, irritability, and stiffness. The parents report that the child has been experiencing difficulty with feeding and has lost weight. On examination, the infant has hypertonicity, exaggerated reflexes, and poor head control. There is also evidence of optic atrophy. The pediatrician suspects Krabbe disease and orders genetic testing. The results confirm the diagnosis, and the child is referred to a specialist for further management.
column10: Mrs. X is a 34-year-old woman who presents with a history of progressive muscle weakness, difficulty speaking, and impaired vision. Her symptoms initially started three years ago when she experienced difficulty walking and maintaining balance. Over time, her symptoms progressed to difficulty speaking and swallowing. She reports that her vision has also been affected, and she experiences frequent falls due to her poor motor coordination. On physical examination, Mrs. X has generalized muscle weakness with decreased reflexes. Her speech is slurred, and she has difficulty with articulation. Her visual acuity is decreased, and she has nystagmus on lateral gaze. MRI of the brain shows diffuse white matter abnormalities consistent with Krabbe disease.

column1: Glycogen storage disease due to glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency
column3: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents due to frequent episodes of hypoglycemia, lethargy, and vomiting. The child has a history of delayed growth and development and has experienced multiple hospitalizations for similar symptoms. On physical exam, the child appears thin and pale with hepatomegaly and an enlarged spleen. Laboratory tests reveal low blood glucose levels, elevated liver enzymes, and increased lactate levels. Further evaluation shows a deficiency in glucose-6-phosphatase activity, confirming the diagnosis of glycogen storage disease due to glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency. The child is started on a high-carbohydrate diet and given frequent glucose supplements to prevent hypoglycemia. Long-term management includes regular monitoring of blood glucose levels, liver function, and growth and development.
column10: A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of frequent episodes of hypoglycemia, fatigue, and muscle weakness. He reports a history of multiple hospitalizations for severe hypoglycemia and lactic acidosis. The patient also reports difficulty gaining weight despite a high-calorie diet. On physical examination, the patient appears thin and frail with muscle wasting. Laboratory tests reveal an elevated lactate level, low glucose level, and an elevated liver enzyme level. A liver biopsy confirms the diagnosis of glycogen storage disease due to glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency. The patient is started on a high-carbohydrate, low-fat, and protein diet and is advised to avoid fasting. He is also started on treatment with glucose infusions during episodes of hypoglycemia.

column3: A 5-year-old male presents to the pediatrician with complaints of decreased visual acuity and a history of joint stiffness and short stature. On examination, the child is noted to have a short stature with a disproportionate trunk and limbs. The child has a barrel-shaped chest, and his fingers are short and stubby with limited joint mobility. Ophthalmological examination reveals microspherophakia, high myopia, and ectopia lentis. The child's clinical presentation is consistent with Weill-Marchesani syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by short stature, joint stiffness, and ocular abnormalities such as microspherophakia and ectopia lentis.
column10: A 35-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of blurred vision and eye discomfort. On examination, he is noted to have short stature, a stubby nose, and a high-pitched voice. His ophthalmic exam reveals microspherophakia, a shallow anterior chamber, and a dislocated lens. He is diagnosed with Weill-Marchesani syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by short stature, brachydactyly, joint stiffness, and ocular abnormalities including microspherophakia and lens dislocation. The patient is referred for surgical intervention to address his ocular symptoms and genetic counseling to discuss the risks of passing the condition on to future generations.

column1: Severe combined immunodeficiency due to complete RAG1/2 deficiency
column3: A 6-month-old male infant was admitted to the hospital with recurrent infections including pneumonia, otitis media, and thrush. The patient was born full term with no complications during delivery and had no significant medical history. Physical examination revealed a pale, lethargic child with poor weight gain. Laboratory tests showed severe lymphopenia with absent T and B cells and low immunoglobulin levels. Genetic testing revealed a complete RAG1/2 deficiency, confirming the diagnosis of severe combined immunodeficiency. The patient was immediately started on intravenous immunoglobulin and prophylactic antibiotics while awaiting further management, including hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.
column10: John is a 35-year-old male who presents to the clinic with a history of recurrent infections since childhood. He has had several episodes of pneumonia, sinusitis, and ear infections, which have required hospitalization and intravenous antibiotics. He has also experienced chronic diarrhea and weight loss. On examination, he appears thin and pale, with multiple scars from surgical procedures and intravenous lines. His lymph nodes are not palpable, and he has no tonsils or adenoids. Laboratory tests reveal severe lymphopenia and absent T and B cells. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of severe combined immunodeficiency due to complete RAG1/2 deficiency. John is referred for a bone marrow transplant as soon as possible to prevent further infections and improve his quality of life.

column3: A 6-month-old male infant presented to the emergency department with poor feeding, vomiting, lethargy, and a fruity odor in his breath. The infant was born full-term with an uneventful delivery and had been feeding well until 2 days ago when he developed these symptoms. On examination, the infant appeared lethargic and had a mild fever. There was evidence of dehydration and metabolic acidosis. Laboratory investigations revealed elevated levels of isovaleric acid in the blood and urine. The diagnosis of Isovaleric acidemia was made. The infant was started on a low-protein diet, and carnitine and glycine supplementation were initiated. The infant responded well to the treatment and was discharged after a few days with regular follow-up appointments with a metabolic specialist.
column10: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with lethargy and confusion. She has a history of recurrent episodes of vomiting and a fruity odor from her sweat and urine. On examination, she is found to have a decreased level of consciousness and a fruity odor is noted. Laboratory investigations reveal an elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis, hyperammonemia, and elevated levels of isovaleryl carnitine. The patient is diagnosed with Isovaleric acidemia, an inherited metabolic disorder that causes the body to be unable to break down the amino acid leucine, leading to a buildup of isovaleric acid. Treatment is initiated with intravenous fluids, glucose, and carnitine supplementation, resulting in an improvement in the patient's clinical status.

column3: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents with complaints of severe abdominal pain and vomiting. He has a history of easy bruising and joint hypermobility. On examination, he has a pulsatile abdominal mass and a tender abdomen. CT scan reveals a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. The child is diagnosed with Vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome due to the family history of similar symptoms and genetic testing results. He undergoes emergency surgery to repair the aneurysm and is closely monitored for possible complications such as arterial rupture or dissection. The most important clinical features of this condition are arterial and organ rupture, easy bruising, joint hypermobility, and a positive family history.
column10: A 35-year-old male presents with a history of recurrent arterial ruptures, including aortic dissection, carotid artery dissection, and mesenteric artery aneurysm. He also reports a family history of similar vascular events. Physical examination reveals thin and translucent skin, visible veins, and extensive ecchymoses. Joint hypermobility is also noted, with a Beighton score of 7/9. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. The patient is advised to avoid strenuous physical activities and to receive regular monitoring of his vascular system due to the high risk of life-threatening complications.

column3: A 7-year-old boy was referred to a pediatric neurologist due to progressive muscle weakness and difficulty in running and climbing stairs. He had a history of delayed motor milestones and frequent falls. On examination, he had proximal muscle weakness in both upper and lower limbs, with a waddling gait and difficulty in standing up from a squatting position. There was no muscle wasting or fasciculations. His creatine kinase (CK) levels were elevated, and electromyography (EMG) showed myopathic changes. Genetic testing revealed a mutation in the Calpain-3 gene, confirming the diagnosis of Calpain-3-related limb-girdle muscular dystrophy R1. The family was provided with genetic counseling and supportive management, including physiotherapy and occupational therapy.
column10: A 32-year-old male presents with a history of progressive muscle weakness and difficulty walking. He reports that he noticed difficulty climbing stairs and getting up from a seated position over the past few years. On physical examination, he has proximal muscle weakness in his lower limbs, with a waddling gait and difficulty standing on tiptoes. He also has weakness in his upper limbs, particularly in the shoulder girdle muscles. His reflexes are normal, and he does not have any sensory deficits. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the calpain-3 gene, confirming a diagnosis of Calpain-3-related limb-girdle muscular dystrophy R1.

column1: Glycogen storage disease due to liver phosphorylase kinase deficiency
column3: A 5-year-old male child presents to the emergency department with recurrent episodes of hypoglycemia, lethargy, and vomiting. The child's parents report that he has a history of frequent episodes of fatigue and muscle weakness, especially during times of fasting or physical activity. On examination, the child appears pale and is noted to have hepatomegaly. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated liver enzymes and a low blood glucose level. Further investigations reveal a deficiency in liver phosphorylase kinase, leading to a diagnosis of Glycogen storage disease type IX. The child is started on a high-carbohydrate diet and advised to avoid fasting. The child is referred to a metabolic specialist for further management.
column10: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of fatigue, weakness, and intermittent episodes of hypoglycemia for the past few months. He reports having a low carbohydrate diet to avoid hypoglycemic episodes, but symptoms have persisted. On physical examination, he appears thin and malnourished with mild hepatomegaly. Laboratory investigations show hypoglycemia, elevated liver enzymes, and lactic acidosis. A liver biopsy reveals glycogen accumulation with absent or reduced phosphorylase kinase activity, confirming the diagnosis of Glycogen storage disease due to liver phosphorylase kinase deficiency. The patient is started on a high carbohydrate diet, and enzyme replacement therapy is initiated to manage the condition.

column3: A 2-year-old male child is brought to the pediatrician's office for evaluation of developmental delays and frequent episodes of vomiting. The child's mother reports that he has always been slower to meet developmental milestones than his older siblings. On physical examination, the child appears thin and malnourished, with muscle wasting and weakness. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of glutaric acid in the urine and blood, suggesting a diagnosis of Glutaryl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency. Further genetic testing confirms the diagnosis. The child is started on a low-protein diet and carnitine supplementation, and referred to a metabolic specialist for ongoing management.
column10: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department with acute encephalopathy. He has a history of recurrent episodes of metabolic decompensation since childhood, including vomiting, lethargy, and seizures. He is also noted to have macrocephaly and developmental delays. Laboratory studies reveal elevated levels of glutaric acid, 3-hydroxyglutaric acid, and glutaryl carnitine, consistent with a diagnosis of Glutaryl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency. Urgent treatment with intravenous glucose, hydration, and carnitine supplementation is initiated, and the patient is transferred to the intensive care unit for further management of his metabolic crisis. Long-term management involves strict adherence to a low-protein diet and regular monitoring of metabolic parameters to prevent future episodes of decompensation and neurologic damage.

column3: A 3-day-old male infant is brought to the emergency department by his parents with lethargy, poor feeding, and vomiting. The baby was born full-term, with an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. The mother has no significant medical history, and the pregnancy was uneventful. On examination, the baby appears dehydrated and jaundiced. His vital signs are within normal limits. Laboratory studies show elevated ammonia levels, metabolic acidosis, and anion gap. Further metabolic workup reveals increased levels of argininosuccinic acid in the blood and urine, confirming a diagnosis of Argininosuccinic aciduria. The baby is started on a low-protein diet, sodium benzoate, and arginine supplementation, and is referred to a metabolic specialist for long-term management.
column10: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department with confusion and lethargy. He reports a history of recurrent episodes of vomiting, poor appetite, and fatigue for the past few years. On physical examination, he appears pale and dehydrated. His blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, and his heart rate is 110 beats per minute. Laboratory results reveal elevated ammonia levels, metabolic acidosis, and hyperammonemia. Further investigation shows elevated levels of argininosuccinic acid in the urine, confirming a diagnosis of argininosuccinic aciduria. The patient is started on a low protein diet and intravenous infusion of arginine and citrulline, and referred to a specialist for long-term management.

column3: A 3-month-old male infant presents with jaundice and pale stools since birth. The parents report that the child has been lethargic and not feeding well. Physical examination reveals icteric sclera and skin. Laboratory investigations show elevated levels of unconjugated bilirubin and normal liver function tests. The child is diagnosed with Crigler-Najjar syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by impaired bilirubin metabolism due to a deficiency in the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase. The child is started on phototherapy and phenobarbital to increase bilirubin conjugation. Long-term management will involve strict adherence to phototherapy and liver transplantation may be considered in severe cases.
column10: John is a 28-year-old male who presents to the clinic with a history of jaundice since birth. He reports that his skin and eyes have a yellowish tint and that he has experienced occasional episodes of abdominal pain. John states that he has never been able to tolerate alcohol or certain medications due to liver problems. His medical history is significant for Crigler-Najjar syndrome, a rare inherited condition that affects bilirubin metabolism. Physical examination reveals scleral icterus, and laboratory tests demonstrate elevated unconjugated bilirubin levels. John is started on phototherapy to manage his symptoms and is advised to avoid medications that could worsen his liver function.

column1: Kyphoscoliotic Ehlers-Danlos syndrome due to lysyl hydroxylase 1 deficiency
column3: A 7-year-old girl presents to the pediatrician with frequent joint dislocations, chronic pain, and difficulty breathing. She has a history of scoliosis and a noticeable curvature of the spine, along with hypermobility of her joints. Her skin is also fragile and bruises easily. The pediatrician orders genetic testing, which reveals a diagnosis of Kyphoscoliotic Ehlers-Danlos syndrome due to lysyl hydroxylase 1 deficiency. This rare form of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome affects collagen production, leading to weakened connective tissues in the body. The child is referred to a geneticist and a team of specialists to manage her complex medical needs, including respiratory support, pain management, and physical therapy to help strengthen her muscles and prevent further joint dislocations.
column10: A 34-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of chronic joint pain, recurrent dislocations, and easy bruising. He has a history of multiple fractures and has been diagnosed with scoliosis. On physical examination, he has hypermobile joints and a marked kyphoscoliosis. His skin is hyperextensible and translucent, with visible veins. The patient reports a family history of similar symptoms and a sibling with a diagnosis of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Kyphoscoliotic Ehlers-Danlos syndrome due to lysyl hydroxylase 1 deficiency. The patient is advised to avoid high-impact activities and is referred to a physical therapist for exercises to improve joint stability.

column3: A 5-year-old male presents to the pediatrician with a history of frequent skin infections and abnormal sweating patterns. On examination, he has sparse, fine hair on his scalp, eyebrows, and eyelashes. His skin appears dry and scaly, especially on the palms and soles, and he has small bumps on his face. His teeth are small and pointed, and his nails are thin and brittle. The child's family history reveals that his father and grandfather also have a similar condition. Based on these clinical features, a diagnosis of Hidrotic ectodermal dysplasia is suspected. Further evaluation with genetic testing confirms the diagnosis. The child is counseled on the need for regular skin and dental care, and the importance of early intervention to prevent complications such as hearing loss, vision problems, and respiratory infections.
column10: John is a 32-year-old male who presents to the clinic with a history of recurrent skin infections and dental problems since childhood. He also complains of excessive sweating and heat intolerance. On examination, he has sparse hair on his scalp, eyebrows, and eyelashes, and his skin appears thin and dry. He has hypodontia, with only a few teeth present, and those that are present are malformed. His nails are thin and brittle, and he has a reduced sense of taste and smell. Based on these findings, a diagnosis of Hidrotic ectodermal dysplasia is suspected.

column3: A 6-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with weakness and muscle pain after a 30-minute bike ride. He has a history of recurrent episodes of muscle pain, cramping, and weakness during prolonged exercise or fasting. On examination, he is found to have muscle weakness and tenderness, with elevated levels of creatine kinase. The patient's family history is notable for a sister who had similar symptoms and was diagnosed with Carnitine palmitoyltransferase II deficiency. A blood test confirms the diagnosis, and the patient is started on a low-fat, high-carbohydrate diet. The patient is also advised to avoid fasting and prolonged exercise to prevent future episodes.
column10: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department complaining of muscle pain and weakness after a strenuous workout. He reports a history of recurrent episodes of muscle pain and weakness during exercise, which usually resolve within a few hours. However, this episode has been ongoing for the past 24 hours and he has noticed dark urine. On examination, he has diffuse muscle tenderness and weakness, with elevated creatine kinase levels. The patient's medical history is significant for episodes of rhabdomyolysis and a family history of unexplained muscle pain and weakness. Further investigations reveal a Carnitine palmitoyltransferase II deficiency.

column3: A 4-year-old child was brought to the clinic with complaints of constipation and recurrent urinary tract infections. The child had a history of anorectal malformation and underwent surgical repair at birth. On physical examination, the child had a sacral dimple and a small anal opening. Imaging studies revealed a presacral mass and tethered cord syndrome. The child was diagnosed with Currarino syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by the triad of sacral anomalies, anorectal malformation, and presacral mass. The child was referred to a pediatric surgeon for further evaluation and management.
column10: Mrs. Smith, a 42-year-old woman, presented to the clinic with a history of chronic constipation, recurrent urinary tract infections, and lower back pain. She reported difficulty with bowel movements since childhood and had undergone several surgeries for anal stenosis and rectal prolapse. On examination, she had a sacral dimple, and an MRI revealed a presacral mass consistent with a teratoma. Genetic testing confirmed a diagnosis of Currarino syndrome. She was referred to a surgeon for resection of the teratoma and a colorectal specialist for management of her chronic constipation.

column3: A 6-month-old male infant is brought to the pediatrician by his parents with concerns about developmental delays. The child has not yet achieved head control and does not respond to loud noises. Upon examination, the pediatrician notes hypotonia, poor head control, and absent deep tendon reflexes. The child also has macrocephaly with a head circumference greater than the 99th percentile. MRI shows diffuse white matter abnormalities consistent with Canavan disease. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis. The parents are counseled on the progressive nature of the disease and the poor prognosis, with most children dying before the age of 10.
column10: Mr. Smith is a 30-year-old male who presented to the neurology clinic with developmental delay and a progressive decline in cognitive and motor function. He was diagnosed with Canavan disease based on genetic testing, which revealed a homozygous mutation in the aspartoacylase gene. On examination, he had hypotonia, spasticity, and hyperreflexia in all four limbs. He also had optic atrophy and nystagmus. His speech was severely impaired, and he was unable to communicate effectively. Brain MRI showed diffuse white matter abnormalities with increased T2 signal and decreased N-acetylaspartate (NAA) levels. Overall, the clinical presentation of Mr. Smith is consistent with Canavan disease, an autosomal recessive leukodystrophy characterized by severe neurologic impairment and progressive degeneration of white matter in the brain.

column3: A 7-year-old girl presents to the clinic with complaints of abdominal pain and vomiting after meals. She has a family history of hyperlipidemia and her parents report that she has had recurrent episodes of abdominal pain and pancreatitis since the age of 2. Physical examination reveals eruptive xanthomas on the trunk and limbs and hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory investigations show marked elevations in triglycerides, cholesterol, and lipoprotein lipase activity. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of Familial chylomicronemia syndrome. The child is started on a strict low-fat diet and lipid-lowering medication.
column10: John is a 35-year-old male who presents to the clinic with complaints of recurrent abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. He has a family history of lipid disorders, and his father died of a heart attack at the age of 45. On physical examination, he is obese with a BMI of 34 kg/m2 and has tenderness in the epigastric region. His laboratory workup shows elevated triglycerides of 2,500 mg/dL and a low-density lipoprotein (LDL) level of 120 mg/dL. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of Familial chylomicronemia syndrome. He is started on a low-fat diet, omega-3 fatty acid supplements, and fibrates to manage his lipid levels. Follow-up visits show gradual improvement in his symptoms and lipid levels.

column3: A 6-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent painful episodes on sun exposure. He reports that his skin becomes red, swollen, and itchy within minutes of being in the sun. The symptoms improve with cooling measures and avoidance of sunlight. On examination, the child has a rash on the exposed areas of his skin and shows evidence of sunburn. There are no signs of blistering or scarring. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated levels of protoporphyrin in the blood and stool. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of Autosomal erythropoietic protoporphyria. The child is advised to avoid direct sunlight and to use sunscreen, hats, and protective clothing when outdoors. He is also prescribed beta-carotene supplements and phototherapy to reduce the symptoms and prevent complications.
column10: A 35-year-old male presents to the dermatology clinic with a chief complaint of severe burning pain and redness on sun-exposed areas of his skin. He reports a history of recurrent episodes of painful photosensitivity since childhood, which has worsened over the years. He avoids sunlight as much as possible and wears protective clothing when outside. Physical examination reveals erythema, edema, and bullae on the dorsal hands and feet, ears, and nose, consistent with photosensitivity. Laboratory workup shows elevated levels of protoporphyrin in the blood and feces. A diagnosis of Autosomal erythropoietic protoporphyria is made, and the patient is advised to avoid sunlight exposure and use broad-spectrum sunscreens. He is referred to a specialist for further management.

column3: A 4-month-old male infant presents with vomiting, poor feeding, and jaundice. Physical examination reveals hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, and a distinctive cabbage-like odor. Laboratory tests show elevated serum tyrosine and methionine levels, as well as elevated urine succinylacetone levels. The infant is diagnosed with Tyrosinemia type 1 and started on a low-phenylalanine and tyrosine diet, as well as Nitisinone therapy. Repeat labs and clinical follow-up show improvement in liver function and growth.
column10: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and yellow discoloration of the skin and eyes. He reports having had similar episodes in the past that have resolved on their own. On further questioning, he reveals a history of developmental delay, intellectual disability, and a low-protein diet. Physical examination reveals hepatomegaly and splenomegaly. Further workup reveals elevated levels of tyrosine and its metabolites in the blood and urine, confirming a diagnosis of Tyrosinemia type 1. Treatment is initiated with nitisinone, a medication that blocks the production of toxic metabolites, and a low-protein diet is recommended to prevent further episodes. The patient is referred to a metabolic specialist for long-term management of his condition.

column3: Maria is a 4-year-old girl who was referred to a geneticist for evaluation due to facial abnormalities. Her parents reported that she was born with a small head and a flat midface. Upon examination, the geneticist noted that Maria had a prominent forehead, sunken eye sockets, and a beaked nose. She also had a small upper jaw and crowded teeth. Further evaluation revealed that Maria had hearing loss due to narrow ear canals and a small airway causing sleep apnea. She was diagnosed with Crouzon syndrome, a genetic disorder that affects the development of the skull and face. Maria will require a team of specialists including an ENT doctor for her hearing and breathing issues, an ophthalmologist for her vision, and a craniofacial surgeon for potential surgical interventions to improve her breathing and facial structure.
column10: Mrs. Smith is a 35-year-old woman with Crouzon syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by premature fusion of the skull bones leading to craniofacial abnormalities. She presents with severe headaches, visual disturbances, and difficulty with chewing and swallowing. On examination, she has a high forehead, shallow eye sockets, and protruding eyes (exophthalmos), leading to compression of the optic nerves and subsequent vision loss. Her midface is underdeveloped, leading to a small nose and a crowded mouth with dental malocclusion. She also has a cleft palate, which contributes to her difficulty with chewing and swallowing. These features of Crouzon syndrome can lead to a variety of complications, including obstructive sleep apnea, hearing loss, and increased intracranial pressure. Mrs. Smith will need comprehensive management by a multidisciplinary team, including neurosurgery, ophthalmology, otolaryngology, and dentistry, to prevent or manage these complications and improve her quality of life.

column3: A 10-year-old child presents to the clinic with concerns about their lack of menstruation. On examination, the child appears female and has a normal external genitalia. Further investigations reveal that the child has XY chromosomes and has a high testosterone level. The child's breasts have developed normally, and there is no palpable uterus or ovaries. A karyotype confirms the diagnosis of Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome. The child is referred to a specialist for further management and counseling regarding their gender identity.
column10: A 25-year-old individual presents to the clinic with primary amenorrhea and absence of breast development. The patient reports a history of undescended testes that were surgically removed during childhood. Physical examination reveals a tall stature, scant pubic and axillary hair, absence of a vaginal opening, and a small clitoral hood. Hormonal testing shows elevated testosterone and undetectable levels of estrogen. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of complete androgen insensitivity syndrome. The patient expresses concerns regarding infertility and gender identity. Counseling regarding fertility options and referral to a specialist in gender identity are initiated.

column3: Samantha is a 5-year-old girl who presents to the pediatric clinic with jaundice and severe itching. Her mother reports that Samantha has had recurrent episodes of diarrhea and abdominal pain for the past few months. Samantha is small for her age and has a characteristic facial appearance with a prominent forehead, deep-set eyes, and a pointed chin. On physical exam, Samantha has a systolic heart murmur and a liver palpable 4 cm below the costal margin. Lab work reveals elevated liver enzymes and a total serum bilirubin of 6 mg/dL. After further evaluation, Samantha is diagnosed with Alagille syndrome, a genetic disorder that affects multiple organ systems, including the liver, heart, and kidneys. The characteristic facial appearance, along with cholestasis (jaundice and severe itching), and cardiac abnormalities, are hallmarks of this condition. Samantha's recurrent episodes of diarrhea and abdominal pain are also common in Alagille syndrome due to malabsorption. The diagnosis is confirmed with genetic testing, which reveals mutations in the JAG1 gene. Samantha will require ongoing multidisciplinary care to manage her complex medical needs.
column10: Mr. X is a 30-year-old man who presented to the clinic with a history of jaundice, severe itching, and fatigue. He had a past medical history of Alagille syndrome, which was diagnosed in childhood. On examination, he had yellowish discoloration of the skin and sclera, and multiple small, irregularly shaped, and mildly elevated skin lesions on his upper and lower extremities. His liver was palpable and enlarged, and laboratory investigations revealed elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin levels. An abdominal ultrasound showed a small, shrunken liver with a paucity of intrahepatic bile ducts. A diagnosis of cholestatic liver disease due to Alagille syndrome was made, and he was started on ursodeoxycholic acid therapy. Follow-up appointments were scheduled for monitoring of his liver function and progression of his disease.

column1: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase deficiency
column3: A 6-year-old girl presents to the pediatric endocrinology clinic with ambiguous genitalia and early signs of puberty, including pubic hair growth and breast development. The patient's parents report a history of infertility, with multiple failed attempts at conceiving before the patient's birth. The patient's laboratory results reveal elevated levels of 17-hydroxyprogesterone and androstenedione, confirming a diagnosis of Congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase deficiency. The patient is started on glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid replacement therapy to manage her symptoms and prevent adrenal crisis. The medical team emphasizes the importance of long-term follow-up to monitor the patient's growth, development, and hormone levels.
column10: A 32-year-old female presents with a history of hirsutism, acne, and menstrual irregularities. She reports a history of early pubic hair development at the age of 6 and clitoral enlargement during puberty. On examination, she is noted to have hyperpigmentation of the skin in a sun-exposed distribution. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of 17-hydroxyprogesterone and androstenedione, and low levels of cortisol. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase deficiency. The patient is started on glucocorticoid replacement therapy and referred to an endocrinologist for further management.

column1: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 11-beta-hydroxylase deficiency
column3: A 5-year-old child is brought to the clinic by their parents due to concerns about their growth and development. The child is small for their age and has not yet begun to develop pubic hair. The child's blood pressure is elevated at 140/90 mmHg, and the parents report that the child has been experiencing episodes of vomiting and diarrhea. Upon further examination, the child is found to have an enlarged clitoris and fused labia. Lab tests reveal elevated levels of 17-hydroxyprogesterone and low levels of cortisol. These findings are consistent with Congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 11-beta-hydroxylase deficiency, a rare genetic disorder that affects the production of steroid hormones in the adrenal glands. The child is started on hormone replacement therapy and referred to an endocrinologist for further management.
column10: A 32-year-old female presents to the clinic with a history of irregular menstrual cycles, hirsutism, and acne. She reports difficulty conceiving and has been trying to conceive for the past year. Physical examination reveals a blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg, moderate hirsutism, and a masculine appearance. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated serum levels of 17-hydroxyprogesterone, testosterone, and dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate. A diagnosis of Congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 11-beta-hydroxylase deficiency is made. The patient is started on glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid replacement therapy, and her symptoms improve over time. Follow-up visits show a reduction in blood pressure and a regular menstrual cycle, and she conceives six months later.

column3: A 2-year-old male child was brought to the hospital by his parents with complaints of frequent fractures and difficulty in walking. The child had a history of multiple fractures since birth and was unable to walk without support. On physical examination, the child had short stature, wide-set eyes, and a prominent forehead. His bones were thickened, and he had a barrel-shaped chest. The child's laboratory investigations showed anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated serum alkaline phosphatase levels. The child was diagnosed with Autosomal recessive malignant osteopetrosis, a rare genetic disorder characterized by defective bone resorption leading to thickened bones, frequent fractures, and growth retardation.
