The diagnosis of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) due to adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency was confirmed by genetic testing. The patient was started on enzyme replacement therapy and underwent hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

column3: A 7-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a history of muscle weakness and difficulty walking. The parents report that he has been experiencing these symptoms for the past year and that they have progressively worsened over time. On examination, the child has marked weakness in the proximal muscles of the upper and lower extremities, with a waddling gait and difficulty getting up from a seated position. There is also evidence of joint contractures in the elbows, ankles, and neck. His creatine kinase levels are elevated, and genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Emery-Dreifuss muscular dystrophy. The child is referred to a specialist for further management and genetic counseling.
column10: A 35-year-old male presents with complaints of difficulty lifting his arms above his head and weakness in his lower limbs. He reports a family history of muscle weakness and cardiac abnormalities. On examination, the patient has scapular winging and contractures in the elbows, ankles, and neck. Muscle strength testing reveals weakness in the biceps, triceps, quadriceps, and tibialis anterior muscles. The patient also exhibits a shortened Achilles tendon and limited range of motion in the neck. An electrocardiogram shows an atrioventricular block. These findings are consistent with Emery-Dreifuss muscular dystrophy, a rare genetic disorder characterized by muscle weakness, joint contractures, and cardiac conduction defects. The patient is referred to a specialist for further evaluation and management.

column1: Laminin subunit alpha 2-related congenital muscular dystrophy
column2: Change in presentation related to age
column3: A 3-year-old male child presents with delayed motor milestones and difficulty in standing and walking. He has a waddling gait, frequent falls, and difficulty in climbing stairs. The child has muscle weakness and atrophy, especially in the lower limbs, and has a positive Gower's sign. The muscle biopsy shows reduced levels of laminin subunit alpha 2, confirming the diagnosis of Laminin subunit alpha 2-related congenital muscular dystrophy. The child also has respiratory insufficiency and is at an increased risk of developing scoliosis. The family history is negative for any neuromuscular disorders.
column10: A 32-year-old male presents to the clinic with a complaint of progressive muscle weakness since childhood. The patient reports difficulty with activities of daily living, such as walking, climbing stairs, and lifting objects. He has a history of delayed motor milestones and required a wheelchair for mobility since the age of 10. On examination, the patient has significant muscle wasting, particularly in the upper limbs and pelvic girdle. He has weakness in the neck flexors, shoulder girdle, and hip girdle muscles. Muscle biopsy reveals the presence of dystrophic changes with reduced staining for laminin alpha 2. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Laminin subunit alpha 2-related congenital muscular dystrophy.

column3: A 7-year-old male child presents with progressive weakness in his lower limbs, difficulty standing up from a sitting position, and frequent falls. He has been experiencing these symptoms for the past 2 years, and they have gradually worsened over time. On examination, there is significant muscle wasting and weakness in the proximal muscles of the lower limbs. The child also has a waddling gait and is unable to run or climb stairs without assistance. His creatine kinase levels are elevated, and genetic testing reveals a mutation in the Delta-sarcoglycan gene, confirming a diagnosis of Delta-sarcoglycan-related limb-girdle muscular dystrophy R6. The child is referred to a neuromuscular specialist for further management and genetic counseling.
column10: A 35-year-old male presents with progressive muscle weakness and difficulty in walking for the past 5 years. He reports difficulty in climbing stairs and getting up from a seated position. On examination, there is wasting of the proximal muscles of the upper and lower limbs. There is also weakness of the neck flexors, hip flexors, and knee extensors. Serum creatine kinase levels are significantly elevated. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the delta-sarcoglycan gene, confirming the diagnosis of Delta-sarcoglycan-related limb-girdle muscular dystrophy R6. The patient is referred to a neuromuscular specialist for further management.

column3: A 5-year-old child is brought to the clinic by his parents due to easy bruising and nosebleeds. The parents report that the child has always had a tendency to bruise easily, but recently they have noticed an increase in the frequency and severity of the bruising. They also report that the child has had several episodes of nosebleeds that have been difficult to control. Upon physical examination, the child is found to have multiple bruises of varying sizes and stages of healing, as well as petechiae on his legs. Laboratory testing reveals a low platelet count and normal coagulation studies. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of MYH9-related disease, a rare genetic disorder that affects platelet function and can lead to bleeding disorders and kidney problems. The child is referred to a hematologist for further evaluation and management.
column10: Mr. J is a 45-year-old man who presents to the clinic with a history of easy bruising and prolonged bleeding after minor injuries. He reports a family history of similar symptoms, with his mother and sister experiencing similar bleeding tendencies. On physical examination, he has scattered petechiae and ecchymoses over his arms and legs. Laboratory tests reveal a decreased platelet count and enlarged platelets on peripheral smear. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of MYH9-related disease, a rare genetic disorder that affects platelet function and can lead to bleeding and kidney problems. Mr. J is referred to a hematologist for further management and monitoring of his symptoms.

column3: A 6-month-old male infant was brought to the hospital with poor weight gain, vomiting, and diarrhea. The infant had been healthy at birth and had no significant family history. On physical examination, he appeared thin, with hepatosplenomegaly and a cherry-red spot on the retina. Laboratory tests revealed pancytopenia, elevated liver enzymes, and low levels of sphingomyelinase. MRI of the brain showed diffuse white matter abnormalities. A diagnosis of Infantile neurovisceral acid sphingomyelinase deficiency (Niemann-Pick disease type A) was suspected. The infant was started on supportive care and enzyme replacement therapy, but unfortunately, his condition continued to worsen, and he passed away at 9 months of age.
column10: A 35-year-old female patient presented to the clinic with a history of recurrent episodes of abdominal pain, diarrhea, and vomiting since childhood. She reported that her symptoms became more severe and frequent over the past year. On physical examination, her abdomen was distended, and there was hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory investigations revealed anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated liver enzymes. Genetic testing confirmed the diagnosis of infantile neurovisceral acid sphingomyelinase deficiency. The patient was started on enzyme replacement therapy, and her symptoms improved significantly. However, she was counseled about the chronic nature of the disease and the need for lifelong treatment.

column3: A 4-year-old male child is brought to the neurology clinic by his parents with the chief complaint of delayed motor milestones. On examination, he is found to have spasticity, difficulty standing, and walking. His muscle tone is increased in both lower limbs, and he has exaggerated deep tendon reflexes. He also has nystagmus, difficulty with coordination, and speech delay. MRI of the brain reveals a characteristic pattern of diffuse white matter hypoplasia, consistent with Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease. Further genetic testing confirms a mutation in the PLP1 gene, which encodes for the myelin protein proteolipid protein 1. These findings are consistent with a diagnosis of Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease, a rare X-linked leukodystrophy characterized by hypomyelination of the central nervous system, leading to progressive neurological dysfunction.
column10: Mr. Johnson is a 33-year-old male who presented with a history of developmental delay, difficulty with walking, and slurred speech. He has a positive family history of similar symptoms in his younger brother. On examination, he had spasticity in both lower limbs, exaggerated reflexes, and a positive Babinski sign. His gait was ataxic with a tendency to fall towards the right side. He had a mild tremor in his hands, dysarthria, and nystagmus. MRI of the brain revealed diffuse hypomyelination involving the white matter, consistent with Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease. Genetic testing confirmed the diagnosis of a PLP1 gene mutation. He was started on symptomatic treatment for spasticity, tremor, and dysarthria, with close follow-up by a neurologist.

column3: A 6-year-old child presents to the dermatology clinic with a history of recurrent episodes of painful, swollen gums and premature loss of primary teeth. Upon examination, the child has erythematous and edematous gums with significant gingival recession. The palms of the child's hands and soles of the feet are also noted to be thickened and hyperkeratotic. The child has a history of frequent skin infections and has developed a foul odor from the feet. The parents mention that similar symptoms have been observed in the child's older sibling. A diagnosis of Papillon-Lefèvre syndrome is made based on the clinical presentation and family history. The child is referred to a geneticist for further evaluation and management.
column10: A 28-year-old male presents with severe periodontitis and multiple missing teeth. He reports experiencing frequent dental abscesses and pain. On examination, his palms and soles are erythematous and hyperkeratotic. He also has yellow-brown hyperkeratotic plaques around his nails. The patient reports a history of similar skin lesions in his sister. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Papillon-Lefèvre syndrome.

column3: A 6-year-old girl presented to the pediatrician with short stature and limb abnormalities. On physical examination, she was found to have shortening of her upper and lower extremities, particularly in the arms. Additionally, she had characteristic facial features including a flattened nasal bridge and prominent forehead. Radiographic imaging revealed skeletal abnormalities such as punctate calcifications in the epiphyses and metaphyses of the long bones. The diagnosis of X-linked dominant chondrodysplasia punctata was made based on these findings. Further genetic testing confirmed a mutation in the emopamil-binding protein gene, which is responsible for the disease. The patient was referred to a geneticist for further management and counseling regarding the inheritance pattern of the disorder.
column10: Mrs. Smith is a 35-year-old female who presents to the clinic with complaints of joint pain, short stature and vision problems. She has a history of multiple joint surgeries for dislocations and has been diagnosed with cataracts in both eyes. On physical examination, she has short stature, with a height of 4 feet 10 inches, and she walks with a waddling gait. She has dysmorphic facial features, including a flattened nasal bridge and a small chin. X-rays show characteristic stippling of the epiphyses of long bones and the vertebral column. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of X-linked dominant chondrodysplasia punctata.

column3: A 6-year-old child presents to the clinic with recurrent skin lesions and freckles on sun-exposed areas of the body. The child's parents report that the child experiences severe burning and blistering when exposed to sunlight, even for short periods. The child also complains of eye irritation and vision problems. A physical exam reveals multiple hyperpigmented macules and papules on the face, neck, and arms, as well as conjunctival injection and corneal opacities. The child is diagnosed with xeroderma pigmentosum, a rare genetic disorder that impairs the ability of the skin to repair DNA damage caused by ultraviolet radiation. The child is advised to avoid sun exposure, wear protective clothing and use sunscreen with a high SPF. Regular eye exams are also recommended to monitor for the development of ocular lesions. The child is referred to a genetic counselor for further evaluation and management.
column10: A 35-year-old man presents to the dermatologist with a history of multiple skin lesions and freckles since childhood. He reports severe sunburns with minimal sun exposure and a family history of skin cancer. On examination, the patient has numerous hyperpigmented macules and papules on his face, neck, and arms. The skin is dry and rough to the touch. He also has a few actinic keratoses and a history of basal cell carcinoma. The dermatologist suspects Xeroderma pigmentosum and orders genetic testing to confirm the diagnosis. The patient is advised to avoid sun exposure, wear protective clothing and use a high SPF sunscreen to prevent further skin damage. Regular skin cancer screening is also recommended.

column3: A 4-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent bacterial infections, including pneumonia and otitis media. He has also experienced chronic diarrhea and has failed to thrive despite adequate caloric intake. Family history is significant for multiple male relatives who died in early childhood due to severe infections. Physical examination reveals a normal appearing child with no palpable lymph nodes or tonsils. Laboratory tests show markedly reduced levels of immunoglobulins, and genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of X-linked agammaglobulinemia.
column10: John is a 29-year-old male who presents with recurrent infections, including sinusitis, bronchitis, and pneumonia. He reports having these infections since childhood and has required multiple hospitalizations and courses of antibiotics. He also reports a family history of males with similar symptoms. On physical examination, he has no palpable lymph nodes and a normal spleen size. Laboratory studies reveal low levels of immunoglobulins, particularly IgG and IgM. Flow cytometry analysis shows a significant reduction in B cells. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of X-linked agammaglobulinemia, a rare primary immunodeficiency disorder caused by mutations in the BTK gene. John is started on immunoglobulin replacement therapy to prevent further infections.

column2: Change in presentation related to age
column3: A 3-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician with failure to thrive and recurrent infections. He was born prematurely at 34 weeks and has always been small for his age. On examination, he has a mild cardiomyopathy with a systolic murmur, poor muscle tone, and delayed motor milestones. His blood work reveals neutropenia and increased levels of creatine kinase. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Barth syndrome. Barth syndrome is a rare X-linked disorder that affects mitochondrial function and energy production. It primarily affects boys and typically presents in infancy or early childhood with symptoms such as failure to thrive, muscle weakness, cardiomyopathy, neutropenia, and recurrent infections. The diagnosis is confirmed through genetic testing. Management involves a multidisciplinary approach with nutritional support, cardiac medications, and antibiotics for infections.
column10: John is a 25-year-old male who presents with unexplained fatigue and shortness of breath. He reports a history of recurrent infections, particularly respiratory infections, and muscle weakness. On examination, he appears thin and has a high-pitched voice. His heart sounds are muffled, and he has an irregular rhythm. An echocardiogram reveals dilated cardiomyopathy, and a muscle biopsy shows abnormal mitochondria. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Barth syndrome. Barth syndrome is a rare X-linked genetic disorder that primarily affects males. It is caused by mutations in the tafazzin gene, which results in abnormal mitochondrial function. The most common clinical features include cardiomyopathy, neutropenia, skeletal muscle weakness, and growth delay. Patients may also have recurrent infections, particularly respiratory infections, and elevated levels of liver enzymes. The diagnosis is confirmed by genetic testing and muscle biopsy. Treatment is supportive and may include medications to improve heart function, growth hormone therapy, and antibiotics for infections.

column3: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents due to concerns about his vision and developmental delays. On examination, the child is noted to have strabismus and nystagmus. The pediatrician also observes that the child has a small head circumference and is shorter than average for his age. The parents report that the child has not yet begun to speak and has difficulty with balance and coordination. Genetic testing is ordered and reveals a deletion on chromosome 11p13 consistent with WAGR syndrome. The child is referred for further evaluation and management by a geneticist and ophthalmologist.
column10: John is a 25-year-old male with WAGR syndrome. He presents with developmental delay, intellectual disability, and a history of childhood kidney cancer. On examination, he has a low-set ears, a small penis, and a broad nasal bridge. He also has a high risk of developing Wilms tumor and other tumors due to the deletion of the WT1 gene. John has a history of behavioral issues, including aggression and self-injurious behavior, that require management with medications and behavioral therapy. He is followed closely by a multidisciplinary team that includes a pediatrician, neurologist, urologist, oncologist, and psychologist.

column3: A 5-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician's office with short stature, microcephaly, and intellectual disability. The patient also has a narrow face with a beak-like nose, prominent forehead, and protruding ears. On physical examination, the child has bird-like arms and legs, and his fingers and toes are thin and elongated. The pediatrician suspects Seckel syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by severe growth retardation, microcephaly, and distinctive facial features. The patient is referred to a geneticist for further evaluation and genetic testing to confirm the diagnosis.
column10: A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of short stature, intellectual disability, and a small head size. On examination, she measures 4 feet tall and has a head circumference of 46 cm, which is below the third percentile for her age. She also has a narrow face, a beak-like nose, and prominent ears. Her cognitive function is impaired, with an IQ of 65. She has mild microcephaly and a high-pitched voice. These features are consistent with Seckel syndrome, an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by severe growth retardation, microcephaly, and intellectual disability.

column3: A 4-year-old male child was brought to the clinic by his parents with a history of developmental delay and behavioral issues. His parents reported that he had delayed speech and motor milestones and often exhibited hyperactivity, aggression, and difficulty sleeping. On physical examination, he had coarse facial features, a large head circumference, and hepatosplenomegaly. Further investigations revealed elevated levels of glycosaminoglycans in his urine and a deficiency of the enzyme N-acetylglucosamine-6-sulfatase, confirming a diagnosis of Sanfilippo syndrome type B. The child was referred for genetic counseling and management of his symptoms, including behavioral therapy and supportive care.
column10: Mr. Smith is a 30-year-old male who presents to the clinic with complaints of behavioral changes, developmental regression, and progressive intellectual disability. He has a history of delayed speech and motor milestones since childhood. On examination, he has coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, and joint stiffness. His gait is unsteady, and he has difficulty with fine motor tasks. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated urinary glycosaminoglycans levels, confirming the diagnosis of Sanfilippo syndrome type B. Further genetic testing confirms a homozygous mutation in the NAGLU gene. The patient is referred to a specialist for further management and genetic counseling.

column3: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician's office by his parents for concerns about his muscle weakness and delayed motor milestones. On examination, he has hypotonia and weakness in his proximal muscles, especially in his hip flexors and neck extensors. He struggles to stand up from a seated position and has difficulty climbing stairs. His reflexes are decreased, and he has a waddling gait. His parents report that he has been a slow developer, with delayed walking and difficulty with fine motor skills. They also mention a family history of muscular dystrophy. A muscle biopsy confirms the diagnosis of X-linked centronuclear myopathy. The child is referred to a neuromuscular specialist for further management and genetic counseling.
column10: John is a 35-year-old male who presents with progressive muscle weakness, particularly in his upper arms and legs. He reports difficulty lifting objects and climbing stairs. He also notes that his facial muscles feel weak and that he has difficulty speaking and chewing. John reports that his symptoms have been present for several years, but have become progressively worse over time. On physical examination, John is found to have hypotonia and weakness in his proximal muscles, including his shoulders, hips, and neck. There is also evidence of facial muscle weakness and ptosis. His reflexes are diminished, and he has an elevated serum creatine kinase level. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of X-linked centronuclear myopathy.

column3: A 3-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a history of delayed milestones and poor vision. On examination, he is found to have a small head circumference and bilateral congenital cataracts. The patient has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections and polyuria. There is also evidence of hypotonia and muscle weakness. A diagnosis of Oculocerebrorenal syndrome of Lowe is suspected based on these clinical features. Further investigations reveal elevated serum creatine kinase levels and decreased levels of phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate in the urine. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis, and the patient is referred to a specialist for further management.
column10: A 35-year-old male presents with a history of developmental delay, intellectual disability, and bilateral congenital cataracts. He has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections and polyuria. On examination, he has hypotonia and muscle weakness. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated levels of amino acids, particularly cystine, in the urine. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Oculocerebrorenal syndrome of Lowe.

column3: A 6-year-old male child presents with difficulty walking and frequent falls. He has a history of delayed motor milestones and progressive weakness in his lower limbs. On examination, he has a waddling gait, proximal muscle weakness in his lower limbs, and scapular winging. He also has calf hypertrophy and diminished deep tendon reflexes. There is a positive family history of muscular dystrophy. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the Gamma-sarcoglycan gene, confirming the diagnosis of Gamma-sarcoglycan-related limb-girdle muscular dystrophy R5. The child is referred to a neuromuscular specialist for further management and support.
column10: A 34-year-old male presents with progressive weakness in his lower limbs and difficulty climbing stairs. He has a history of delayed motor milestones in childhood and a family history of muscle weakness. On examination, he has marked wasting of the lower limb muscles and proximal muscle weakness, with a positive Gower's sign. Creatine kinase levels are elevated. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the gamma-sarcoglycan gene, confirming a diagnosis of Gamma-sarcoglycan-related limb-girdle muscular dystrophy R5.

column3: A 6-month-old infant presents to the pediatrician with poor feeding, vomiting, and lethargy. The child was born at term with an unremarkable birth history but has failed to thrive since birth. On physical examination, the infant appears weak and hypotonic with a fruity odor. Laboratory studies reveal metabolic acidosis, hyperammonemia, and elevated levels of propionic acid, confirming the diagnosis of Propionic acidemia. The child is immediately started on a low-protein diet and receives intravenous fluids to correct the metabolic imbalance. The child is referred to a metabolic specialist for long-term management of the condition.
column10: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department with confusion and lethargy. He has a history of developmental delay and recurrent episodes of vomiting and diarrhea since childhood. On examination, he appears acutely ill, with a fruity odor to his breath. Laboratory studies reveal metabolic acidosis with an anion gap, elevated serum ammonia and lactate levels, and hyperammonemia. Urine organic acid analysis shows an increased level of propionylcarnitine, confirming the diagnosis of Propionic acidemia. The patient is started on emergent treatment with intravenous fluids, glucose, and carnitine, and is admitted to the hospital for further management.

column3: A 6-month-old male infant is brought to the emergency department after having a seizure at home. The parents report that the baby has been experiencing recurrent seizures since birth, which have been becoming more frequent and severe over the past few weeks. The child's neurological examination is unremarkable except for mild hypertonia. Laboratory tests reveal low levels of pyridoxine (vitamin B6) in the blood and cerebrospinal fluid. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Pyridoxine-dependent epilepsy. The child is started on high doses of pyridoxine supplements, which result in the resolution of seizures within hours. The parents are advised to continue the supplements and to avoid fasting or other stressors that can trigger seizures. Follow-up visits show that the baby is developing normally and has been seizure-free.
column10: John is a 28-year-old male who presents with a history of recurrent seizures since childhood. He has been taking anti-epileptic medications with varying degrees of success. He reports that his seizures are often triggered by stress, fatigue, and missed meals. He reports a family history of epilepsy. On examination, John has normal neurologic exam findings. Laboratory investigations reveal low levels of pyridoxine (vitamin B6) in his blood. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of pyridoxine-dependent epilepsy. John is started on high-dose pyridoxine supplementation, and his seizures significantly improve.

column3: A 4-year-old boy presents to his pediatrician with complaints of difficulty walking and frequent falls. On examination, the child is noted to have a short stature with a height of 80 cm (<3rd percentile) and a weight of 12 kg. He has a large head circumference (>97th percentile) and a prominent forehead. His chest is broad with a barrel-shaped rib cage, and he has kyphoscoliosis. The child's arms and legs are short, and he has a waddling gait. The child's hands and feet are broad with stubby fingers and toes. Radiographic evaluation reveals platyspondyly, irregularities of the vertebral end plates, and a small pelvis. These findings are consistent with the diagnosis of Metatropic Dysplasia, a rare form of skeletal dysplasia characterized by short stature, kyphoscoliosis, and a distinctive "dumbbell-shaped" femur. The pediatrician refers the child to a geneticist for further evaluation and management.
column10: John is a 30-year-old male who presents to the orthopedic clinic with complaints of short stature and joint pain since childhood. His medical history is significant for multiple surgeries including spinal fusion and hip replacement. On examination, he has a short stature with a height of 3 feet 5 inches and a characteristic barrel-shaped chest. His arms and legs are short and bowed, and he has limited range of motion in his hips and knees. X-rays reveal severe kyphoscoliosis and irregularities in the shape and size of his bones, consistent with a diagnosis of Metatropic dysplasia. John reports a significant impact on his quality of life due to his physical limitations and chronic pain.

column3: A 7-year-old male presents to his pediatrician with complaints of pain and swelling in his knees and elbows. He has a history of nail abnormalities and was diagnosed with Nail-patella syndrome at birth. On examination, the child has hypoplastic, absent or discolored nails, and patella hypoplasia. He also has bilateral elbow contractures and limited range of motion in his knees. The pediatrician notes a triangular shaped face with prominent forehead and receding hairline. The child's mother reports a family history of similar nail and skeletal abnormalities. The pediatrician refers the child to a geneticist for further evaluation and management.
column10: A 35-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of knee pain and difficulty walking. She reports a long history of nail abnormalities and small, poorly developed patellae. Upon examination, the patient has hypoplastic patellae and nails that are triangular-shaped with a small base and a tendency to split. She also has evidence of early-onset osteoarthritis in her knees. Further evaluation reveals that the patient has proteinuria and a history of kidney disease, which is commonly associated with Nail-patella syndrome. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of Nail-patella syndrome, a rare autosomal dominant disorder that affects the development of nails, patellae, and the kidneys. The patient is referred to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management of her kidney disease, and an orthopedic specialist for treatment of her knee pain and osteoarthritis.

column3: A 2-year-old male child presents to the pediatrician with developmental delay and delayed milestones. The parents report that the child has difficulty sitting up and crawling compared to other children his age. On examination, the child appears pale and lethargic with a decreased muscle tone. The physician also notices a musty odor coming from the child's skin. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of phenylalanine in the blood and urine, along with low levels of tyrosine. A diagnosis of hyperphenylalaninemia due to tetrahydrobiopterin deficiency is suspected, and the child is referred to a metabolic specialist for further evaluation and management.
column10: A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of developmental delay and intellectual disability since childhood. He also reports experiencing mild tremors and difficulty with coordination. His medical history is significant for a diagnosis of hyperphenylalaninemia due to tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) deficiency. On examination, he has mild hypertonia and hyperreflexia. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of phenylalanine and decreased levels of tyrosine and neurotransmitters such as dopamine and serotonin. Further genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of BH4 deficiency. The patient is started on BH4 supplementation and a low phenylalanine diet. Follow-up visits show improvement in his tremors and coordination, as well as modest gains in cognitive function.

column3: Sarah is a 4-year-old girl who presents to the clinic with her parents. Her parents report that Sarah has had recurrent infections, developmental delays, and vision problems. Sarah is small for her age and has a disproportionately small head. During the physical exam, the doctor notices that Sarah has dry, scaly skin and a prominent forehead. She also has thinning hair and small, widely spaced teeth. When the doctor attempts to move her limbs, Sarah seems to be in pain and resists movement. Sarah's parents report that she has been experiencing hearing loss and has become increasingly sensitive to light. Based on these findings, the doctor suspects that Sarah may have Cockayne syndrome, a rare genetic disorder that affects growth and development.
column10: A 35-year-old male presents with developmental delay, short stature, and photosensitivity. He has a history of frequent infections and hearing loss. On physical examination, he has a bird-like facies, thin hair, and small eyes. His skin is dry, thin, and has multiple freckles on sun-exposed areas. Neurological examination reveals cerebellar ataxia and peripheral neuropathy. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Cockayne syndrome.

column3: A 7-year-old boy presents to the ophthalmologist with complaints of progressive vision loss and difficulty seeing at night. The child has a history of night blindness that started at the age of 4. On examination, the ophthalmologist notes the presence of white, punctate lesions located throughout the retina. The lesions are small and round, and they appear as white dots on fundus examination. There is also evidence of macular degeneration. The child's visual acuity is significantly reduced, and he struggles with visual tasks that require good contrast sensitivity. The ophthalmologist diagnoses the child with Retinitis punctata albescens, a rare genetic disorder characterized by the presence of numerous white dots on the retina and progressive vision loss. The child is referred to a geneticist for further evaluation and management.
column10: A 35-year-old male presents to the ophthalmologist with complaints of gradual loss of vision in both eyes over the past 5 years. He reports difficulty seeing in low light conditions and has noticed multiple small white dots in his visual field. On examination, the patient has reduced visual acuity and bilateral retinal pigment deposits in a punctate pattern. Fluorescein angiography reveals areas of hyperfluorescence corresponding to the pigment deposits. The patient is diagnosed with Retinitis punctata albescens, a rare genetic disorder characterized by progressive vision loss due to the accumulation of deposits in the retina.

column3: A 5-year-old boy presents to the dermatology clinic with a history of recurrent blistering and skin erosions all over his body since birth. He has a family history of similar symptoms and his parents are also affected. On examination, his skin is extremely fragile and any touch or trauma leads to the formation of blisters and erosions. His nails are dystrophic and there are areas of scarring and hyperpigmentation on his skin. He has difficulty eating solid foods due to oral blistering and has frequent episodes of upper respiratory infections due to involvement of the mucous membranes. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of severe generalized junctional epidermolysis bullosa, a rare and debilitating genetic disorder that affects the skin and mucous membranes. The child requires ongoing multidisciplinary care and management to prevent infections, maintain skin integrity, and improve his quality of life.
column10: John is a 32-year-old male who has been suffering from recurrent blistering and skin erosions since he was a child. He has been diagnosed with severe generalized junctional epidermolysis bullosa (EB), a rare genetic disorder that affects the skin and mucous membranes. His skin is extremely fragile and easily blisters and tears with minor trauma or friction. John has scars on his skin due to repeated blistering and healing. He reports experiencing significant pain and discomfort due to his skin condition, which has affected his daily activities and work. He has also had recurrent infections, including skin infections and sepsis, requiring hospitalization. John has a history of malnutrition and anemia, which is due to the limited food intake as chewing and swallowing is painful. John has a positive family history, and his two siblings and father also have a similar skin condition. He has been managed by a dermatologist and a multidisciplinary team of specialists, including a nutritionist and a pain management team. His treatment has included wound care, pain management, and preventive measures such as avoiding trauma to the skin. John's prognosis is guarded as there is no cure for EB, and the management is mainly supportive.

column2: Change in presentation related to age
column3: A 6-month-old male infant was brought to the emergency department with poor feeding, lethargy, and seizures. The infant was born full-term with no known complications during pregnancy or delivery. On examination, the infant was hypotonic and had a weak suck reflex. Blood tests revealed elevated glycine levels, and a urine organic acid analysis showed elevated levels of glycine and its metabolites. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain showed diffuse white matter abnormalities. The infant was diagnosed with Glycine encephalopathy, a rare metabolic disorder caused by a defect in the glycine cleavage system. Treatment was started with a low-protein diet, sodium benzoate, and dextromethorphan. Despite treatment, the infant's neurological status continued to deteriorate, and he passed away at 9 months of age.
column10: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a history of recurrent seizures and developmental delay since childhood. She has a history of intellectual disability and speech delay. The patient's family reports that she has had several episodes of unexplained fever and lethargy in the past. On examination, the patient appears lethargic and has a low-grade fever. She has a mild tremor, and her deep tendon reflexes are hyperactive. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated serum glycine levels, and a diagnosis of glycine encephalopathy is made. The patient is started on intravenous fluids, anticonvulsants, and supportive therapy. She is referred to a metabolic specialist for further management.

column1: Severe hereditary thrombophilia due to congenital protein C deficiency
column3: A 6-year-old male child was admitted to the hospital with severe bleeding and bruising on his arms and legs. The child had a history of congenital protein C deficiency, which was diagnosed during his neonatal period. He had been receiving regular protein C replacement therapy, but he missed his last dose due to a family emergency. The child's parents reported that he had been experiencing pain and swelling in his left leg for the past few days. On physical examination, the child had multiple ecchymoses and petechiae on his arms and legs. His left leg was swollen, and there was tenderness and warmth in the area. Laboratory tests revealed a markedly prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) and a low level of protein C. Doppler ultrasound of the left leg showed deep vein thrombosis. The child was diagnosed with severe hereditary thrombophilia due to congenital protein C deficiency and was started on anticoagulant therapy along with protein C replacement. The child's condition improved gradually, and he was discharged from the hospital after a week with close follow-up appointments.
column10: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset chest pain and shortness of breath. He has a history of hereditary thrombophilia due to congenital protein C deficiency and has been on anticoagulation therapy for the past year. The patient reports that he recently stopped his medication due to financial constraints. On examination, he has tachycardia, tachypnea, and decreased oxygen saturation. A chest x-ray reveals a pulmonary embolism. Laboratory tests confirm a significantly elevated D-dimer level and a low protein C level. The patient is started on heparin therapy and admitted for further management. The importance of consistent anticoagulation therapy is emphasized to the patient and a follow-up appointment is scheduled for medication reconciliation and monitoring.

column3: Tommy is a 5-year-old boy who has been experiencing multiple health problems since birth. He has delayed development, short stature, and frequent ear infections. His parents also noticed that he has a hoarse voice, a flat nasal bridge, and thick lips. Tommy's pediatrician referred him to a metabolic specialist, who diagnosed him with Mucopolysaccharidosis type 6 (MPS 6). Further evaluation revealed that Tommy has an enlarged liver and spleen, as well as restricted joint movement. He also has corneal clouding, which affects his vision. His urine test showed elevated levels of glycosaminoglycans (GAGs), which confirmed the diagnosis of MPS 6. Tommy's parents were devastated to learn that there is no cure for MPS 6, and that the treatment options are limited to managing the symptoms. Tommy will require enzyme replacement therapy to slow down the progression of the disease. He will also need regular follow-up with a team of specialists, including a metabolic specialist, a genetic counselor, and an ophthalmologist, to monitor his condition and manage his symptoms.
column10: John is a 35-year-old male who presents to his primary care physician with a history of joint pain, stiffness, and limited mobility. He also reports difficulty with hearing and vision. On physical exam, he has coarse facial features, a prominent forehead, and a large tongue. He has limited range of motion in his hips and shoulders. His gait is waddling and he has a noticeable sway in his back. His hands are broad with thick fingers and his skin is thickened. He has a history of recurrent ear and respiratory infections. A urine test reveals elevated levels of glycosaminoglycans. These findings are consistent with Mucopolysaccharidosis type 6, also known as Maroteaux-Lamy syndrome.

column3: A 5-year-old Hispanic boy presents to the pediatrician with a history of recurrent nosebleeds, easy bruising, and frequent infections. On physical examination, he has pale skin, nystagmus, and mild hepatomegaly. His platelet count is low, and his clotting time is prolonged. A detailed family history reveals that his father and grandmother also have similar symptoms. Further evaluation and genetic testing confirm the diagnosis of Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome, a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by oculocutaneous albinism, bleeding diathesis, and immunodeficiency. The patient is referred to a specialist for management of his symptoms and genetic counseling for his family members.
column10: A 35-year-old Hispanic male presents to the clinic with a history of recurrent episodes of easy bruising, nosebleeds, and shortness of breath on exertion. He has a medical history of albinism and visual impairment since childhood. On examination, he has multiple bruises on his arms and legs, scattered petechiae on his face and oral mucosa, and a faint systolic murmur on cardiac auscultation. Laboratory tests reveal mild thrombocytopenia and prolonged bleeding time. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome. The patient is advised to avoid strenuous physical activity and to undergo regular monitoring for pulmonary fibrosis and progressive vision loss. He is also referred to a hematologist for further evaluation and management of his bleeding disorder.

column3: David is a 8-year-old boy who was brought to the pediatrician by his parents due to progressive difficulty in walking and talking. His parents noticed that he was becoming clumsy and would frequently fall over while playing. David's speech has also become slurred and difficult to understand. The pediatrician noted that David had dystonia, which is a movement disorder that causes involuntary muscle contractions. He also exhibited spasticity, which is a condition where the muscles are stiff and difficult to move. David's MRI showed iron deposition in the basal ganglia, which is a hallmark of Pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration (PKAN). PKAN is a rare inherited disorder that affects the nervous system, causing progressive movement problems, speech difficulties, and cognitive decline. The pediatrician referred David to a neurologist for further evaluation and management.
column10: A 32-year-old male presented to the neurology clinic with a six-year history of progressive difficulty with walking and tremors. He reported frequent falls and difficulty with simple tasks such as buttoning his shirt and brushing his teeth. The patient's family noted that he had also been experiencing dysarthria and dysphagia, and had developed a rigid posture. On examination, the patient exhibited dystonia, spasticity, and hyperreflexia. MRI showed iron deposition in the basal ganglia, and genetic testing confirmed a diagnosis of Pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration (PKAN). The patient was started on treatment with levodopa, but his symptoms continued to progress.

column3: A 4-year-old male presents with developmental delay and frequent infections. Physical exam reveals coarse facial features, thickened lips, and a prominent forehead. He also has hepatosplenomegaly and joint stiffness. Laboratory testing shows low levels of beta-mannosidase enzyme activity. A diagnosis of Beta-mannosidosis is made.
column10: A 32-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of progressive intellectual disability, seizures, and muscle weakness. He reports having difficulty with coordination and balance, and has experienced multiple falls in the past few months. On physical examination, the patient has coarse facial features, a prominent forehead, and a large jaw. He also has hepatosplenomegaly and a slightly enlarged heart. Laboratory tests reveal low white blood cell count, low platelet count, and elevated levels of beta-mannosidase in his blood and urine. Further genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Beta-mannosidosis.

column3: A 6-year-old child presents to the pediatrician with a history of frequent bone fractures and delayed growth milestones. The child's parents report that their child has always been smaller than their peers and has experienced multiple fractures with minimal trauma, such as falls from a low height. Physical examination reveals short stature, a prominent forehead, and a small chin. The child's teeth appear crowded due to a narrow palate, and the mandible is underdeveloped, resulting in a characteristic facial appearance. The pediatrician suspects Pycnodysostosis, a rare genetic disorder that affects bone growth and development. The diagnosis is confirmed with a genetic test, and the child is referred to a specialist for ongoing management and monitoring of their bone health.
column10: Meet John, a 35-year-old male with Pycnodysostosis. He presents to his primary care physician with complaints of joint pain and frequent fractures. On physical examination, John is found to have short stature, a small head, a prominent forehead, and a beaked nose. His teeth are crowded and abnormally shaped, and he has a high-pitched voice. X-rays reveal thickening of the bones and an increased risk of fracture. John also reports a history of dental problems, including abscesses and early tooth loss. These findings are consistent with the diagnosis of Pycnodysostosis, a rare genetic disorder characterized by bone fragility, short stature, and distinctive facial features.

column3: Sarah is a 2-year-old girl with trichothiodystrophy (TTD), a rare genetic disorder that affects hair, skin, and nails. She was born with sparse, brittle hair that has a characteristic "tiger tail" appearance under a microscope. Sarah also has dry, scaly skin, and her nails are thin and easily breakable.  Sarah's parents noticed that she has developmental delays and intellectual disability. She struggles with speech and has delayed motor milestones. Sarah also has photosensitivity and is prone to sunburns and skin rashes. She has a history of recurrent infections, including respiratory and ear infections. Physical examination reveals a small head circumference and facial features that are typical of TTD, such as a small nose and thin lips. Sarah's skin is dry and scaly, and she has a rash on her cheeks. Her hair is sparse, brittle, and has a characteristic tiger tail appearance.  Sarah's medical team will monitor her for infections, developmental delays, and intellectual disability. They will also recommend sun protection measures to prevent skin damage and monitor her hair and skin for any changes.
column10: A 32-year-old male presents with short, brittle hair, dry scaly skin, and intellectual disability. He has a history of recurrent respiratory infections and photosensitivity. Physical examination reveals sparse, brittle hair with a characteristic "tiger-tail" banding pattern under polarizing microscopy. Skin examination shows erythema and scaling with an increased risk of skin cancer. The patient's neurologic examination is notable for mild intellectual disability and spasticity. These findings are consistent with Trichothiodystrophy, a rare genetic disorder characterized by defects in DNA transcription and repair pathways due to mutations in genes encoding the TFIIH complex. The patient is advised to avoid sun exposure and undergo regular dermatologic surveillance. Genetic counseling is recommended for the patient and his family members due to the risk of inheritance.

column3: A 4-year-old male child was brought to the emergency department with a history of recurrent bacterial infections, including pneumonia, otitis media, and cellulitis. The child had a delayed umbilical cord separation and had a history of poor wound healing. On examination, the child had poor dentition and had a gum abscess. The child had no lymphadenopathy or hepatosplenomegaly. His laboratory investigations showed a marked leukocytosis with a neutrophilic predominance and a normal platelet count. Flow cytometry showed a complete absence of CD18 expression on neutrophils and lymphocytes, consistent with a diagnosis of Leukocyte adhesion deficiency type I.
column10: A 28-year-old male presents with a history of recurrent infections since childhood. He reports frequent episodes of skin abscesses, pneumonia, and gingivitis. Physical examination reveals poor wound healing and lack of pus formation. Laboratory investigations reveal leukocytosis with neutrophilia but a lack of pus cells on gram stain. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Leukocyte adhesion deficiency type I.

column3: A 7-year-old boy presents with episodes of sudden, involuntary movements of his limbs and trunk, which last for several minutes. These episodes occur at rest and are not triggered by any particular movement. The boy's parents report that the episodes occur about once a week and are not associated with any other symptoms. The boy has a normal neurological exam in between episodes. The diagnosis of paroxysmal non-kinesigenic dyskinesia is suspected and confirmed with genetic testing. The boy is started on medication to manage his symptoms and is referred to a neurologist for further management.
column10: A 34-year-old male presents to the clinic with a history of sudden, involuntary movements of his limbs and trunk. He reports that these episodes last for a few minutes and occur several times a day, but are not associated with any specific activity or trigger. The movements are characterized by twisting, writhing, and jerking of his arms and legs, and occasionally involve his face and neck. He has no family history of similar symptoms, and his neurological examination is normal between episodes. After a thorough evaluation, he is diagnosed with paroxysmal non-kinesigenic dyskinesia, a rare movement disorder characterized by intermittent and unpredictable episodes of abnormal movements that are not triggered by sudden movements or exercise.

column3: A 6-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician with complaints of headaches and difficulty seeing. On physical examination, the child has a prominent forehead, flattened midface, and beaked nose. The eyes are widely spaced and the corneas are slightly cloudy. He also has thick, bushy eyebrows and a small lower jaw. The pediatrician notes the presence of acanthosis nigricans in the neck and axillary regions. The child's mother reports that she and her husband have a history of similar facial features. The pediatrician suspects the child may have Crouzon syndrome-acanthosis nigricans syndrome, a rare genetic disorder that affects the development of the bones in the skull and face. The child is referred to a geneticist for further evaluation and management.
column10: Mr. Smith is a 35-year-old male with a history of Crouzon syndrome-acanthosis nigricans syndrome. On examination, he has craniosynostosis, exophthalmos, hypertelorism, proptosis, and a beaked nose. He also has acanthosis nigricans, which is present on the neck, axilla, and groin regions. His vision is impaired due to optic nerve compression, and he has intermittent headaches. He has a high-arched palate with a narrow airway, resulting in obstructive sleep apnea. His hearing is impaired due to recurrent otitis media. He has an abnormal dental occlusion with a malocclusion of his teeth. His fingers are short and stubby, and he has mild joint stiffness. Overall, Mr. Smith's condition requires a multidisciplinary approach, including neurosurgery, ophthalmology, otolaryngology, dentistry, and dermatology.

column1: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 17-alpha-hydroxylase deficiency
column3: A 4-year-old male patient is brought to the hospital by his parents due to ambiguous genitalia and failure to thrive. On physical examination, the patient has a micropenis with fused scrotum and undescended testes. He also has poor muscle tone and appears underdeveloped for his age. Laboratory tests reveal low levels of cortisol and aldosterone and high levels of progesterone and 17-hydroxyprogesterone. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 17-alpha-hydroxylase deficiency. The patient is started on hormone replacement therapy and referred to a pediatric endocrinologist for further management.
column10: A 32-year-old woman presents with primary amenorrhea and hirsutism. She reports never having a menstrual cycle and has noticed excess facial hair growth over the past few years. On examination, she has a deep voice, clitoromegaly, and no breast development. Her blood pressure is elevated at 160/100 mmHg. Laboratory testing reveals low levels of cortisol, aldosterone, and sex hormones, with elevated levels of 17-hydroxyprogesterone and progesterone. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 17-alpha-hydroxylase deficiency. She is started on glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid replacement therapy to manage her hormonal imbalances and hypertension. Long-term management includes regular monitoring of hormone levels and blood pressure to prevent complications such as cardiovascular disease and infertility.

column3: A 4-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician with recurrent infections and eczema since infancy. He has a history of easy bruising and nosebleeds. Physical examination reveals small bruises on his arms and legs, and his skin is dry and scaly with areas of erythema and oozing. Laboratory tests show thrombocytopenia and elevated IgE levels. Additional testing reveals a mutation in the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein gene. The child is diagnosed with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, a rare X-linked immunodeficiency disorder characterized by thrombocytopenia, eczema, recurrent infections, and a predisposition to develop autoimmune disorders and lymphomas. The child is referred to a hematologist for further management and genetic counseling for his family.
column10: John is a 27-year-old male who presents to the hospital with a history of recurrent infections and easy bruising. He reports a history of frequent respiratory infections, otitis media, and sinusitis since childhood. He also reports multiple episodes of bacterial skin infections and recurrent episodes of gastrointestinal bleeding. On physical examination, he has petechiae and ecchymoses on his arms and legs and a history of persistent thrombocytopenia. He also has a history of eczema since childhood. His laboratory tests show a low platelet count and decreased levels of immunoglobulin M and immunoglobulin A. Further workup reveals a genetic mutation in the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP) gene, confirming the diagnosis of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome.

column3: Tommy is a 5-year-old boy who has difficulty with balance and coordination. He has been experiencing tingling and numbness in his hands and feet, and his vision has been deteriorating. His parents also noticed a strong odor coming from his skin and breath. Further evaluation showed that Tommy has elevated levels of phytanic acid in his blood and urine. Genetic testing confirmed a diagnosis of Refsum disease, an inherited disorder that affects the breakdown of phytanic acid. Tommy's treatment includes a strict low-phytanic acid diet and regular monitoring of his vision and neurological function.
column10: Mr. X is a 32-year-old male who presents with a history of progressive vision loss, hearing impairment, and difficulty with balance and coordination. On examination, he has retinitis pigmentosa, ataxia, and peripheral neuropathy. Further investigations reveal elevated levels of phytanic acid in his blood and urine. The patient is diagnosed with Refsum disease, a rare inherited metabolic disorder that affects the breakdown of phytanic acid. He is advised to avoid foods containing phytanic acid and is started on treatment with plasmapheresis to remove excess phytanic acid from his bloodstream.

column3: A 7-year-old boy presents to the clinic with developmental delay, coarse facial features, and recurrent infections. On examination, he has hepatosplenomegaly and joint stiffness. The parents report that the child has always been slow to meet developmental milestones and has struggled with frequent ear infections and upper respiratory infections. Further testing reveals a deficiency in alpha-mannosidase enzyme activity, confirming a diagnosis of alpha-mannosidosis. The child is referred to a specialist for further management and genetic counseling.
column10: John is a 35-year-old male who presents to his primary care physician with complaints of joint pain, frequent infections, and speech difficulties. On examination, he has joint stiffness, hepatosplenomegaly, and coarse facial features. His medical history reveals that he had developmental delay as a child and was diagnosed with a learning disability in adolescence. He also had recurrent ear infections and sinusitis. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of oligosaccharides in his urine, and genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of alpha-mannosidosis. Further evaluation reveals cognitive impairment and hearing loss. John is referred to a specialist for further management of his condition.

column1: Glycogen storage disease due to glycogen branching enzyme deficiency
column3: A 5-year-old boy presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue, weakness, and frequent episodes of vomiting after meals. The child's parents report that he has always had difficulty gaining weight despite a healthy appetite. On physical examination, the child appears thin and malnourished with hepatomegaly and splenomegaly. Blood tests reveal elevated liver enzymes and hypoglycemia. Further investigations reveal a deficiency in glycogen branching enzyme, confirming a diagnosis of Glycogen storage disease due to glycogen branching enzyme deficiency. The child is started on a strict diet high in complex carbohydrates and is referred to a specialist for long-term management.
column10: A 32-year-old male presents to the clinic with a history of recurrent episodes of hypoglycemia since childhood. He reports experiencing frequent fatigue, dizziness, and confusion during these episodes. His medical history is significant for delayed growth and development during childhood. Physical examination reveals a thin build, hepatomegaly, and muscle weakness. Laboratory investigations reveal hypoglycemia, elevated liver enzymes, and elevated serum lactate levels. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of glycogen storage disease type IV, also known as glycogen branching enzyme deficiency. The patient is advised to follow a high carbohydrate diet and to avoid fasting to prevent recurrent episodes of hypoglycemia.

column3: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to frequent nosebleeds and prolonged bleeding after minor cuts. His parents report that he has had these symptoms since birth. On physical examination, the child appears otherwise healthy. Laboratory tests reveal low levels of factor XI activity, confirming a diagnosis of Congenital factor XI deficiency. The child is advised to avoid contact sports and to inform healthcare providers about his condition before any medical or dental procedures. He is also prescribed desmopressin and recombinant factor XI concentrates to prevent bleeding episodes. The child's parents are educated on the importance of prompt medical attention for any significant bleeding and the need to carry a medical alert card at all times.
column10: John is a 35-year-old male who presents to the emergency room with a bleeding episode that started after an injury to his left knee. He has a known history of congenital factor XI deficiency, which was diagnosed during childhood when he had a prolonged bleeding episode after a tooth extraction. He reports that he has had several bleeding episodes in the past, including nosebleeds, easy bruising, and prolonged bleeding after minor injuries.  On examination, John has a large hematoma on his left knee, and his blood pressure is slightly low. Laboratory tests reveal a prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) and a low factor XI activity level. He is started on factor XI replacement therapy, and his bleeding episode resolves within a few days. The most important clinical feature in this vignette is the patient's history of bleeding episodes, which is indicative of a bleeding disorder. The diagnosis of congenital factor XI deficiency is confirmed by laboratory tests, and treatment with factor XI replacement therapy is effective in controlling bleeding episodes. Patients with factor XI deficiency are at risk of bleeding complications during surgical procedures, and prophylactic factor replacement may be necessary before surgery or dental procedures.

column3: A 6-year-old male child presented to the emergency department with excessive bleeding from a small cut on his hand that had been sustained while playing outside. The child had a history of recurrent bleeding episodes since infancy and had been previously diagnosed with Congenital factor V deficiency. On examination, the child was pale and tachycardic. Laboratory investigations showed a prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) and a low factor V level, confirming the diagnosis of Congenital factor V deficiency. The child was started on factor V replacement therapy and was subsequently referred to a hematology specialist for further management.
column10: A 30-year-old male presents with a history of spontaneous bleeding episodes. He reports frequent nosebleeds and easy bruising with minor trauma. He also recalls experiencing prolonged bleeding after a tooth extraction. He denies any family history of bleeding disorders. Laboratory tests reveal a prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) and a low factor V level. Further testing confirms a diagnosis of Congenital factor V deficiency. The patient is started on prophylactic factor V replacement therapy and counseled on the importance of avoiding activities that could lead to bleeding.

column3: A 7-year-old boy presents to the pediatric neurology clinic with a history of chronic gastrointestinal symptoms, including recurrent vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. He also has a history of progressive muscle weakness, difficulty walking, and frequent infections. The patient's family reports a history of consanguinity, and his older sister has a similar clinical presentation. On examination, the patient has muscle weakness and atrophy in the proximal limbs, with significant difficulty in standing up from a sitting position. He also has ophthalmoparesis, with impaired eye movements and ptosis. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated lactate levels in the blood and cerebrospinal fluid, along with mitochondrial dysfunction on muscle biopsy. Based on these findings, the patient is diagnosed with Mitochondrial neurogastrointestinal encephalomyopathy (MNGIE), a rare mitochondrial disorder that affects the gastrointestinal system and the nervous system. The disorder is caused by mutations in the thymidine phosphorylase (TP) gene, which leads to an accumulation of toxic metabolites and mitochondrial dysfunction. The patient is started on supportive treatment to manage his symptoms, including intravenous fluids, antiemetics, and pain management. He is also referred to a mitochondrial disease specialist for further management and genetic counseling.
column10: John is a 35-year-old man who presents to the clinic with a history of gastrointestinal symptoms, exercise intolerance, and progressive weakness for the past 5 years. He reports chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and difficulty swallowing. He also experiences muscle pain and cramps during physical activity. John has a history of hearing loss and visual disturbances, and his family history is significant for similar symptoms in his mother and sister. On physical examination, John has muscle wasting and weakness in his limbs, with decreased reflexes and sensory loss. He also has ophthalmoplegia and ptosis. His laboratory workup reveals elevated lactate levels and abnormal mitochondrial function tests. A muscle biopsy confirms mitochondrial myopathy. John's clinical presentation and diagnostic findings are consistent with Mitochondrial neurogastrointestinal encephalomyopathy (MNGIE), a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the TYMP gene. MNGIE is characterized by gastrointestinal dysmotility, ophthalmoparesis, leukoencephalopathy, and peripheral neuropathy. The disease is progressive and often leads to severe disability and death.

column3: Sarah is a 6-year-old girl who has been experiencing a progressive decline in her motor and cognitive abilities. Her parents have noticed that she has difficulty walking and tends to fall frequently. They also report that she has become more forgetful and has difficulty communicating with others. On examination, Sarah presents with dystonia and rigidity in her limbs, as well as dysarthria and dysphagia. She also has optic atrophy and retinal degeneration, which has resulted in visual impairment. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the MPAN gene, confirming the diagnosis of Mitochondrial membrane protein-associated neurodegeneration (MPAN).
column10: Mr. S is a 42-year-old man who presents with progressive dystonia, spasticity, and ataxia. He reports experiencing difficulty with balance and coordination, as well as increased muscle stiffness, over the past year. His family history is significant for multiple relatives with neurological symptoms, including his younger sister who died in childhood due to a similar disorder. Neurological examination reveals dystonic posturing of his limbs, increased muscle tone, and brisk deep tendon reflexes. Brain MRI shows iron deposition in the basal ganglia. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Mitochondrial membrane protein-associated neurodegeneration (MPAN).

column3: A 4-year-old boy is brought in by his parents with a history of recurrent fevers, sore throat, and mouth ulcers. The symptoms have been occurring in cycles, with episodes lasting for about 3-5 days before subsiding. During these episodes, he also experiences fatigue and malaise. Physical examination reveals mild cervical lymphadenopathy, and the child is found to have a low absolute neutrophil count. Further investigations reveal a pattern of cyclic neutropenia, with the child's neutrophil count dropping every 21 days before returning to normal levels. The child is started on prophylactic antibiotics to prevent infections during the neutropenic periods and will require close monitoring for any potential complications.
column10: A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with recurrent episodes of fever and sore throat for the past 6 months. He reports a history of similar episodes in childhood but they had resolved on their own. On examination, the patient appears pale and has an enlarged spleen. Laboratory investigations reveal a cyclic pattern of neutropenia with an absolute neutrophil count of 200 cells/mm3 during the febrile episodes, and a normal count of 1500 cells/mm3 during the asymptomatic period. A bone marrow biopsy confirms the diagnosis of cyclic neutropenia. The patient is started on prophylactic antibiotics to prevent infections during the neutropenic phase. He is also advised to maintain good oral hygiene to reduce the risk of oral infections.

column1: Autosomal dominant adult-onset proximal spinal muscular atrophy
column3: A 12-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a history of progressive muscle weakness and difficulty in walking. The patient reports that he has had trouble with running, jumping, and climbing stairs for the past few months. On examination, the child is noted to have proximal muscle weakness in both lower extremities, with a waddling gait and difficulty rising from a sitting position. Further workup revealed elevated creatine kinase levels and electromyography showed evidence of chronic denervation. Genetic testing was positive for autosomal dominant adult-onset proximal spinal muscular atrophy. The patient was referred to a neuromuscular specialist for further evaluation and management of the condition.
column10: Mrs. Smith is a 45-year-old woman who presents with a 3-year history of progressive weakness and wasting of her upper limbs. She reports difficulty with activities that require fine motor skills, such as buttoning her shirt or holding a pen. She also complains of fatigue and muscle cramps. On examination, she has decreased muscle bulk and tone in her upper extremities, with weakness of shoulder abduction and elbow flexion. She has preserved sensation and reflexes. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the SMN1 gene, confirming the diagnosis of Autosomal dominant adult-onset proximal spinal muscular atrophy.

column3: Samantha is a 7-year-old girl who was referred to a pediatric neurologist because of progressive weakness in her lower extremities. Her parents first noticed difficulty with running and jumping when she was 5 years old. Over the past year, she has also had difficulty climbing stairs and getting up from a seated position. On examination, Samantha has a waddling gait and has difficulty standing up from the floor without using her hands. She has mild proximal muscle weakness in her lower extremities, particularly in the hip flexors and knee extensors. Her calf muscles are also mildly enlarged. She has no cardiac involvement. Genetic testing revealed a mutation in the beta-sarcoglycan gene, confirming a diagnosis of Beta-sarcoglycan-related limb-girdle muscular dystrophy R4.
column10: A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of difficulty in walking and climbing stairs for the past few years. He reports frequent falls and muscle weakness, which has been progressive in nature. On examination, the patient is found to have proximal muscle weakness, particularly in the hip and shoulder girdles. There is also evidence of calf muscle hypertrophy. The patient's deep tendon reflexes are diminished, and he reports mild difficulty in swallowing. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated creatine kinase levels. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of Beta-sarcoglycan-related limb-girdle muscular dystrophy R4. The patient is counseled regarding the progressive nature of the disease, and appropriate supportive measures are initiated.

column3: A 7-year-old male presents to the pediatrician with a complaint of difficulty with balance and coordination. The child's parents report that he has been experiencing tremors in his hands and has been having difficulty with fine motor skills such as writing and buttoning his shirt. Upon further questioning, it is revealed that the child has a history of developmental delay and delayed speech. Physical examination reveals hyperreflexia and ataxia. Further evaluation reveals a decreased serum ceruloplasmin level and elevated serum ferritin levels. The child is ultimately diagnosed with Aceruloplasminemia, a rare genetic disorder characterized by the accumulation of iron in the brain and other tissues due to the absence of ceruloplasmin, a protein that helps to transport iron. Treatment options include chelation therapy to remove excess iron and supportive care for symptoms.
column10: Mrs. K is a 46-year-old woman who presents to the neurology clinic with a three-year history of progressive movement disorder. She reports difficulty with coordination, tremors, and stiffness in her limbs. On physical examination, Mrs. K has bilateral dysmetria, dysdiadochokinesia, and bradykinesia. Additionally, she has a resting tremor in her right arm and cogwheel rigidity in her right leg. Her speech is slurred, and she reports difficulty swallowing. MRI of the brain reveals bilateral basal ganglia T2 hyperintensities. Further evaluation reveals low serum ceruloplasmin levels and elevated serum ferritin levels. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Aceruloplasminemia.

column3: Sarah is a 5-year-old girl who presents with a history of recurrent episodes of swelling and pain in her joints. She has a limited range of motion in her neck and jaw, and her right arm is stiff and immobile. On examination, she has multiple bony lumps on her back, neck, and arms, and her joints are tender to palpation. X-rays reveal heterotopic ossification in her neck, back, and right arm. Further evaluation reveals a mutation in the ACVR1 gene, confirming a diagnosis of fibrodysplasia ossificans progressiva.
column10: John is a 30-year-old male who presents with a history of painful swelling and stiffness in his joints. He states that these symptoms started when he was a child, and they have gradually worsened over time. He also reports having multiple episodes of soft tissue injury, which have resulted in the formation of bone in unusual places. On physical examination, he has limited range of motion in his neck, shoulders, and hips due to bony overgrowth. X-rays reveal the presence of calcified masses in his muscles and connective tissues. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis of fibrodysplasia ossificans progressiva (FOP).

column1: Neonatal acute respiratory distress due to SP-B deficiency
column3: Baby John was born at 38 weeks gestation via C-section due to fetal distress. He presented with tachypnea, grunting, and intercostal retractions shortly after birth. His oxygen saturation was 83% on room air, prompting immediate intubation and mechanical ventilation. Chest X-ray showed diffuse bilateral pulmonary infiltrates. Blood gas analysis revealed respiratory acidosis and hypoxemia. Further workup revealed low levels of surfactant protein B, confirming the diagnosis of neonatal acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to SP-B deficiency. Baby John was started on exogenous surfactant replacement therapy and received supportive care in the neonatal intensive care unit. Despite initial challenges, he gradually improved and was extubated after 10 days. Follow-up evaluations showed normal lung function and growth.
column10: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath and difficulty breathing. He reports a history of recurrent respiratory infections and a recent exacerbation of his symptoms. On examination, the patient is tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute and has reduced oxygen saturation levels. Auscultation reveals diffuse crackles and decreased breath sounds. A chest X-ray shows diffuse bilateral pulmonary infiltrates. Laboratory investigations reveal low levels of SP-B, confirming a diagnosis of Neonatal acute respiratory distress due to SP-B deficiency. The patient is immediately started on oxygen therapy and admitted to the ICU for further management.

column3: A 4-year-old male child is brought to the hospital with a history of bleeding from the umbilical stump and circumcision site that did not stop despite initial management. The child also had easy bruising and prolonged bleeding following minor injuries. The child had a family history of bleeding disorders, and on further workup, he was diagnosed with Congenital factor XIII deficiency. Physical examination revealed multiple ecchymoses and petechiae over the extremities. Laboratory investigations showed a prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) and a reduced factor XIII activity level. The child was managed with factor XIII concentrate replacement therapy and was advised to avoid trauma and contact sports.
column10: John is a 30-year-old male who presents to the emergency department with a history of excessive bleeding after a minor trauma to his arm. He reports a lifelong history of easy bruising and prolonged bleeding after any injuries. He has been diagnosed with Congenital factor XIII deficiency, a rare bleeding disorder that affects the clotting mechanism. On examination, he has multiple bruises and petechiae on his arms and legs. Laboratory investigations show a prolonged clotting time and decreased factor XIII activity. He is treated with factor XIII concentrate and discharged with instructions to avoid trauma and to seek medical attention for any bleeding episodes.

column3: A 6-year-old male child was brought to the emergency department with complaints of excessive bleeding from a small cut on his arm. The parents reported a history of bleeding episodes after minor injuries since the child was an infant. The child had no history of significant trauma or surgery. On examination, the child had petechiae and ecchymoses on his arms and legs. His vital signs were within normal limits. Laboratory investigations showed a prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and a normal activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT). Further evaluation revealed a decrease in factor II (prothrombin) activity, confirming the diagnosis of Congenital factor II deficiency. The child was started on factor II replacement therapy and advised to avoid activities that could lead to bleeding. The child's family members were tested for the same condition, and it was discovered that his mother also had the same deficiency.
column10: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe bleeding from a cut on his hand that occurred while cooking. He reports a history of easy bruising, recurrent nosebleeds, and heavy menstrual bleeding in his mother and sister.
